story:
The Calumet Art Center

Where art, culture, and history inspire and challenge the people of the Keweenaw.

  • Since 2008, the Calumet Art Center has been providing arts education and resources to youth and adults in the Keweenaw.
  • Our organization is community funded, and partners with BHK Child Development to provide much needed after school and summer arts educational programming focused on teaching a wide range of arts through the lens of culture and history.
  • Your contributions are not only 100% tax deductible, they offset the cost of our programs so that we can provide these resources to all children in our area, even those who otherwise could not afford it.  Without you, none of this would be possible.

Our Campaign

  • In order to hire teachers, provide supplies, and keep the center operational, we need to raise $10,000.  Our summer programs have been growing over the last 6 years, and without additional support, we won't be able to continue to provide the excellent instruction and supplies necessary to support these wonderful programs.
  • As a 501(c)3, all donations to our campaign are tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.  If your place of employment offers matching funds for charitable donations, we're happy to help with the necessary paperwork.
  • Every dollar you donate will make a huge difference in our community--it will provide teachers, supplies, and scholarships so that our programs can have the most reach and impact, and so that we can keep the doors open for many more students and families.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every single dollar counts, and no donation is too small to make a difference, but if you don't have a dollar to spare, here are a few things you can still do to help:

  • Send the link to this campaign to your friends, family, coworkers, and contacts.  A personal message goes a long way to convincing your friends to participate.  The indiegogo share tools make it easy to spread the word.
  • Ask about volunteering with our organization!  You can reach out to: info@calumetartcenter.com
  • Leave us a comment on this site showing your support, it will help raise the profile of our campaign so we reach more donors.

Thanks for your help, without you, none of what we do would be possible.

story:
The Nashoba Regional High School (NRHS) DI team from Stow Massachusetts has advanced to compete in the Destination Imagination Global Finals in Knoxville, TN on May 21-24th!   More than 1,300 teams from 45 states, 7 Canadian provinces and 13 countries gather to showcase their Challenge solutions. To get to Globlas the NRHS team needs your help.

This DI Season, the team took first place at regionals and second place at the State tournament.  They also won a very exceptional award DaVinci Award!

This team has exceptional talent and work ethic demonstrated by the fact they have earned all possible DI awards, only 5% of teams reach this kind of success!

The Team:

Kali Cook
Magen Cook
Jessie Duggan
JoJo Enzmann
Kristina MacLure
Rob Pulgarin
Marianna Sardella

These students are the next generation of leaders and innovators. Now they have the opportunity to learn and experience the creative process from imagination to innovation, while participating in teamwork events and gaining confidence in their ability to solve any challenge. They will be meeting others from around the world with one common characteristic, they all love DI!

Their Challenge - Going to Extremes

The team chose the scientific challenge which asks the team to depict an extreme environment with some specific guidelines through creativity without adult interference. All ideas and solutions must be team created and implemented.

  • Research an Extreme Environment that exists in our universe.
  • Present a Story about characters who adapt to survive in the Extreme Environment.
  • Design and create Extreme Gear that is demonstrated by using scientific principles and technical methods.
  • Design and create a depiction of the Extreme Environment.

DI Mission

To develop opportunities that inspire the global community of learners to utilize diverse approaches in applying 21st century skills and creativity.

The Destination Imagination program encourages teams of learners to have fun, take risks, focus and frame challenges while incorporating STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics), the arts and service learning. Our participants learn patience, flexibility, persistence, ethics, respect for others and their ideas, and the collaborative problem solving process. Teams may showcase their solutions at a tournament.

What We need

We need a total of $10,000 dollars to get the team to Tennessee, any donation will help!

  • Meals, Room and Board for team members
  • Travel for team members to and from Tennessee
  • Cargo transport of costumes, backdrops, materials and props
  • Room and Board only for their 2 Team Managers
  • Registration Fees

With your help, we can foster the next generation of risk takers, critical thinkers, problem solvers, leaders and world-class innovators. We hope that you will consider making a tax-deductible gift today of $50, $100, $150 or something meaningful to you that will further advance Destination Imagination's mission and change a child's life by preparing them for future success.
Thank You!
story_txt:
The Nashoba Regional High School (NRHS) DI team from Stow Massachusetts has advanced to compete in the Destination Imagination Global Finals in Knoxville, TN on May 21-24th!   More than 1,300 teams from 45 states, 7 Canadian provinces and 13 countries gather to showcase their Challenge solutions. To get to Globlas the NRHS team needs your help.This DI Season, the team took first place at regionals and second place at the State tournament.  They also won a very exceptional award DaVinci Award!This team has exceptional talent and work ethic demonstrated by the fact they have earned all possible DI awards, only 5% of teams reach this kind of success!
The Team:
Kali CookMagen CookJessie DugganJoJo EnzmannKristina MacLureRob PulgarinMarianna SardellaThese students are the next generation of leaders and innovators. Now they have the opportunity to learn and experience the creative process from imagination to innovation, while participating in teamwork events and gaining confidence in their ability to solve any challenge. They will be meeting others from around the world with one common characteristic, they all love DI!Their Challenge - Going to ExtremesThe team chose the scientific challenge which asks the team to depict an extreme environment with some specific guidelines through creativity without adult interference. All ideas and solutions must be team created and implemented.

Research an Extreme Environment that exists in our universe.


Present a Story about characters who adapt to survive in the Extreme Environment.


Design and create Extreme Gear that is demonstrated by using scientific principles and technical methods.


Design and create a depiction of the Extreme Environment.


DI Mission
To develop opportunities that inspire the global community of learners to utilize diverse approaches in applying 21st century skills and creativity.The Destination Imagination program encourages teams of learners to have fun, take risks, focus and frame challenges while incorporating STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics), the arts and service learning. Our participants learn patience, flexibility, persistence, ethics, respect for others and their ideas, and the collaborative problem solving process. Teams may showcase their solutions at a tournament.What We needWe need a total of $10,000 dollars to get the team to Tennessee, any donation will help!
Meals, Room and Board for team members
Travel for team members to and from Tennessee
Cargo transport of costumes, backdrops, materials and props
Room and Board only for their 2 Team Managers
Registration Fees
With your help, we can foster the next generation of risk takers, critical thinkers, problem solvers, leaders and world-class innovators. We hope that you will consider making a tax-deductible gift today of $50, $100, $150 or something meaningful to you that will further advance Destination Imagination's mission and change a child's life by preparing them for future success.Thank You!

story:
WHAT WE NEED

It takes thousands of dollars to host a Pride Festival. We are asking our community to support our efforts in making this the best festival yet! We are looking to raise $15,000+ between now and our “Free to be You” Pride Festival and Equality Celebration in September.

WHY WE NEED THE COMMUNITY'S SUPPORT

Sedona/Verde Valley Pride is a Non-Profit 501(c)(3) organization. All of the money we use to hold our events each year comes in from your generous donations and sponsorships from local and corporate businesses. In order for us to maintain our mission of educating the whole Verde Valley on issues affecting our LGBT friends, family and neighbors, we must maintain our visibility in the community and we do so with our Annual Pride Festival in September.  Without the support of the community and sponsors, Pride would not exist in Sedona or the Verde Valley.

HOW WE’LL USE YOUR DONATION 

Every year we must rent the tents, tables, chairs, a dance floor and sound equipment to make the festival enjoyable for everyone. With more vending options, more entertainment and more events scheduled than ever before, we need the money to pay for equipment rentals, food & drinks for our events and for marketing & advertising purposes. Your money pays our entertainers, your money helps fund the rentals, your money helps us organize and make our vision a reality. Every dime raised between now and September 25th goes toward this year’s festival.

OUR FESTIVAL HIGHLIGHTS

Sedona Gay Pride began in the city of Sedona and over the years expanded into surrounding communities. Now branded as Sedona/Verde Valley Pride, the annual festival site has been moved to Old Town Cottonwood on the community activities field and offers a central location with sufficient parking for the Saturday Festival. Thursday, Friday and Sunday festival events are in Sedona and surrounding towns.

SEDONA/VERDE VALLEY PRIDE’S FEATURES

With a focus on our community, we have as many local wineries, restaurants, bars, entertainment venues, and other local businesses involved in our festival weekend as possible. Our festival is unique in the fact that events are held at multiple locations throughout the Verde Valley over the course of 4 days.

The Pride Victory Garden is a community favorite and is hosting tours during the festival and this year we introduce a new tradition, “The Wall of History – A Time Line of Pride.”

OUR FESTIVAL EVENT LOCATIONS

Known the world over for its impressive red rock formations, Sedona is also regarded as a spiritual and artistic mecca.  The whole of Verde Valley is nestled among the 1.8 million-acre Coconino National Forest about two hours drive from the Grand Canyon and cross-cut with nearly half a dozen rivers and large creeks, offering a wide variety of outdoor activities to enjoy with family and friends. Each town is a slice of Western Americana set in the beautiful high desert of Central Arizona. (The USGS horizontal survey marker for Arizona is located in Camp Verde’s Rezzonico Park at Beasley Flat on the Verde River) These small desert communities are home to archaeological and geological wonders. With such emphasis on alternative lifestyles and beauty—of both the inner and outer varieties—Sedona/Verde Valley Pride is grateful to have found such a warm welcome  in the heart of Arizona.

Check out the photo galleries from our Pride festivals in the past!

OUR FESTIVAL WEEKEND SHARES THE MESSAGE OF PRIDE

Freedom, love, humanity, equality – what does PRIDE mean to you? Why do we celebrate Pride? At the heart of our celebration we share our history, our heritage and our hopes for the future. We educate those looking for answers and we explain to those who don’t understand. But this effort takes a lot of investment from a dedicated army of volunteers and supporters. By supporting us, you are ensuring that the message continues.

A NEW METHOD OF SUPPORT!

You have an opportunity to grab your own Pride Package and Support Sedona/Verde Valley Pride in a whole new way! This is a unique chance to show your support for Pride and keep the celebrations and education going. 

Choose which donation level you’d like - the more you give, the more we all get!

You have the freedom be who you are and part of our community – one we celebrate!

Click the donate button today and don’t forget to SHARE the love on social media, #free2bu.

story:
Turn up for the Elderly!

Help students in Mrs.Ford's Social Action Class raise money to buy MP3 players for elderly residents at Park Manor Nursing home. Music is known to help people with dementia relive past memories and feelings. Donate money and give back to grandmothers, grandfathers, war veterans, and other courageous men and women that have done their part in the community. For just a small donation, you can make someone's day a little brighter.


What else can you do?

Mp3 player donation boxes are located in central locations, such as the library and front office. Drop off new or gently used Mp3 players ! 


Thank you!

ALL donations are greatly appriciated! Everything helps!

story:
Who We Are

Spark MicroGrants is pioneering a new method of community development that puts rural poor communities at the frontline of their own development. 

We work with these communities to design, implement, and manage their own social impact projects. This month, we are raising money to help the Gahonga village implement a milling machine project that will provide income for their community and allow children to attend school.

Don't stop reading yet. This is where it gets exciting! This is the part where we get to tell you what this project will actually do for the people of Gahonga. 

Currently, women and children walk hours a day to retrieve maize flour. As you can imagine, this takes away tremendous amounts of time that could be spent in school or in income generating activities. Having a milling machine in their own community would allow children to attend school and would allow women more time to participate in community activities and to cultivate business opportunities.

Income generated from the milling machine project will:

  • Provide income to send children to school
  • Allow community members to purchase health insurance, thus improving the overall health in the village
  • Engage women in more income generating activities 
The crazy thing is that this project has a ripple effect larger than we could imagine! Spark communities use income generated from their first project to create more social impact projects and further the betterment of their communities. By donating today, you are investing in so much more than just a milling machine project- you are investing in the future of an entire village! 

How does it work?

Spark communities are provided with an in-country fellow who is responsible for walking communities through a 3-5 month project planning process. During this time, the community meets weekly to identify their most pressing problem and to build a plan that will address that problem.

After the planning process has been completed, Spark provides a microgrant (a small sum of money that does not have to be repaid) to the community to help the community get the project up and running.


Community Background

Situated in the Burera District in Rwanda, the Gahonga community is composed of 138 households. Community members have low income due to infertile soil and a lack of access to clean water and electricity. The community has identified several problems, but agreed that the one they would like to address is the time it takes children and women in the village to travel a long distance in order to buy maize flour, the most basic ingredient used for cooking in Rwanda. Having to travel long distances for maize flour has resulted in children being absent from school and women missing crucial time needed to preform income generating activities.

Community-Designed Solution

Gahonga has chosen to address this challenge through a milling machine project. Not only will this project reduce the long distance that community members are obliged to go for maize flour, and thus enable children to receive proper education and women to use their time more efficiently, but it will also generate income for the community. 

Here's the Deal

In order to purchase this milling machine and allow the Gahonga children to attend school and women to have time for income generating activities, we need you to help us raise $12,847. 

This money will:

  • Provide the $6000 it will take to purchase the milling machine.
  • Provide the $5000 it costs to employ a Rwandan Facilitator to be a part of the planning and implementation process.
  • Provide the $600 for expert advice on the project to ensure its safety and effectiveness.
  • Provide the $1247 that will be charged as a part of Indiegogo's usage fees. 

Here at Spark, we are unyielding optimists! We believe that with your help we can go above and beyond our goal. 

If we do so, we will be able to put the extra money toward other Spark community projects that are currently in the planning stage! Some of these projects include vocational schools, business projects, and more. 

To thank you for your donation, we would like to invite you into our Spark family! That means receiving exclusive photo stories with insight into the lives of our partner communities, video greetings from our facilitators and founder, and even videos of traditional Gahonga dances. Our goal is to get to know you, thank you, and let you get to know us. 

The Impact

Other Ways You Can Help

Feeling excited about an innovative approach to international aid, but can't contribute financially? That's ok! 

There are other ways you can help:

Spread the word about this campaign. The more people that know about Spark's work, the better! Like us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter.

story:
Short Summary

In April, I volunteered as the PR/social media lead for a one-off coding workshop Dallas. The community response was swift and eager. The event was a success, but it left parents looking for the next opportunity for their children to learn more. And with that, I decided to launch The Tomorrow Techies.

About The Tomorrow Techies workshops

  • Open to both boys and girls
  • For students in grades 6 - 12
  • Offered at Richland College beginning this fall
  • Tuition from $45
  • Will launch with HTML and CSS workshops, with future offerings to include launching and promoting your blog, how to make money with a YouTube channel, using Wordpress, Javascript, Ruby, and more.
  • Instructors are professionals in the tech community, TA's will often be college students studying technology

Why we need your help

We want to give the community the best value and to do that, it's going to take some start-up funds. Our $10,000 goal will cover our first year of operation and get us off to a great start. Here's how it will be applied:

  • Compensating instructors and TA's - We understand the value of a motivated team. Paying for their time and knowledge is probably the biggest reason we're launching this campaign.
  • Techie scholarships - A scholarship fund for techies who need assistance with our tuition.
  • Student gifts - As a thank you for joining us, students will receive a t-shirt. Other thank you gifts will be planned as the workshops grow.
  • Branding, marketing, and promotion - When people are looking for you, you'd better make sure they have something good to look at. We have a network of creatives who would love to help us put our best foot forward--and we'd like pay them, too.

The Impact

Because I was the primary point of contact for the workshop, I got to see first-hand how many parents were overjoyed for their children to have this opportunity. It was also very inspiring to see how excited the kids were to create something of their own. The future is in STEM careers, and by fostering an early interest in technology, students can build upon what we've shown them and hopefully enter lucrative careers in tech.

(A little-known fact: I taught myself how to write HTML in the late 90s out of sheer curiosity and started building websites and blogs. Fast-forward to 2004, I landed my first job out of college with BlackAmericaWeb.com, not only on the fact that I was a good writer, but that I knew how to code. That led to a 10 year career in digital marketing.) 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    I believe in a skill share! If you can't contribute much to our campaign, email us at info@tomorrowtechies.com to discuss how you can help with:

    • Creating lesson plans
    • Creative support (logo design, photography, video & editing)
    • Public relations and community outreach support

    And of course, you can always help by sharing our Indiegogo campaign. Thank you so much for reading all the way to the end. Here's to The Tomorrow Techies!

story:
Hello,

  My name is Elizabeth and I am deeply passionate about children. In particular the children of Uganda, a beautiful country that God led me to in 2006. The first time I stepped foot onto African soil my heart was captured. Through out the years I have been back to Uganda and worked in several areas of ministry. This summer I have returned to minister and teach in a primary school for a year. I will be teaching and ministering to vulnerable children many of who are orphans. Uganda has over 2.5 million orphans due to disease mainly AIDS.

I believe that no matter where these children have come from  there is HOPE for a bright future. I desire to instill hope in these precious children's lives, by teaching them in a school setting and opening their eyes to knowing Jesus as their Savior and friend. I desire for the children  to know and see that they are Loved, valued, and precious. I want them to feel taken care of and protected in the ways I am able to ,and  truly know that no matter how they feel they are NEVER alone. As Jesus Christ extravagantly loves them and is right by there side.

By donating you are truly helping to create change on the other side of the world. The change starts in the classroom by letting the children know that they are valued and that we believe in their potential. After the classroom the change in one child will make a positive impact in his brothers and sisters lives and it truly can have a ripple effect. 

Overtime the change will be felt in the whole community. As the children grow up the values and hope that have been instilled in them will follow them into adulthood and ultimately they be able to give hope to their own families. This type of HOPE and change is priceless.

The funds will be going to the following  areas ; children's scholastic materials,sports and recess equipment , my food,housing  and transportation. Fun activities like arts and crafts projects for the children will also  take a portion of the funding. 

Ministry is beautiful and powerful. But it takes a village of support to be equipped. Thank you for all of your support! Because of You these children will have a much brighter future. 

Blessings, Elizabeth

story:
UPDATE: I now have an anonymous donator who agreed to match up to $5000 donated!! So every $1 you give now equals $2 towards much needed Arts Education!

Help me raise funds to open Jacksonville Arts & Music School, JAMS a new nonprofit arts education organization dedicated to developing creative minds and encouraging education among youth.

I am creating JAMS for my final project to receive my Master of Arts Administration at Savannah College of Art and Design.

JAMS will strive to make the arts more accessible to underprivileged youth and foster a safe haven of positive reinforcement and creativity. This afterschool community center will drive students to express themselves and work to grow their creative and academic skills. The artistic environment in which I grew up developed my passion for the arts and an open attitude toward life; therefore I passionately believe that arts should be a part of every child’s education, no matter their economic background. The decline of arts education in schools drove me to design JAMS because I believe the artistic influences in my life introduced another world of opportunity and provided experiences that allowed for life perspective and expression.

Jacksonville, Florida does not currently have an organizational system in place to be able to serve the amount of underprivileged students in the area. Currently, there are 127,085 students in Jacksonville, FL that do not receive arts education. There is a great demand to meet the needs of the remaining students. For example, one of the largest arts education organizations, Cathedral Arts Project, only serves 2,000 students. Arts education dwindled after the economic recession, creating a surplus of underprivileged students without access to arts education opportunities. JAMS would tap in to that target market, filling the standing void. No one organization can tackle the number of students throughout Jacksonville that are in need of arts education but with the introduction of JAMS, student exposure to the arts in Jacksonville will be increased with every student who walks through our doors.

I picked JAMS as my final project because of my passionate belief in the need of increased arts education in inner city Jacksonville. My commitment to JAMS has spanned nearly a year and after meeting with numerous parties on the matter I realize the extent of the need. The initial stages of the organization are prepped and ready to go, I am dedicated to see this project through, JAMS will one day open its doors. I feel that if the board gives me the chance to put my plan into action, they will not be disappointed but will be proud to play a part in helping kick start the early stages of one of the best arts organizations in Jacksonville, Florida.

I have defined the need not only by data but also by talking to the police department, who have helped me identify two hot spot areas of major lack of resources for youth.  One in north Moncrief Rd. and Soutel Dr., and one in District Seven area in the square comprised of Talleyrand Ave, 8th St., North Liberty and The Arlington expressway. 

In District Seven, The Police Athletic League (PAL), which serves over 2,000 kids annually, and can not keep up with the demand. There is an over crowded PAL at 1050 Franklin St Jacksonville, FL 32206 where intend to focus. In the heart of District Seven, many people have implored to me the overwhelming need for after school help. This is a huge area of need not only for after school help with homework, but also exposing children to the arts. My experience at working for Cathedral Arts Project as Program Coordinator gives me great insight into the needs of students, schools and communities as well as the programming knowledge needed to fulfill those needs. With my passion, knowledge and commitment, Jacksonville Arts & Music School will open its door to expose the under served to the arts.

story:
Who is going?

I am a recent graduate of Shepherd University in Shepherdstown, West Virginia USA with his Bachelor's Degree in Music. My primary focus is in music composition. I have been composing since 2009; and, have studied composition with a number of outstanding professionals since. While attending Shepherd, I served as one of the founders, and officers of Shepherd's student chapter of Society of Composers Inc. (SCI). I have also performed with many of the music department's ensembles, have experience in conducting, and helped with several years of music-related events hosted by the Shepherd Music Department. After completing my undergraduate studies at Shepherd, I have been working on refining my craft with a variety of small projects community and various public school commissions. MIDI realizations of most of my works can be found on my soundcloud page here: https://soundcloud.com/kaz-white 

Where is he going?

The Setnor School of Music at Syracuse University!! I have always had a passion for the Appalachian region and its beautiful mountains. To be able to attend a school that is settled right within that prime geographical region is simply perfect.

When is he going?

I will be moving to Syracuse on Saturday, August 9th. The orientation for all graduate students and graduate teaching assistants is the following week. Classes begin August 18th. It is a two-year program; so, I expect to be graduating at the end of May, 2016.

What is he doing?

I will be pursuing a Masters Degree in Music Composition. I will also be a graduate teaching assistant for the first-year music theory classes. While studying at Syracuse, I hope to also continue playing clarinet in one of their wind ensembles as well as furthering my education as a conductor. I will also continue to pursue and develop my interests in Appalachian Culture and Heritage; and, I will consistently be working to tie that into the music I write. After earning my masters degree, I am considering working towards a second masters in Conducting. 

Where does your contribution go?

Overall, my budget plan for moving is to have already saved roughly three months' worth of rent, as well as anything from $500-$2000 in savings to act as a buffer for any required purchases within my first two weeks of classes. I would like that to cover textbooks, teaching materials, hidden fees from the university, and new literature for study in my private lessons (both composition and clarinet).

Luckily, I was fortunate enough to receive one of the music school's teaching assistantships. With that assistantship comes a tuition credit waiver as well as a salary paid in twice-per-month installments. Because Syracuse is a larger and more popular city, rent is incredibly expensive. Additional bills, regular public transportation fees, and other things like groceries will also be fairly expensive.

Your contribution will go towards any additional fees from the university as well as any and all living expenses that will not be covered by the assistantship paycheck. Your help will also be put towards additional career costs such as score printing, recording costs, and instrument maintenance and repair.

There are also those times when accidents or unfortunate circumstances occur; for instance: bicycle damage (as it will be the main source of transportation), health-related issues, an error in billing for living expenses. Heaven forbid anything of that sort does occur, but your contribution will help act as a buffer and safe-zone savings for those occasions. 

What happens if the goal is not met?

While there is the possibility that this goal will not be met, I still plan on using any and all received funds to cover the listed points above. I am not one to spend frivolously. I am extremely particular on budgeting and long-term planning. That being said, your contribution will not be wasted on items of personal enjoyment nor any other excessive purchases. Items of that nature will be purchased with money saved up after I have fully established myself in Syracuse.

What do you get for contributing?

There is a very large variety of perks that are available to you as a thanks for contributing!! The very lowest-tier and simplest perk is a personalized, well-thought-out, and hand-written letter from me thanking you for all of your support. Additional things such as pictures, t-shirts, and stickers are added throughout the different tiers corresponding to the donation amounts.

The higher-tiered perks include a personal, guided video tour of my favorite places around Syracuse, including certain areas of campus; a personalized visualization and creation of your favorite piece of music, as seen through the eyes of a synesthete; and best of all, your very own commission of a piece from me! As a composer, I'm always looking for new material; and, now you can help!! With these four-highest perks, you can actually see your donations dollars at-work. All you have to do is email me what sort of group you want to perform, and what you want the piece to sound like. Additional details are listed in the perk explanation and you will receive your very own signed copy of the score and a recording. NOTE: Making a recording is not free; and therefore, your donation will go towards getting a recording made especially for you!! 

All of the perks are inclusive; by which I mean, when choosing a higher-tiered perk, you will also receive the perks of any/all lower-tiered perks up to that donation level. NOTE: All commissions will include the perks until the $100 donation as I will not write 4 different pieces for someone if he/she donates $1000. ALSO: Any commission recipients will still receive a Synesthesia Visualization, so be sure to include your song-of-choice for that as well.

    How can I trust my donation will be used properly?

    In the past, I have been the recipient of the Jefferson County McCormick Scholarship that provides full-payment for tuition, room/board, and textbooks. I was able to maintain and adequately budget that money throughout my entire undergraduate career. I also received the WV Promise Scholarship (tuition) as well as the Federal Pell Grant and the WV Higher Education Grant. All of which were put towards expenses such as a complete cleaning and mechanic overhaul on my clarinet and the printing of all scores and parts for my senior composition recital.

    Do I have to contribute money?

    No! Not at all!! If you just wish to express your emotional support towards this new step in my life, it is greatly appreciated!! If you would like to donate any items towards my education (such as office supplies) or new apartment (such as odds and ends like dishes or towels), that's super cool too! This campaign is simply to put my plans out there with the help of anyone and everyone willing to see this next step in my career become a success.

    Can I share this campaign information with my friends & family?

    Absolutely!! Feel free to spread the information about this campaign as far and wide as you'd like!! I am not opposed to receiving messages from someone I've never met, half-way around the world, interested in hearing the music I have to offer and seeing that I am able to make more of it!! It is possible to share this campaign through Facebook, on Twitter, and even just copy/pasting the link wherever you like.

    Can I share your story & information with my friends & family?

    Most definitely!! I love meeting new people and learning about their stories, their experiences, their education, and most of all their talents! As such, I have no problem what-so-ever with wanting to share that with anyone else who's interested and willing to listen. Even if you don't want to contribute, but want to spread the news about the work I do, that is supportive in itself and extremely appreciated!!

story:
I am Helen Howard, and H&RH Escargots is one of the few UK snail farms growing edible snails and helping other people to grow their own snails at home. As a teacher I believe it is vital for young children to learn about living things through practical experience not just by reading about them in books. I am keen to support schools in helping children to learn in an engaging way.

The National Curriculum is so demanding that it is easy for other important learning to get lost in the time pressure. A mini snail farm sitting at the side of the classroom so children can take turns to care for the snails extends their learning and is a reminder of the importance of the living world.

My snail farm came to public attention through TV appearances on Countryfile, the Alan Titchmarsh show, Great British Menu and Easter Eggs Live. Press articles  include the Guardian, the Independent, Amateur Gardener, Smallholder Review and Metropolitan magazine. Last year Molluscs and Me was published: my story about setting up and running the snail farm. More recently I appeared on BBC Breakfast on a Sunday morning and Taste Of Britain.

Why choose a mini snail farm?

Baby snails are very engaging, even if they are not on your list of favourite animals because they might eat your garden plants. 

Just look at those long slender antennae that look too heavy for their heads. 

When they can smell food, watch them zip around at an amazing speed for such a small creature.

Mini Snail Farm Contents


A mini snail farm provides 6 baby snails and everything you need to look after them:

·  Attractive housing

·  Convenient bedding

·  Special baby snail food to supply their early nutritional requirements

·  Care instructions so the children know how to keep the snails healthy and growing well.

In school, snails are undemanding to keep and it would be difficult to find an animal that shows so many features relevant to early learning about science. In winter they hibernate and in summer when it’s hot and dry they aestivate. Their shells are constructed in a spiral form perfect for growing with the snail’s body. They are very important in the natural balance of wildlife in the UK, providing food for an enormous range of other animals from badgers to shrews and from birds to beetles. 

The aspects of the national curriculum that can be illustrated through studying snails include:

·  Respect for living things

·  the main external parts of the body


·  How snails explore the world around them

·  What snails eat and what eats them

·  Life cycles

·  Different kinds of snails living in the school grounds – use of keys

·  Life Processes

·  Shell and epiphragm for protection

·  hibernation and aestivation

Snail behaviour, for example, their homing instinct could provide the basis for the children to carry out a range of scientific explorations.

Vision 

We need your support to take mini snail farms into 50 selected UK schools to support teachers in providing opportunities for children to learn about living things. 

Our mission is to promote science education in primary schools so that the next generation understands more about the world around them

We have spent eight years developing the mini snail farm through Meet the Snail Days in primary and nursery schools and at Slow Summer Snail Farm.

Indiegogo is an international platform and it is only right that our campaign should launch here. 

What will your contribution do?

Help cover the minimum cost of production/delivery for 50 mini snail farms to UK schools

  • cover the cost of selecting schools from all over the UK that will benefit most from this opportunity
  • Cover the cost of components and packaging for the mini snail farms.
  • Cover the cost of storage and postage for mini snail farms to selected schools. 

Testimonials

“My little boy had to keep going back every 10 minutes to see if they’d grown yet.”

“The baby snails are so cute! I thought I didn’t like snails until I met these beautiful creatures.”

“We’ve tried giving them lots of different kinds of food and been surprised at the things they didn’t like.”

“Just watching the muscles ripple along the foot as they move is mesmerising and I had no idea they had teeth.”

“To be honest I was a bit squeamish about snails before I met them but they are quite engaging aren’t they?”

Risks and Challenges 

The greatest potential problem is managing the logistics of delivering the snail farms and the perks in a timely manner. Using the Indegogo platform gives me the chance to have a team that will support me and make sure we meet our responsibilities with regards to delivery dates.

Occasionally the delivery system lets us all down. But in the unfortunate circumstance where some snails do not survive their journey, they will of course be replaced.

Share

Please help spread the campaign Mini Snail Farm Trail. Even if you can't give a contribution, spreading this page via all social media platforms and through family and friends will help us a lot!

Thank You

story:
What is Merit Academy Space Center?

Merit College Preparatory Academy is a public charter school located at 1440 West Center Street, in Springville, Utah. We are a school committed to ensuring a quality education for each one of our students. At Merit, we aim to prepare students to succeed in higher education and in life. Our faculty is dedicated to create a safe environment for students to excel.  Our Space Education program aims to empower students by teaching them real life skills and giving them an advantage in the workplace. With a focus on Service, Leadership and Academic excellence, they have dedicated themselves to our cause: Giving students of Southern Utah County the opportunity to experience a taste of life in space. We are building two space ship simulators, the Excalibur and the Katana.  Along with the simulators, we are building a classroom area for students to learn about the cosmos and a gift shop!

What We Need

We are trying to raise $5,000. We know that this won't be easy, but with your help, we can reach it! 

The Impact!

People who come to the space center will be able to go on exciting science fiction missions, and learn teamwork, leadership, and communication skills. The space center will also help drive students towards STEM careers and help them excel in their problem solving skills. When completed, the Merit Academy Space Center will be an effective and exciting educational experience.  

Risks & Challenges

Building two fully functional spaceship simulators and a classroom learning experience doesn't come cheap. Computers, cameras, TVs, and other electronic equipment is required. Building materials, plans, computer programs, and tools can also pose a challenge. However, we can, with your help, overcome these challenges and get the supplies needed to go forward with our mission. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't donate, please like Merit College Prep Academy on Facebook and spread the word about our educational endeavor.

  Other Ways You Can Help If you just can't donate, please like Merit College Prep Academy on Facebook and spread the word about our educational endeavor.

story:
Got Lit? You'll Have It -- If you do Shakespeare and Journalism

Dear Friends,

Just 30 percent of third-graders in the New Haven Public Schools can read at grade level. Studies show that if a child is behind in reading in third grade, he or she will stay behind.

To promote literacy in a fun and interesting way, Mauro-Sheridan teachers Jodi Schneider and Judy Nacca have brought actor/director Jeremy Funke and journalist Alix Boyle to lead after school programs that reinforce reading, writing, critical thinking, cultural literacy and public speaking.

Funke, a Harvard graduate, writes kid-friendly adaptations of the Bard’s plays for students in third to eighth grade. Since moving to Connecticut in 2005, Funke has appeared in numerous productions with New Haven’s Elm Shakespeare Company (ESC), where he serves as its Resident Teaching Artist. Locally he has appeared with Shakespeare on the Sound, Long Wharf Theater’s Stage II, and countless other theaters along the shoreline. He has conducted theater residencies at high schools in New Haven through ESC, performance workshops in conjunction with the NEA’s Poetry Out Loud competition, and appeared in numerous educational performances with ESC and New Haven's Collective Consciousness Theatre. This year at Mauro-Sheridan, 30 children will perform his original adaptation of As You Like It. Previously for Mauro-Sheridan, Funke directed his adaptations of Julius Caesar, Macbeth and The Tempest.

Boyle, a journalist and public relations professional whose work has been published in The New York Times, The Hartford Courant, Parents magazine and numerous other publications, coaches students in how to write newspaper articles, shoot photos, edit and create headlines. The result is The MASH News, a completely student-produced school newspaper.

We are passionate about this program because we want to see our students succeed.

We are trying to raise $2,000 that will pay for:

·  Costumes

·  Scenery

·  Props

·  Printing Expenses (scripts, programs, etc.)

·  Healthy Snacks

·  Software and Notebooks

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Spread the word, send our link to anyone who might be interested in contributing.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Quick Summary

I've enrolled in the world challenge program in order to go on an expedition which I feel will prove to be life changing  and completely change my perspective of the world and me as a person. 

This expedition is extremely important to me as I've always wanted to go on an expedition like this and from this trip i'll gain immense skills in: 

  • Communication 
  • Teamwork & Leadership 
  • Enterprise & Money Management 
  • Cultural perspective

What I Need 

  • I need around £500 to pay for equipment, vaccinations and fees for this campaign.
  • If the full amount  isn't raised  then I'll be going to Ethiopia with a rucksack and a sleeping bag...

What I'll do

In order to raise this sum of money I will be running a half marathon (52 laps around a 400 meter track) on the 28th of June!

Other Ways You Can Help


In all honesty I have eluded to the idea of fundraising due to the pressure of exams and  at times shear laziness but at this moment in time any form of help would be extremely appreciated. 

If you are unable to donate any sum of money then it would also be greatly  appreciated if you could share this page or let me know of anyone that could help with the purchasing of equipment.

Thank you.

story:
General Information

The Bridge was conceived by two native-born and globally-trained executives who have a passion for elevating excellence in Nigerian youth. The two identified a gap in the skill-sets exhibited by young graduates and new entrants into the Nigerian labour market and were compelled to find a solution. 

The Bridge aims to address these shortcomings—workforce incompetence, unethical leadership and unemployment—by training of the youth and encouraging job creation by the youth. The Bridge seeks to groom, empower and inspire young adults to strive for excellence and achieve self-actualisation. The program is positioned to help participants attain global professional competency, become contenders for impactful career opportunities and leadership roles and become entrepreneurs that create job in their communities.

Our vision is to see a socially, economically and politically prosperous Nigeria driven by Ethical leaders. Our success will be to transform participants into young leaders who will ensure the socio, cultural, economic and political landscape they inhabit is affected positively and ultimately altered permanently by their presence and decisions. We will equip and motivate these young leaders to identify and maximize their full potential as catalysts for change and growth. Our mandate is to ensure the actualisation of leadership potential, innovation and professionalism in our participants’ career and entrepreneurial endeavours. We truly believe the program will help uncover and expand the opportunities available to all participants.


What We Need 

We need all the help we can get as we set to pilot the program with a 4-week camp in July. You can support us by giving monetary or in-kind donations, your skills and your time (contact us via email if you want to donate in-kind or via checks or direct deposit).

Our funding goal has been set at $20000. This is how much we need to pilot the first phase of the program - intensive 4-week camp starting in mid-July for 4 weeks. It will fund 12-15 participants.

No donation is too small and while our funding target may seem lofty, anything contributed is entirely welcome. 


The Impact

At the end of the intensive program participants will have an increased awareness of their role as job creators, great leaders and competitive and ethical service men and women. Emphasis shall also be placed on entrepreneurship as a legitimate career choice, studies on ideal leadership models, and essential business and professional skills that are critical to our mandate - their development. Ultimately, these young leaders will be better prepared for the next phase of their life journey - their careers. 


Risks & Challenges

We realize that there are certain hurdles that we have to overcome in our efforts to achieve our goals. 

  • Publicizing the program and recruiting participants (as this is the pilot project)
  • Raising the requisite finance 
  • The short time period we have till the proposed start of the project is in itself, a challenge

Despite these challenges, we are resolute in our efforts to make The Bridge Project a reality. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, it's no problem. You can provide assistance in any of the following ways. 

  • Liking our Facebook page (The Bridge Project) and spreading the word
  • Donating non-monetary resources such as volunteering time (if applicable).
  • Referring The Bridge Project to potential speakers (inspirational leaders in industry) and participants. 

Please contact us at thebridgeprogramng@gmail.com for more details.

story:
Brandeis Students Are Going to the PCM!

We're taking Brandeis students to the People's Climate March this Sunday – but we need your help! Chip in to subsidize the cost of the bus so we can offer cheap tickets to those who need them.

What We Need

The total cost of chartering a 57 person bus from Brandeis to NYC and back in 1 day came out to about $2,400. We've fronted that money and are asking students to pay what they can for their tickets, but we're estimating we'll need to make up between $1,000 and $1,500 from various sources.

This fundraiser will help put us back in a more financially stable situation. When we have a better idea of the total amount we'll need to raise and what other sources of funding we have, we'll post updates!

Why We're Doing This

We know this march is gonna be big, and we know we need everyone there. We also know it's gonna be inspiring, empowering, and radicalizing. We want to make sure Brandeis students have the opportunity to be there. If the People's Climate March is going to change everything, that change is going to have to carry on from this Sunday, and we can't wait to have Brandeis students coming back to campus  pumped up and ready to bring the power they felt at the march to their campaigns, their clubs, their local organizations.

#FillThatBus

Know any Brandeis students who are might be interested in coming? Or perhaps you have a listserve, a class, or a group that you could let know about our bus. We still have seats on the Brandeis bus, so sign up here: http://bit.ly/X9HmYN

story:
HISTORY

Major Nathaniel Cheairs built the Greek Revival brick structure on property originally purchased by his father in 1811. The current rear wing was the original two-story house and detached smokehouse which was constructed before the main house and was occupied by the Cheairs family until the main house was completed in 1855. Afterwards, it was used as a kitchen and living quarters for slaves and servants. The Cheairs family enjoyed a few peaceful years before the Civil War began.

The Battle of Spring Hill brought the Civil War to Rippavilla. On the morning of November 30, 1864, General John Bell Hood ordered his subordinate commanders to meet him at Rippavilla for a meeting before proceeding to Franklin. The meeting, also referred to as Hood’s War council breakfast, occurred in the dining room after being served coffee, ham and biscuits by Mrs. Cheairs. Rippavilla was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on July 19, 1996 for historic significance,

CURRENTLY

In addition to being a non-traditional educational setting for local schools, Rippavilla is a tourist destination for vacationers and tour bus groups. For the past ten years, tourism has been and continues to be one of the top five economic drivers in Middle Tennessee and Rippavilla’s role in local tourism enables Maury County to compete with surrounding counties and attract this stream of tax revenue.

Rippavilla sponsors a Boy Scout Troop and a Girl Scout Troop as part of its community outreach. Both troops are allowed to meet and camp on the site’s 89 acres.

Throughout the last 18 years, Rippavilla, Inc and the board of directors have worked diligently to become good financial stewards of this stately antebellum mansion. As a 501(c)(3) non-profit we do not receive any financial help from local, state or federal governments. There have been varied fundraisers throughout the years, corn maze, bridal fairs, vintage marketplace, paranormal investigations, Civil War reenactments, etc to raise the much needed funds. Due to the age of the house, 159 years old, and the cost to maintain the house and property the fundraisers have not been able to provide enough monetary gain for the necessary repairs.

NEEDS

On the rear wing, the existing metal standing seam roof and metal gutters were installed the early 1900s (some research indicates both roof and gutters were installed in 1914) have rusted throughout the years allowing rain to leak into the interior. As a result, interior plaster damage ($2,025) is apparent in the original kitchen. Repairs to the roof ($9,050) and gutters ($2,750) are of vital importance as to prevent moisture from creating exterior structural damage to the bricks and mortar and the interior plaster.

On the main house, a new copper roof and flashing were installed in 1996, when Rippavilla, Inc was incorporated, but through the years the flashing joints have eroded allowing moisture to enter the interior walls and ceiling of the original dining room gradually break downing the plaster resulting in bits of plaster falling on the furnishings and floor.

Repairing the flashing on the connecting hallway roof ($350) and plaster in the dining room of the mansion ($3,500) is of vital importance as to prevent further damage to the plaster and the original wood lath supporting the plaster. If the flashing is not repaired, moisture could begin to damage the exterior brick wall and mortar potentially resulting in structural damage. Also, the walls and ceiling are a very visible part of our tours as well as part of the area used for fundraising dinners.

The home has 60 shuttered windows that were originally hung in the 1950's. The shutters were repaired in 2004 by local Amish carpenters but have begun to deteriorate again due to weather. Some shutters on the south and west side of the home have fallen off completely and shutters on other sides have started to lose slats. The cost for new historically accurate shutters is $30,000 for all 60 windows.

Thank you for taking time to read about our wonderful mansion. We understand that you may not be able to help financially at this time, but we would like you to help us get the word out through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or email. 

Question and Answers:

Can I donate any amount of money to your cause? Yes, any amount is appreciated. 

Can my donation be tax-deductible?  Yes. We are a 501 (c) 3 tax exempt corporation.

story:
Hey family, friends and all my supporters on here... The holiday season is upon us once again and there is a great need for Christmas gifts for the kiddos in my foster agency. There are over seventy kids that come out to the annual Christmas party to see Santa. Unfortunately, Santa is kinda broke and the agency needs help. I am trying to contribute as much as I can to this event aside from starting up Foster Connect La﻿ and I can't do it all alone. Last year with the help from so many of you I was able to purchase the gifts for all of the teenage girls and one very special 17 year old boy, named Alex who was very obsessed with Star Wars(he got a nice Lego set) thanks to so many of your donations. Last year I started this very last minute so I am hoping that this year I can put together a larger fund to donate more toys to these kids. So many times these kids don't get to spend it with their loved ones but my goal in this is to at least put in real energy into a gift that will put a smile on their faces. I need your help with a donation of $5. If  I have enough people donating just $5 I can help with 20 kids in the agency. Please let me know if you can help. 


Donations can be donated here or sent to my email if you have bofa as your banking institution (josieindart@gmail.com)

story:
I am a Junior at the University of Hawaii Maui College and have been nominated to represent the United States, my university and my community as a member of the International Scholar Laureate Program (ISLP) Delegation on May 27, 2014 through June 9, 2014 in China.

ISLP nominates exceptional college and university students from around the country to this experiential educational program. I have enclosed a sample of our itinerary for your review. As you can see, this will be a powerful experience, enabling me to interact with many prominent men and women in engineering and technology.

Attending this program will challenge me to develop my leadership skills and reach my career goals of becoming an engineer with a focus on energy management and efficiency. I am focusing on my liberal arts degree right now and plan to graduate in 2015 with goals to continue on to electrical engineering at University of Hawaii Manoa campus. I maintain a 3.91 GPA, am involved in training other students in energy auditing and was recently awarded certifications in Energy Management and Production, Home Energy Surveying and Commercial Energy Auditing.

Imagine if you had been given this opportunity for a life changing experience when you were in college and were unable to participate for lack of funds. The program cost including tuition and travel will exceed $8,000. I am investing every dollar I can of my own money to make sure I don’t miss out on this once‐in‐a‐lifetime experience.  I currently work full time at Mana Foods as a produce clerk, part time for Green Building Hawaii as an energy consultant and go to school part time in order to support my education and live here in Maui.

If you want to know what your money will be contributing to I have attached a copy of all the activities I will be able to be a part of due to your financial support.  If you don't want to contribute through my Indiegogo site you can join me at Flatbread Paia on April 22nd, Earth day, for a fund raiser and silent auction. 


International Scholar Laureate Program Delegation Itinerary to China

The International Scholar Laureate Program (ISLP) Delegation on Engineering & Technology in China will provide you with access to the people, places and perspectives at the core of the engineering powerhouse that is today’s China.

Through special access to engineering marvels, lectures by top engineers and government officials, exciting activities, group discussions and immersion in the sights, sounds, people and places that make up this exotic land, you will return with not only a new perspective on China, but also on the future of engineering and the role you want to play in it.

Beijing

Cultural Excursions included in the Program:

Tian’anmen Square is the political heart of modern China. At 100 acres, it is the largest public square in the world. Known as the site of massive student protests, it is the entry point to the Forbidden City. The square features famous monuments including the Gate of Heavenly Peace and the mausoleum of former Chinese ruler Mao Zedong.

China’s former imperial palace, the Forbidden City, has been home to a long line of emperors, from Yongle in 1420 through Puyi in 1924. The political center of Chinese government for five centuries, it now houses the Palace Museum, which contains the largest collection of imperial artwork and artifacts in the country.

The Great Wall of China is the world's longest human-made structure, stretching across approximately 4,500 miles. It is a series of stone and earthen fortifications constructed and maintained between the 5th century BC and the 16th century AD. Originally built to keep nomads out of China, it is today considered a symbol of Chinese unity and is one of the world’s most recognizable landmarks. The Great Wall was named a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1987.

Each week, Chinese students congregate at the English Corner on the campus of Renmin University to practice their English-speaking skills. A unique opportunity to meet and interact with Chinese citizens, English Corner welcomes native English speakers to converse with the students on a variety of topics, from politics to pop culture.

The Olympic Green was developed for the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing. These unique new Beijing landmarks include the Laoshan Velodrome, the National Aquatics Center (“Water Cube”) and the National Stadium (“Bird’s Nest”), where the grandeur of the opening and closing ceremonies dazzled the world.

Cultural Excursions for Independent Exploration during free time (if desired, local guides will be available to facilitate individual purchase for admission):

The Temple of Heaven was built in 1420 for emperors to worship Heaven and is China’s largest complex of ancient sacrificial buildings. The main buildings include the Altar of Prayer for Good Harvests, the Imperial Mound of Heaven and the Circular Mound Altar. The temple was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1998.

The Summer Palace for Chinese royalty was built 800 years ago and is said to be the largest imperial garden in the world. It first opened to the public in 1911, so that visitors could enjoy the natural beauty of the landscape mingled with the stunning architecture at this ancient royal retreat.

Beijing Zoo is the largest zoo in China. Called Wanshengyuan (Ten Thousand Animal Garden) during the Qing Dynasty, it was officially renamed in 1955. Beijing Zoo currently houses over 7,000 different animals, comprising more than 600 species. Highlights for visitors are the animals native to China, including the Golden Monkey and, of course, the Giant Panda, known the world over as a Chinese national symbol.

Yichang

Cultural Excursions included in the Program:

The Three Gorges Dam on the Yangtze River produces hydroelectricity, increases the river's navigation capacity, and reduces the potential for floods downstream by providing flood storage space. The project management and the Chinese state regard the project as a historic engineering, social and economic success, a breakthrough in the design of large turbines, and a move toward the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. However, the dam has also flooded archaeological and cultural sites, displaced over a million people and has significantly changed the ecological landscape.

Shanghai

Cultural Excursions included in the Program:

Shanghai is China’s largest city and the financial, commercial and industrial hub of the country. Located at the mouth of the Yangtze River, Shanghai is well-known for its modern Pudong skyline, featuring such noted landmarks as the Oriental Pearl Tower, the Jin Mao Tower and the Shanghai World Financial Center.

In Shanghai, scholars will take in the thrilling spectacle of the ERA Acrobatics Show. Marvel at amazing acrobatic feats performed to original music in a show that amazes and entertains.

Cultural Excursions for Independent Exploration during free time:

Shanghai Museum is a grand collection of ancient art, containing eleven galleries and three special temporary exhibition halls. The museum, located in the People’s Square since 1996, houses approximately 120,000 works of art.

The Bund is a famous waterfront, regarded as a symbol of the city of Shanghai. At less than one mile in length, the Bund is the perfect place for a short stroll along the Hunagpu River and is packed with notable buildings, including the Oriental Pearl TV Tower and the Jin Mao Tower. The highlight of the Bund is the west side, featuring 52 buildings of varying architectural styles, including Gothic, Baroque, Romanesque, Renaissance and Classicism.

Frenchtown (also known as the French Concession) is a district of Shanghai once designated as a settlement for French traders and businesspeople, and formerly overseen by the French government. Today it is a blend of east and west, an enclave of trendy cafés, shops, and European-style architecture frequented by tourists and urbanites alike.

Nanjing Lu, China’s premier shopping street, stretches from the Bund to the People’s Park in downtown Shanghai. The city’s first commercial road, it is now known as the “Oriental Paris.” Whether you’re into high-end fashion or just looking for the best bargain, you’ll find it here!

Yuyuan Garden (also known as Yu Gardens) is a classical Chinese garden was first established in 1559. The focal point is the Five-Dragon Wall, a monument to the magical creature so prevalent in Chinese legend. The wall divides the garden into six sections: the Grand Rockery, Ten-Thousand-Flower Pavilion, Hall of Heralding Spring, Hall of Jade Magnificence, Inner Garden, and Lotus Pool. The gardens are the place to go for a stroll, or just take a break from the bustling pace of the city.

The Jade Buddha Temple is a Buddhist temple that was founded in 1882 with two jade Buddha statues imported to Shanghai from Burma by sea. These were a sitting Buddha and a smaller reclining Buddha representing Buddha's death. The temple now also contains a much larger reclining Buddha made of marble, donated from Singapore, and visitors may mistake this larger sculpture for the original, smaller piece.

Hong Kong

Cultural Excursions included in the Program:

Take a peek at Victoria Peak, one of Hong Kong’s most popular attractions. Travel over 1200 feet to the summit on the Peak Tram, which pulls visitors via a steel cable up an incline of nearly 45 degrees. Once at the top of The Peak, enjoy amazing panoramic views of Hong Kong Harbour, Kowloon and the towering city skyline.

Aberdeen Fishing Village is one of Hong Kong’s oldest and widely-visited sites. Share the experience of “the boat people” who live on the hundreds of fishing junks docked in Aberdeen Harbour. Visitors can tour the fishing village via sampan, a flat-bottomed, Chinese wooden boat. The contrast of the lives of the boat people against the backdrop of Aberdeen’s modern skyline provides a striking contrast of traditional and modern life in Hong Kong.

Repulse Bay’s unique moniker comes from a 19th century battle during which the British army “repulsed” a pirate attack. In the early 20th century, the area was developed into a crescent-shaped beach. Today, it is a scenic residential area, featuring some of the most expensive real estate in Hong Kong.

Situated between Hong Kong Island and the Kowloon Peninsula, Hong Kong Harbour (also known as Victoria Harbour) hosts thousands of sailing vessels every year. It is a popular gathering site for tourists and locals due to its central urban location.

Nathan Road is the oldest road in Kowloon, the first section of which was completed in 1861. Lined with shops and restaurants, it is one of the busiest commercial thoroughfares in Hong Kong. Each evening, Nathan Road comes alive in a colorful array of glowing neon lights.

Cultural Excursions for Independent Exploration during free time:

Kowloon Peninsula is attached to mainland China across the harbor from Hong Kong Island. Kowloon is the site of many cultural gems, including Nathan Road and myriad exotic markets.

The Hong Kong Flower Market features stalls selling a plethora of fragrant blooms. Located on Flower Market Road in Kowloon, it features flowers of all varieties in every color of the rainbow—a truly beautiful sight!

If exotic birds are more your fancy, Kowloon Bird Market is the place to be! Stroll amongst hundreds of cages displaying songbirds of all varieties. Take in the sights and sounds of this aviary wonderland, where locals will often bring their own pet birds to sing with one another.

In China, jade has often been associated with long life and good health. The Jade Market is a gathering of hundreds of stalls selling jade ornaments, pendants, bracelets, rings and other treasures.

The Ngong Ping 360 is a gondola connecting Ting Ghung, on the north coast of Lantau with the Ngong Ping area in the hills above. The peak is home to the Po Lin Monastery and the Tian Tan Giant Buddha. The 25 minute ride gives panoramic views over the North Lantau Country Park, the South China Sea and Hong Kong International Airport.

Travel Dates

Program Start/Arrival Date: Tuesday, May 27, 2014
 Arrival City: Beijing (Airport code: PEK)

Departure Date: Monday, June 9, 2014
  Departure City: Hong Kong (Airport Code: HKG)
story_txt:
I am a Junior at the University of
Hawaii Maui College and have been nominated to represent the United States, my university
and my community as a member of the International Scholar Laureate Program (ISLP)
Delegation on May 27, 2014 through June 9, 2014 in China.
ISLP nominates exceptional college
and university students from around the country to this experiential
educational program. I have enclosed a sample of our itinerary for your review.
As you can see, this will be a powerful experience, enabling me to interact
with many prominent men and women in engineering and technology.
Attending this program will
challenge me to develop my leadership skills and reach my career goals of
becoming an engineer with a focus on energy management and efficiency. I am
focusing on my liberal arts degree right now and plan to graduate in 2015 with
goals to continue on to electrical engineering at University of Hawaii Manoa campus. I maintain a 3.91 GPA,
am involved in training other students in energy auditing and was recently
awarded certifications in Energy Management and Production, Home Energy Surveying
and Commercial Energy Auditing.
Imagine if you had been given this
opportunity for a life changing experience when you were in college and were
unable to participate for lack of funds. The program cost including tuition and
travel will exceed $8,000. I am investing every dollar I can of my own money to
make sure I don’t miss out on this once‐in‐a‐lifetime experience.  I currently work full time at Mana Foods as a
produce clerk, part time for Green Building Hawaii as an energy consultant and
go to school part time in order to support my education and live here in Maui. If you want to know what your money will be contributing to I have attached a copy of all the activities I will be able to be a part of due to your financial support.  If you don't want to contribute through my Indiegogo site you can join me at Flatbread Paia on April 22nd, Earth day, for a fund raiser and silent auction.  

International
Scholar Laureate Program Delegation Itinerary to China

The International Scholar Laureate Program (ISLP) Delegation on Engineering
& Technology in China will provide you with access to the people, places
and perspectives at the core of the engineering powerhouse that is today’s
China. 
Through special access to engineering marvels, lectures by top engineers and
government officials, exciting activities, group discussions and immersion in
the sights, sounds, people and places that make up this exotic land, you will
return with not only a new perspective on China, but also on the future of
engineering and the role you want to play in it.
Beijing
Cultural
Excursions included in the Program:
Tian’anmen
Square is the political heart of modern China. At 100 acres, it is
the largest public square in the world. Known as the site of massive student
protests, it is the entry point to the Forbidden City. The square features
famous monuments including the Gate of Heavenly Peace and the mausoleum of
former Chinese ruler Mao Zedong.
China’s
former imperial palace, the Forbidden City, has been home to a long line
of emperors, from Yongle in 1420 through Puyi in 1924. The political center of
Chinese government for five centuries, it now houses the Palace Museum,
which contains the largest collection of imperial artwork and artifacts in the
country.
The
Great Wall of China is the world's longest human-made
structure, stretching across approximately 4,500 miles. It is a series of stone
and earthen fortifications constructed and maintained between the 5th century
BC and the 16th century AD. Originally built to keep nomads out of China, it is
today considered a symbol of Chinese unity and is one of the world’s most
recognizable landmarks. The Great Wall was named a UNESCO World Heritage site
in 1987.
Each
week, Chinese students congregate at the English Corner on the campus of
Renmin University to practice their English-speaking skills. A unique
opportunity to meet and interact with Chinese citizens, English Corner welcomes
native English speakers to converse with the students on a variety of topics,
from politics to pop culture.
The
Olympic Green was developed for the 2008 Summer
Olympics in Beijing. These unique new Beijing landmarks include the Laoshan
Velodrome, the National Aquatics Center (“Water Cube”) and the National Stadium
(“Bird’s Nest”), where the grandeur of the opening and closing ceremonies
dazzled the world.
Cultural
Excursions for Independent Exploration during free time (if desired, local
guides will be available to facilitate individual purchase for admission):
The
Temple of Heaven was built in 1420 for emperors to worship Heaven and is
China’s largest complex of ancient sacrificial buildings. The main buildings include
the Altar of Prayer for Good Harvests, the Imperial Mound of Heaven and the
Circular Mound Altar. The temple was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site in
1998.
The
Summer Palace for Chinese royalty was built 800
years ago and is said to be the largest imperial garden in the world. It first
opened to the public in 1911, so that visitors could enjoy the natural beauty
of the landscape mingled with the stunning architecture at this ancient royal
retreat.
Beijing
Zoo is the largest zoo in China. Called Wanshengyuan (Ten
Thousand Animal Garden) during the Qing Dynasty, it was officially renamed in
1955. Beijing Zoo currently houses over 7,000 different animals, comprising
more than 600 species. Highlights for visitors are the animals native to China,
including the Golden Monkey and, of course, the Giant Panda, known the world
over as a Chinese national symbol.
Yichang
Cultural
Excursions included in the Program:
The

story:
Short Summary

   My name is Jocelyn Hunter, and I need help. I was born and raised in Florida, and am thirty nine years old. I am married and have two small boys, one in second grade, and one in Kindergarten. I have recently gone back to school to finish my Bachelor's Degree in Political Science in an effort to secure a better future for my children. We've had a fairly tough road, like a lot of other people, living paycheck to paycheck, and sometimes not even that.  My financial aid covers tuition, books, and gas, which is a lot since I live an hour's drive from campus and public transportation in not available in this area. My husband and I are both working, but we are barely making ends meet.

   We are managing, but the timing belt in my car is on the brink of disaster. I've looked into changing it myself, bit it simply isn't possible, and if it breaks, it will take out half the cylinders in my engine, causing the need for a much more expensive repair that I simply cannot afford. Unfortunately, I can't afford to replace it, either, which is why I need help. Without my car, I won't be able to get to school, and I will have taken out student loans for nothing, and put my kids' futures at risk. It seems absurd, but so much is riding on a strip of rubber.  A belt, a belt; my kingdom for a belt!

What We Need & What You Get

  I really only need about four hundred dollars, but the minimum I can ask for is five hundred. Obviously, most of that is going to replace the timing belt so that I can continue to drive to and from the University. Anything over that, I can save for future car repairs, or put it toward our living expenses (since we are also behind on rent), or put it toward the mountain of debt that I currently reside under.

   I don't know what I can offer contributors other than my undying appreciation for their help. I can offer hand drawn 'Thank You' cards from my from my boys, and I can keep you all posted on my progress in school, if you are interested (my GPA this first semester was 3.5, so I'm not slacking!) 

   If I don't reach the entire amount, I'll put what I do get away until I have saved enough for the belt replacement, and hope that it doesn't break in the meantime.

The Impact

   If you help me, you can have the satisfaction of knowing that you helped a family do better. I believe in paying it forward, and I always help other people when I can. Minoring in Applied Ethics, I hope to bring a more assertive conscience to the dealings of my local government, as well as make a living that can provide for the needs of my family. Who knows what the future could hold? You never know what a person can do with a little help. I do know that I won't be able to continue with school without it.

Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute directly, you can help by sharing this with people who can. Little things make a big difference, a bucket can be filled drop by drop.
I cannot thank you enough.
