story:
from this to

and then to this

 

One day creating communities like these

 

What Kind Of world do we want to leave for our children?

What kind of world do we want to live in? 

Is there a way of even creating this world?

Join me in my Journey to try and create a better world not just for ourselves but for future generations!

Hello, my name is Miguel Sa and I am asking you for donations to my education because I have faith. I have faith in myself at bringing about a positive change in the world on many levels through the intentions of my actions, and the idea's I choose to engage with. I am passionate about making a difference in people's lives, whether it is as small as saying thank you or as grand as giving them a essential skill, item, or idea that helps them on their journey through life. The kind of help you give is essential, as jesus once said, you give a man a fish, you  feed him for a day. you teach a man to fish you feed him for a life time. That is why I see sustainable housing, one that can take care of your basic necessities, while also making you conscious of where these are coming from, as essential. Without relying on bureaucratic institutions, knowing how to grow your own food and form your own communities, would give you a sense of freedom and personal empowerment few know in our society. Also it is even more important to be able to take care of your own basic necessities because in our highly interconnected society, any sort of crisis across the world can directly effect the system in our own country that so many of us rely on to live. 

A little about Me

I lived in toronto until I was four, then my parents divorced and I moved to Hamilton when my mother met my soon to become step father. There I lived the rest of my childhood until I decided I wanted to go to the University of Ottawa. My childhood was... interesting to say the least. I was the youngest of three brothers (one blood brother one step brother), and observed the struggles of bringing together two families. Needless to say Im thankful for every moment of my life, as without it I would not be where I am right now, and would not have learned so many valuable life lessons. Experiences are the greatest teachers we can have , teachers and books always come second, though they have played a major role in my growth. My Entire Family is Portuguese, and 98% of them live in Portugal, though the majority of my family on my step fathers side live here in Hamilton. 

My Decisions to go to the university of Ottawa was a easy one, its a beautiful city, I wanted to start fresh somewhere new, and the program I decided to go into , conflict studies and human rights, was exactly the kind of direction I wanted to take. Into my second semester I became somewhat disenfranchised with the university system, and the impractical and abstract ways of dealing with the idea of human rights and how someone "deserves" basic necessities. Though most of my grades were in the 80's, I had a feeling of incompleteness or longing for something else. Thats when I discovered earth ships through the documentary the Garbage warrior. It was like a revelation; a home built from mostly recycled materials, that collects rain water, produces electricity, grows food, regulates the temperature of the house using natural phenomenon. This technology puts the power of providing your own basic necessities into your own hands. As I was recently doing plenty of research about the water crisis, the food crisis, in a sense the vulnerability of the entire structure that western society lives off of made earth ships like a God send. So I then realized I was not going to finish University, I attended one more semester of school and officially left Ottawa in january 2013. 

Right after I did a little bit of volunteering and then started working in my fathers company 50+ hours a week to help provide for the money I will be needing to go across America to New Mexico and then off to Missouri for the two courses I will be taking. 

About the courses; 

 The first course is going to be at the Earth ship community just outside of Taos New Mexico where I will be learning the philosophy of earth ships while also receiving hands on training in building earth ships from scratch. It last six weeks from late april until early june. From here I will then go do some volunteer farming in colorado to cut down the cost of the trip, learning more about farming, and to bring me closer to my second destination. 

The second course is an Eco-village course in Rutledge, Missouri where I will be living in an intentional community who has its own local currency, produces most of its own food using permaculture, and builds natural homes out of straw and clay, and insulating with newspaper. The Village is called Dancing rabbit and I will be living there for 37 days from july 5 to august 11. If you want more info on either of the curriculums don’t be afraid to ask, I will give you a full itinerary of what every day would look like and major concepts covered in each course. 

THE TOTAL COST

Earth ship course 2000$US

Eco-village course 2400$US (now only 1900$ because I got a scholarship! thank you ecovillage education!) 

Total transportation (estimation) 750-1000$US (taking buses and trains ....my mom would kill me if I hitchhiked...literally)

Its funny because I feel selfish and unworthy to ask strangers or even family and friends for money. Even though walking down the street if a person asks me for change I never second guess giving them any change I do have. The difference here is I can share with you what I learn and even give my own creativity or inspirations to others in return for any donation. Despite my savings from working , and receiving some support from my family, I will be short on my financial needs to go on this great learning experience.

That is why I am asking you to make a difference, a donation small or big, will make a difference so please give what you can. Any of your contributions will be much appreciated, as Ive never done anything like this before, and even a small donation will make me extremely grateful. If you want to donate to a specific thing please  let me know. Most or all of the contributions without specific requests as to where they wish to be allocated, will be aimed at the second course for that needs to be payed by June 1st, and I will already be attending the earth ship course by the time this campaign ends . Also the funds will help cover the fees from indiegogo.

Your contribution will not only allow me to share what I learn/have learned with a wider audience via the great perks I offer for each donation level, but will also help me stay out of credit card debt! I did apply for a personal bank loan but was rejected because of my lack of resources. 

What You can do

1) make a donation of whatever is fitting with your income

2) share this campaign on twitter, facebook, or other social media outlets. 

Even if you don’t decide to contribute because one, you cant or two, you don’t see that I really am needing of your hard earned dollars. I hope you take a positive message, and some useful knowledge from this campaign, and use it to not only change your life but to help someone else become more sustainable in how they live. If you cant contribute but still wish to help, spread the message using any social media outlets you have at your disposal. The more people see this the more likely I will reach my goal. I thank you for your time in reading my message and even considering helping me on my journey. 

If you want to contact me about something, whether its to get to know me better before you contribute, or whatever it is you can find me here

https://www.facebook.com/miguelsa1799

With my whole heart I wish you all have a wonderful day and your live's be filled with joy.

story:
Hello Everybody!

 

My name is Lexus Loa and I am 12 year old only child with an amazing mother. She has been raising me on her own. My father is in prison for taking someones life. My mom always tells me to "stay young and have fun, be a kid". Also to not only chase my dreams, but catch them as well. In the distant future my goal is to someday get a scholarship to sing at Juilliard Arts. I know that if I put in the effort I can achieve this eventually. Currently though an opportunity of a lifetime has come up. My class will be getting the chance to fly to D.C. and then go to New York. Everyone is invited but not everyone will go. You see this trip is very expensive. My mom said that no matter what I will go and she means what she says. But since she has always done so much for me my whole life I want her to get the chance to come with me. Altogether for both of us to go it will cost over $8000. It includes the flight, hotel, and food. All for 7 amazing days. So if there is anyone out there that can help me reach my goal. I just want to thank you from the bottom of my heart. For those who may not be able to help with my dream financially I still want to thank you for taking the time to read my story it really means alot to me. One thing you could do is spread the word around and tell your friends about me. Once again thank you so much.                 

 

Thank You and God Bless!!! ♥♥♥ :)

story:
Swimming to Costa Rica:  The Roblealto Home for Children

Dear World Contributors:  

I want to thank you for visiting my page and helping me go on a Mission Trip to Costa Rica for the Robleato Child Care Association, in San Jose, Costa Rica.  http://www.roblealto.org 

Nine of us from New Colony Baptist Church, in Billerica, Massachusetts is gonig on this trip.  http://newcolony.org/   This will be my 2nd Mission Trip in 3 years.  In 2010, my first Mission trip was to Kenya, helping two doctors from our church.

My goal is to raise $2000.00 which includes airfare and staying at Robleato -- and greatly needed is supplies for the children. 

Here are the supplies and items needed to bring over to the Robleato Child Care Association in Costa Rica:

^Individual Bed Sheets and Bed Spreads

^Towels ^Tee-Shirts and Shorts

^Underwear Packs and Cotten Sock Packets

^Back Packs and School Supplies (of all sorts)

^Tennis Shoes (sizes 5-10) an Sandals (sizes 5-10).

I will also be spending quality time with the children in the guest-home, doing outside children activities and construction projects.

THIS IS NOT A VACATION FOR ME!

I WILL BE WORKING HARD FOR YOU

Afterall, you are donating your hard earned money for me to go!

Thank you very much and I hope your day is a blessed one!

Warmly,

Richard.

 ====

Please check out the PERKS BELOW...

====

The Video is actually my Son's idea to help raise money for me.  I hope you enjoy the video.  Please see the bloopers or out-takes after the video.  :)

====

Swimming to Costa Rica: The Perks:

1.  A picture and signing DVD from Nathan, the director of Swimming to Costa Rica

2.  A $10.00 coffee gift card from Donkin Donuts are Starbucks

3.  An Ipad Mini (Silver of Black)

4.  A journal and picture diary emailed to you!

====

I know that all can not donate but other ways you can help is:

^Be praying for our team as we go to Costa Rica on August 9th-August 18th, 2013.

^Ask your family and friends to View my page and perhaps donate or the very least pray for a safe trip.

Thank you!

story:
Peace and Blessings,

My name is Susan Diane Mitchell, and I am asking for angel donations, gifts and support to help me achieve a goal on my sacred path, a path of destiny that is much bigger than just myself.  I have consecrated my life work to be in sacred service to the Divine Afrikan Feminine, the divinity within Black women and people of Afrikan descent throughout the planet.  The goal I am reaching for, and for which I am asking for your help, is to raise the funds that will allow me to travel to a very important Transformative Studies Intensive Retreat as the very first part in a program of doctoral study to which I have been accepted. 

I applied to, was accepted, and offered a scholarship for two years to assist me in pursuing a PhD in Transformative Studies from the California Institute of Integral Studies (CIIS) in San Francisco, CA, for the 2013-14 academic year.  However, the scholarship assistance I am receiving does not cover travel expenses.  I am asking for financial help to cover airfare for myself and my caregiver/partner to assist me during the travel and the retreat, as my health necessitates such assistance.

 

Here is a link for Chiari Malformation Type I

http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/chiari-malformation/DS00839/DSECTION=symptoms

and

Multiple Sclerosis

http://www.webmd.com/multiple-sclerosis/guide/multiple-sclerosis-diagnosis

Both of which she is diagnosed with. We are now looking at the possibility of Fibromyalgia.

 

I am so honored by this opportunity, and I would like to explain why this is so important, beyond myself, and why your contribution is sowing seed in good, fertile soil.

 

My Credentials,

I was born in Washington, D.C. in 1967 to young, beautiful, intelligent parents who were students at Howard University. After my parents divorced, I was raised for the majority of my childhood in Oakland, CA, visiting my father in his home of Anniston, AL every summer.  I am blessed to have the ancestral roots that I have, for both of my parents, and my grandparents before them, blessed me with a richness of life and a thirst for knowledge.  I have been supported by wonderful people who love me, and I have always been encouraged to study, write, teach, and excel in my studies.  I attended Spelman College from 1985 to 1988 on an Honors Scholarship, where I studied English and Spanish as a double major. 

I ultimately completed my undergraduate studies in English and Spanish at Jacksonville State University in Jacksonville, AL, graduating with Special Honors in English. I continued my studies while raising a family while attending the University of Alabama at Birmingham as a Graduate Assistant in the Department of English, where I earned an MA in English and American Literature. My studies at Spelman College in the literature of Black women continued at UAB, where I submitted a thesis that focused on the literature of Africana womanist writers, such as Toni Morrison, Maryse Conde, and Gloria Naylor.  I received a High Pass on this scholarship, and graduated with distinction.  In addition, I worked for many years as a college instructor at a community college, a distance learning school, a university, and a technical school, as well as a private and volunteer tutor and instructor for language classes.

          

Those are some of my accolades, and I speak of these  accomplishments to demonstrate that I am highly capable of successfully completing this doctoral program.

 

Scholarship

I want to explain what I discovered during the research for my thesis,  what I have remembered about myself in the process, and why it is so important that I continue on my sacred path.  In applying an original theory of "spirit discourse," I was able to trace a sacred Afrikan feminine principle that underlay every conceivable hardship, oppression, abuse, disenfranchisement, and neglect that these amazing narratives portrayed in the experiences of the Afrikan woman characters depicted in the novels.  I identified this principle as an ancient, primordial, essential transformative and creative power that women possess in general but which I posit Afrikan women and women of Afrikan descent possess in particular because of their experience and because of the anciency of Afrikan spiritual practices that show up, even despite themselves, in the lives and stories of Afrikan women.  I became fascinated with the idea that soon grew into conviction that women--and Afrikan women in particular because of their most ancient connection to the Divine as the first humans on the planet--have within them innate, creative and transformative energy and power that, when cultivated and nurtured rather than debased and destroyed, can significantly impact the healing process that is so desperately needed for the planet and all of her peoples. 

 

CIIS is an integral part of a "mecca" in the Bay Area of worldwide sacred feminine scholarship, and my presence, voice, participation and leadership in this arena is crucial to placing the Afrikan woman in the center of the Great Work that is being done to transform the earth into a place that blesses and sustains everyone and every beneficial lifeform.

 

I am the mother of four beautiful daughters and five beautiful sons.  I am living with a host of neurological symptoms of diagnosed Multiple Sclerosis and Chiari 1 malformation, and suspected fibromyalgia, which include chronic pain and fatigue.  Pursuing this life goal of earning a doctorate in the "field of my dreams," in the writing, research, teaching and visioning of the sacred Afrikan feminine is so healing for me and healing for others. 

The despair I feel sometimes in coping with the pain and fatigue, and the limitations that accompany them is chased away by my excitement of this opportunity. I have much to live for and much to look forward to, and I feel great excitement and gratitude to be able to continue my sacred path in the service of teaching and writing about the Divine Afrikan Feminine, and the anciency of the Black Goddess.  Please help me get to California so that I can continue this most auspicious sacred work.

 

Thank you so much.

story:
My sister Carolyn Hoener Gondran was diagnosed with ALS two years ago. ALS also known as Lou Gehrig’s Disease is a devastating disease that has a two – four year 90% mortality rate.

There is no treatment and no cure.

Carolyn graduated Northampton High School and in 1978, B.A in Chemistry and Physics from Smith College 1982 and went on to receive her Ph. D. in Physical Chemistry from the University of California at Berkeley in 1988.

In honor of Carolyn’s interest and commitment to the sciences I have set up a scholarship in her name to be given to a female Northampton High Schools who has a special interest in and creative approach to the sciences.

Funding the sciences will only bring us closer to a cure. Hope is around the corner!

Thank you,

 

Donna

story:
!!UPDATE!! Although the campaign has ended, donations are still very welcome! If you want to contribute, please transfer any donation to bank account 8865543, M Hopman, Amsterdam. If you send an email to marieke.eba@gmail.com I will grant you access to the weblog.

 

 

ABOUT THE PROJECT

1. The problem
In spite of international law that prohibits the use of child soldiers, an estimated 300.000 children are currently active as soldiers. In the context of the international community and international humanitarian work, there is a general consensus on the use of child soldiers, namely that it should be banned as soon as possible. But even though international legislation provides for this wish, in practice it seems that legal instruments are only partly effective.

One of the reasons why the use of children in war has not stopped yet is the fact that international law on the subject is ambiguous to say the least. Confusion starts from the question what the definition of the child is. Also, these laws are imposed upon groups that never had to do with their creation in the first place, since only governments have been involved in the creation of international laws.

For example Denov, who is a specialist on the subject of child soldiers, argues that defining childhood based on age reflects a bias towards Western notions of childhood. She writes:

"The United Nations (UN) Convention on the Rights of the Child defines a child as ‘every human being below eighteen years’ (article 1). However, ‘childhood’ is indeed a contested concept and a social construction that varies in form and content across cultures and social groups, and is defined by localized understandings and values. Defining childhood based solely upon age not only reflects a bias towards western notions of childhood which are rooted in biomedical theory (Kemper 2005), but also may overlook other salient cultural social, economic, gendered, class and other status determinants that extend well beyond the notion of age (2010: 2)."

 

2. The research question
Central to the question and practice of child soldiers is the question of the child. What is “a child”? What does “childhood” mean? Is the concept of childhood a cultural and temporal bound concept, or is it a universal, timeless fact (as international law seems to claim)? And what does it have to do with age? How are children different from adults and where do we draw a line, if there even is one?

Only when these questions are answered, one can start to look at the more normative questions underlying the question of child soldiers, being amongst others, why is it wrong to use child soldiers? Why is it wrong for children to be involved in armed conflicts? Why should this norm be embedded in international law?

In my research I intend to look into the question of the concept of childhood. The central question to my research will be: “what is the meaning of the concept of childhood, in the context of the use of child soldiers?”. I will link this question to the practice of the use of child soldiers in Africa, specifically Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

 

3. Methodology
For this purpose I will engage in both 

  1. A philosophical and historical investigation into the concept of childhood (theoretical part)
  2. An investigation into the concept of childhood in the context of the use of child soldiers  (field research)

For the second part I will conduct 70 interviews with different groups of people from Rwanda, Congo, the Netherlands and Belgium - people who are involved in the practice of child soldiers or have been involved, policy makers on children's rights, humanitarian workers and "ordinary local people". I will ask all of these groups aboutt their perspective on the question "what is a child". 

 

4. Expected Results

I expect to find different answers to the question “what is the meaning of the concept of childhood?”. Departing from a philosophical and historical perspective, explaining how the idea of childhood originated, how the concept of childhood can be understood as part of a language game and how the idea of childhood is part of constructed social reality, I assume this perspective will create a frame in which to explain and understand the empirical data found in the interviews, including their expected variety. I expect that different people from different groups of interest will give different answers to questions concerning the concept of childhood. Ultimately I expect to come to a general conclusion regarding the concept of childhood understood in the frame of a philosophical perspective. I think the philosophical perspective will help to explain the different content of answers and to combine the answers to a unified answer to the research question.

Also, I expect to come up with recommendations for further research on the subject of the concept of the child, international humanitarian law and the use of child soldiers. The research will also provide input for policy-making and research on current policies.

 

5. Who am I
My name is Marieke Hopman, I am 24 years old. I live in Amsterdam, which is where I'm studying for my masters in philosophy. The current research is my own initiative. It will serve as my master thesis and also for my master after master's thesis at Gent University (Belgium). This is my personal project for the next two years. The only reason I started it is because I realized I wanted to do something usefull with my time, education and brain. I am truly hoping this is how I can contribute to a better world.

 

6. What I Need & What You Get

The budget necessary to finish the project is €10,000,- (USD 13,108). The whole of this budget will be spent on costs for research, mainly costs for field research. My contribution are my hours (approximately 1800 hours over two years).

Any contribution is very welcome. If I turn out not to meet the total budget I might consider chipping in myself or cutting budget (probably both). But the budget is already pretty tight as it is.

What you get: anyone who is willing to contribute even a little of course gets a big THANK YOU. All your names will be mentioned in the planned resulting report. Also, you will get access to a weblog on which I will keep everyone up to date on the progress of the research, my experiences in field research, etc.

 

7. Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this page with anyone interested!!! 
And if you have any comments, ideas, thoughts, etc...I'd be happy to here about them. Please get in touch: marieke.eba@gmail.com.

 -----------------------------------------------------------------------

I would like to share this project, that is doing great work for children in Africa: http://igg.me/p/392172/x/3174624

No more child rape and infanticide

Please help us to buy land urgently needed in Pietermaritzburg, Kwa Zulu Natal so SAFE HOMES can be built for abandoned babies and children.

 

They need your help. Please have a look!

story:
About Us

The Born To Be Free Foundation is a Ghanaian based Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) established in 2011 by a private entrepreneur Mohamed Issa who has an undying passion for humanity and a special interest in football.  His objection to juvenile exploitation drives his vision to provide underprivileged children with all the required resources to see them realize their maximum potential using the powerful tool of football.

Having been born and raised in football crazy Ghana, Mohammed was more than convinced, that football would be the best tool with which to capture the interest and imagination of the children he craved to assist with education and the honing of their soccer skills and so with twenty kids aged 9-13 from Labadi-a suburb of Accra-a soccer pitch, and two Soccer Coaches, a Foundation was born.

The Foundation then took a life of its own and soon twenty kids became fifty.

Fifty kids whose only future was confined to the streets, who were often left to fend for themselves whilst their parents wrestled with the clingy fingers of poverty, who didn’t even dare to dream because that was not an option.

Moving on from nurturing soccer skills, emphasis was heavily placed on ensuring that the kids got quality education. A private school known for academic excellence and discipline was identified.

Vision Seed Academy Primary and Junior High School located in Labadi jumped at the opportunity to partner a noble project, admitted all 50 boys. Whilst the school dedicated their resources in providing quality education, the BTBF backed their effort with paying the kids’ school fees, providing books, uniforms and transport on top of soccer equipment, medical insurance and a hot meal a day.

In addition to this, the Founder, a trained self-development teacher designed and begun implementing a special course targeted at teenagers. The idea is to provide mentorship and inspiration whilst tapping on real life stories.

In this vein, Kuuku Yankah-a young man of similar background and circumstances-was recruited to run the foundation on a daily basis. Chief amongst his tasks is to mentor the kids and become a father figure to them.

After just three years, the Foundation has successfully pulled some of these kids through Junior High School to Senior High School. One of them now plays for Ghana’s National U-17 team and this is just the beginning


Vision& Value

Vision

Help under privileged children attain their ultimate potential in a safe and secured environment.

Mission

To empower the Ghanaian child with skill, knowledge, confidence, the ability and determination to be self sufficient and ready to face or meet Global challenges.

Values & Guiding Principles

BTBF upholds the principles and values of:

  • Equality amongst all participants
  • Respect, transparency and Integrity in all dealings
  • Self sufficiency and moral discipline

How you can help

Our goal is to raise US$5000 to set up a library where our boys can use the books for the school year and when they are done they bring it back so the next born to be free generation can benefit from them it will be the first step in creating something that will go a long way and benefit so many children. We appreciate every contribution you do to help us support these boys dreams


Visit us at: www.borntobefree.org

Thank you

special interest in football.  His objection to juvenile exploitation 
drives his vision to provide underprivileged children with all the 
required resources to see them realize their maximum potential using the
 powerful tool of football.

Having been born and raised in football crazy Ghana, Mohammed was 
more than convinced, that football would be the best tool with which to 
capture the interest and imagination of the children he craved to assist
 with education and the honing of their soccer skills and so with twenty
 kids aged 9-13 from Labadi-a suburb of Accra-a soccer pitch, and two 
Soccer Coaches, a Foundation was born.
The Foundation then took a life of its own and soon twenty kids became fifty. Fifty kids whose only future was confined to the streets, who were 
often left to fend for themselves whilst their parents wrestled with the
 clingy fingers of poverty, who didn’t even dare to dream because that 
was not an option.
Moving on from nurturing soccer skills, emphasis was heavily placed 
on ensuring that the kids got quality education. A private school known 
for academic excellence and discipline was identified.
Vision Seed Academy Primary and Junior High School located in Labadi 
jumped at the opportunity to partner a noble project, admitted all 50 
boys. Whilst the school dedicated their resources in providing quality 
education, the BTBF backed their effort with paying the
 kids’ school fees, providing books, uniforms and transport on top of 
soccer equipment, medical insurance and a hot meal a day.
In addition to this, the Founder, a trained self-development teacher 
designed and begun implementing a special course targeted at teenagers. 
The idea is to provide mentorship and inspiration whilst tapping on real
 life stories.
In this vein, Kuuku Yankah-a young man of similar background and 
circumstances-was recruited to run the foundation on a daily basis. 
Chief amongst his tasks is to mentor the kids and become a father figure
 to them.
After just three years, the Foundation has successfully pulled some 
of these kids through Junior High School to Senior High School. One of 
them now plays for Ghana’s National U-17 team and this is just the 
beginningVision& Value
Vision
Help under privileged children attain their ultimate potential in a safe and secured environment.
Mission
To empower the Ghanaian child with skill, knowledge, confidence, the 
ability and determination to be self sufficient and ready to face or 
meet Global challenges.
Values & Guiding Principles
BTBF upholds the principles and values of:

Equality amongst all participants
Respect, transparency and Integrity in all dealings
Self sufficiency and moral discipline
How you can help
Our goal is to raise US$5000 to set up a 
library where our boys can use the books for the school year and when 
they are done they bring it back so the next born to be free generation 
can benefit from them it 
will be the first step in creating something that will go a long way and
 benefit so many children. We appreciate every contribution you do to 
help us support these boys dreams

Visit us at: www.borntobefree.orgThank you

story:
“America is the land of opportunity…just for some more than others.” (Washington Post Oct. 18th, 2014)

At The Center for Arts Education we strive to level the playing field, and we need your support today.

In a world where neighborhood and family income are predictors of success, (NYTimes Feb 9th, 2012) we use the ARTS to help students who might not have any other path to a successful career.

Our Career Development Program helps students connect to the $21 billion creative arts industry through our Boot Camp and Internship program.

And with your help we can help students achieve their dreams.


Why This Matters Now

Funding has changed, and we need to raise a minimum of $12,500 to continue providing these kids with the skills and experiences they need to compete and succeed in the 21st Century workplace.

Our students come primarily from NYC's outer boroughs -- Queens, The Bronx and Brooklyn and a large majority of our students qualify for free lunch. 

Your donation pays for all Boot Camp expenses, Career Awareness Day, graduation, and students' arts experiences and provides a stipend and a metro card for each student.

The next class is scheduled to start in less than 2 months. We need your help to make sure these students have an experience that honors their talent and ambition.

                                 

The Career Development Program includes:

  • Three-Week Intensive Boot Camp: Students learn the essentials of the workplace from resume writing to networking, email etiquette to career roadmapping. Students graduate from Boot Camp with comprehensive jobs-skills and are prepared to begin their internships.
  • Arts Experiences: Students explore and experience the wide range of art and culture available in New York City - they will attend a Broadway show, visit museums and galleries, and participate in performing and visual arts workshops.  
  • Interviews: Students interview for internships at arts and creative businesses around New York City in a variety of fields including architecture, theater, music, design, advertising, the visual arts, and fashion.
  • Internships: Students are placed in  13-week internships at top NYC arts and arts-related businesses where dedicated mentors show them the ropes and teach them the business.  Frequently, internships turn into summer jobs and beyond.                 

Your Support Impacts the Future

You are funding inspiration and success. You are helping students with tremendous potential but limited resources to connect to a marketplace that needs creative gifted critical thinkers with new perspectives.

 Some kids have connections, these kids have us, 

and now they will have you!

For over 15 years, we have helped more than 600 students link their passion to college and professional possibilities.  While some have gone on to careers as professional artists, many others enjoy success in fields as diverse as retail, law, advertising, architecture, banking, marketing, non-profit management, and education.

Our student success rate is clear: 95% of our graduates go on to college. Our students have earned degrees from schools such as New York University, Queen's College, Columbia University, Fashion Institute (FIT), Pratt Institute, and Baruch College to name a few. Our alumni currently work at companies such as Rockwell Group, Midori and Friends, VICE Media, Morgan Stanley, Kramer Design Group, Bloomingdale's, Uniqlo, Microsoft and many more.

Your donation is a vote of confidence in these students.

                  THANK YOU

About CAE....

The Center for Arts Education (CAE) is committed to ensuring that every child in every New York City public school has equal access to a well-rounded education of which the arts are a central component.

We work to achieve this mission through school and community programs, professional development, parent engagement, and advocacy. 

If you would prefer to give through another method or are interested in partnering with CAE, please contact Lara at 212.239.7811.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Share this campaign by email, FB, Twitter or any social media you like best.  You can use Indiegogo's simple and convenient sharing tools.

story:
# 1 -  Program Description:

 Spirit of Hoops Youth Basketball Training Program

Guiding Principles:
  • Focuses on Native American youth on Reservations
  • Uses nationally proven, youth basketball training methods (developed by “One on One Basketball Inc.” who trains 35,000 youth annually)
  • Devotes personal attention to each child and is free to everyone that participates
  • Trains and uses local Indian Reservation coaches

Native American youth face many challenges as they grow into adults:

  • A suicide rate two and a half times the national average
  • Substance abuse, physical and emotional abuse 
  • High school dropout rates twice the national average 

Basketball is the most popular sport on every Native American Indian Reservation. Mountain Chief Institute, a non-profit corp., has developed the “Spirit of Hoops Tour 2015” basketball training camps for Native American boys and girls ages 6 to 17 including all skill levels.  Camps will be held at different Native American Reservations nationally.  Mountain Chief Institute uses basketball as a vehicle to impact a youth culture where Native children will grow up believing that they are valued, important to their community and have the attitudes, skills, and discipline to succeed in whatever they choose to pursue.   

Coaching and teaching at each camp 

  • Physical fitness warm up and exercises 
  • Basketball fundamentals and drills
  • Basketball scrimmages and games
  • Fun and encouraging for all skill levels
  • Emphasis on character development
  • Sportsmanship, teamwork and perseverance
  • Improve self esteem and confidence
  • A sense of importance and belonging

This experience is powerful and needs to begin at a young age.  Many of our Native Youth do not have this early learning opportunity or experience. “Spirit of Hoops” basketball training camp is an experience of youth discovering their hidden talents and abilities that are within all of them.

#2   - Program Budget 

Mountain Chief Institute has set a goal to raise $150,000 for the Spirit of Hoops Tour 2015. 

This tour in 2015 will: 

  • Provide 20 basketball training camps on 20 Reservations in four areas; Wisconsin/Minnesota, North & South Dakota, California and New Mexico/Arizona
  •  Average 100 participants per camp which last 1 to 3 days
  • Camps Run March through August 2015 

Spirit of Hoops will provide: 

  • Head coaches and quality instruction
  • Camp T-Shirts and prizes

Hosting reservations will provide: 

  • Basketball facility, lunches
  • Local coaches and volunteers

Our goal of $150,000 in funds will be used as follows: 

  • $27,500 per state area (4) totaling $110,000
  • Administration and sustainability expenses $25,000
  • Contingency reserves $15,000

If our fundraising goal is not fully reached, “Spirit of Hoops Tour 2015” will conduct camps on as many reservations as funds allow.

Giving of gifts is a Native American tradition of sharing.  For us to request a gift from you is a little outside of tradition.  However, The Spirit of Hoops Tour , we feel helps to fill a great need of our youth on reservations and we would like to encourage anyone with an interest to help us reach our fundraising goal.

#3  -  Program Impact

Many of you remember your own successes on or off the athletic field.  These accomplishments were experiences from grade school, high school, or maybe college.  Remember the time you hit your first double base hit in baseball, made a 3 point basketball shot and got it, or when you ran in a long race in track and you finished?  It is the same thing when you got your first “A” on a test,  or could print your own name and recite your home phone number from memory.  These events may seem small now,  but they had a tremendous impact on you at the time.

Now you have the opportunity to pass this magic moment of success on to Native American youth through the “Spirit of Hoops Tour 2015”.  Your experiences helped you as you grew up and now through your donation it can help these boys and girls.  

In 2014 Spirit of Hoops had a very successful pilot program 

  • Camps started in March and ended in July 2014
  • We conducted 8 basketball training camps on 5 Reservations; Oneida Tribe (WI), Pechanga Band (CA), Navajo Nation (NM), Pueblo Nations (NM), Rosebud Sioux Tribe (SD).
  • Trained a total of 660 boys and girls ages 6 to17 at all skill levels 
  • Began training local reservation coaches and volunteers
  • Received positive feedback from children, parents, and local coaches
  • Were invited back by all reservations for the 2015 Tour
We feel that returning to these reservations and others in the second year will: 
  • Improve basketball skills
  • Keep reservation boys and girls active and involved
  • Improve the ability to cope with challenges
  • Increase confidence and self esteem
  • Increase compassion for others
  • Replace hopelessness with hope 
  • Help prevent Native American children’s heartbreaking epidemic of suicide

    # 4 - Program Challenges

    Following are some of the risks and challenges we will face.

    The number of youth participating at each basketball camp has grown from an expected 40 to 60 youth to 100 to 150 participants.  How will this program become sustainable with added growth throughout the years?

    • Train local coaches to run basketball programs
    • Make paid part-time and full time positions available
    • Find funding support through tribal budgeted funds 
    • Find grants from corporations, foundations, and federal agencies
    • Add after school programs and leagues
    • Eventually sustained by a tribally run program or a local community youth organization

    How will management and fiscal responsibilities be handled?

    Our president, David Powless is highly qualified:

    • Started up and operated successful businesses over 30 years
    • Raised all funds for our pilot program
    • Believes that sports training can have a life-changing impact on youth
    • Is known in Indian Country as passionate and as a sports role model
    • Provided In-kind contributions of all services and made cash donations

    How will we handle the task of fund raising?

    • Indiegogo crowd funding will give us resources to continue our successes
    • Native professional grants writer on board as a volunteer. 
    • We submitted two requests for grants; one is funded, one is pending
    • Will continue applying for grants

    #5 -  Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can contribute to “Spirit of Hoops Tour 2015”,  thank you!  You have our deepest appreciation.  But, if at this time you cannot, please help us  by telling others about our purpose to use basketball to help Native American youth.  Use your social media channels or use Indiegogo share tools.  Here is our link to share: 

    Spirit Of Hoops Tour 2015


    Mountain Chief Institute President's Video


     I started the “Spirit of Hoops” Native Youth Basketball Training Program because I had the experience of changing and improving my life forever through the power of sports.  I want to bring this experience to our Native boys and girls.  

    My name is David Powless.   I am a member of the Oneida Tribe of Indians of Wisconsin.  I am also the President of Mountain Chief Institute.   On my high school football team, I was less than mediocre.  I had no confidence and no self esteem.  My senior year, I played as hard as I could until I felt good inside.  Everything for me changed.  I became a high school All-State tackle with 9 college football scholarship offers.  I played football on the U. of Illinois Rose Bowl Championship team and was drafted in the NFL to play professional football.          

    In my Oneida Tribe, we do a "Tobacco Burning Ceremony" where we place tobacco on hot embers and we  combine this with the “Good Words” when we speak to the Creator.  The “Good Words” are to give a “Thanksgiving”,  thanking the Creator for our “Original Instructions” that were given to us to lead our lives on earth and thanking the Creator for bringing all of Creation together in this moment.  It ends with “And now our minds are one”. 

    My father told me this:   Take something that you cherish or value the most, something  that you really like, something that is important to you,  something you really wonder if you could be without,  then ---- give it away.  He said that this is the greatest gift because it carries the greatest power from you to help or encourage another person.  And it comes back to you as an ability to improve all of the things that you need.

    “AND NOW OUR MINDS ARE ONE”

story:
Overview

Hello!  My name Mike and I am a teacher who would appreciate any money you can donate so I can get a much needed teaching tool in my classroom, as well as books for my classroom library.  Next year I will be switching schools to teach Fifth Grade at a public charter school in California.  My school does not have the resources to provide every classroom with the technology necessary to create a high-quality and engaging educational experience for students.  I'm looking to raise funds here in order to buy a digital document projector and classroom books, both of which will greatly improve the level of teaching and learning in my classroom.

The What, How and Why of it

The document projector, aka visual presenter, is what most of the funds I recieve would go towards.  If you're unfamiliar with what a document projector is, it's also known as an Elmo, after the company name, and it's a compact, digital device that can sit on a table or desk anywhere in the classroom and it will capture with it's camera a document or object.  When paired with a digital projector, the document or object the Elmo is capturing will then be projected onto the white board for the whole class to see.  In short, this decive takes the place of those old, clunky projectors that are scorching hot, noisy, and have to take up space in the middle of the classroom. In my view the Elmo is an essential device that's needed in order to really engage my students and show them visually what we are studying or working on.  

Here's some examples of how I'd use the Elmo.  If I am teaching about giving more detail in fiction writing, I could demonstrate an example of what I mean on a piece of paper that's under the Elmo camera, and it will then be shown on the whiteboard for students to follow along as I write and guide them through my thinking.  Other examples of what I'd be able to do with the Elmo are: Showing samples of student work, going over a passage of a book together, correcting a quiz, studying a photo of a famous piece of art, studying the roots of a plant (yes an Elmo projects any object put underneath it's camera!)...The possiblities are endless!  Another great feature is that I can hook my laptop up to the system and project websites, documents, images, and videos onto the whiteboard.  It's simply a fantastic tool.

The rest of the money I receive will be spent buying books to bolster my classroom library.  As of now, it doesn't look like our school will have a library next year, so we will be relying heavily on our class library, and we need more books, particularly non-fiction ones!

Wrap Up

In short, your money would be going toward a really good cause.  It would help enable me to create the most enriching and engaging educational experience I can for my students.  I can promise you that my students and I would be very grateful for these additions to our classroom!

 

The Specifics - Where's the Money Going?

I'm looking to raise $600.  If the fundraising is short, I'll collect whatever was raised and put it towards buying the Elmo and books.  If the fundraising exceeds $600 it will be well received and I'll put the extra money towards buying more books and any classroom supplies needed throughout the year.  Here's the breakdown:

  • Elmo MO-1 Visual Presenter -- ranges $350-$400

  • Books for Classroom Library - $150-200

  • Any extra funds will go towards materials and supplies for the classroom!

 

Be sure to check out the perks you can choose to recieve if you donate certain amounts.  

And if you can't donate anything, it's all good, you can still help out by sending this along to anyone you think might be interested.

Thanks for your consideration and anything you're able to give!

Much love,

Mike

In short, your money would be going toward a really good cause.  It would help enable me to create the most enriching and engaging educational experience I can for my students.  I can promise you that my students and I would be very grateful for these additions to our classroom!
 
The Specifics - Where's the Money Going?
I'm looking to raise $600.  If the fundraising is short, I'll collect whatever was raised and put it towards buying the Elmo and books.  If the fundraising exceeds $600 it will be well received and I'll put the extra money towards buying more books and any classroom supplies needed throughout the year.  Here's the breakdown:


Elmo MO-1 Visual Presenter -- ranges $350-$400


Books for Classroom Library - $150-200


Any extra funds will go towards materials and supplies for the classroom!


 


Be sure to check out the perks you can choose to recieve if you donate certain amounts.  
And if you can't donate anything, it's all good, you can still help out by sending this along to anyone you think might be interested.
Thanks for your consideration and anything you're able to give!
Much love,
Mike

story:
ADEL’S STORY

I gave birth to Adelaide Shekwoshimi Hideyoshi Ogidion May 30 2007.  I was 46 years old, eleven years older than his father and Adelaide(Adel for short) is our Only child.  He was diagnosed with two holes in the heart (a PDA and VSD) when he was 5 months old.  His life was ebbing away as his heart grew weaker, larger, occupying virtually all his chest, with more than 50% shunt of the blood pumped from his heart into his lungs.  He was weak and blue when I took him to Hudrulaya Narayana (a Heart Hospital) in Bangalore where he had a surgery with support from feminists and friends like Meena Seshu, Pramada Menon, Bene Madunagu, and the humanitarian desk of the hospital.  This is where Adel was diagnosed with the Down Syndrome.

 

He recovered gradually from the impact of the heart condition

 

He took a little longer in his case to sit without support, crawl, stand and took his first steps when he was 26 months old.

 

At this point, I had started bombarding him with Sesame Street, Barney and Vegetale videos.  He took interest in them was learned over the next two years to say his alphabets, sing along and dance.

 

In all the sessions we had, with his paediatricians and the endocrinologist, they were convinced that he could cope in a regular school because he displayed high level of intelligence.  The Endocrinologist in fact concluded that he must have the mosaic pattern of down syndrome since other children his age could not do certain tasks that Adel was capable of.

At four I enrolled him in a kindergarten class of a faith based institution.  I moved him from there to a private Primary School believing that they had a standard that will enable Adel progress well in his education.

 

Till this point, I had had to fight discrimination and stigma including from family members (his father and his relatives) who saw Adel as an abnormal and handicapped child.  The traditional way of receiving a child born into a family was not performed for Adel.  All through the hospitalisation and surgery, his father’s relations did not visit him in the hospital.  A huge statement of rejection given what should ordinarily have been the case in a cultural setting where extended families are closely knit.

 

At three, Adel could call elevators, select the floors, he could identify our hotel rooms, he could tell his way around town, as wrong turns would draw a cry.  From the age of two, he could operate the DVD player, select channels from the TV, operate the mobile phone in and out of various folders, identify all the letters of the alphabet and numbers in whatever order they are presented, including mirror image.

 

In November 2011, his father left us discontinuing his financial support. One of the reasons he gave was that since I was treating cancer (I have been on treatment for CA breast since December 2010 when I had RMM) and was not in a position to give birth to more children, and the only son I gave him was not normal, he needed to go find some other woman who will have more children for him.  It was an additional pain when in September 2012 the  School wrote me a letter advising me to withdraw my son from their school.  This was shocking because he had passed his examinations.  Convinced that his expulsion from school was a discrimination based on his birth condition, I sued the school and presented evidence of his continually improving performance.  The Judge ruled on 14th February 2013 that the school had acted “in the best interest of the child”.  To pursue appeal on the case, is further depletion of resources needed for his education especially since financial support from his father was no longer forth coming.

 

With the little resources I had left I approached other much cheaper schools to get him back to school, but the efforts have failed.  He is constantly rejected and I am told to take him to the school of the “deaf and dump”, only school for people with hearing and speech impairment. 

The options I have exist only outside Minna, the town where I live and work. Please I need your financial support to take him to Abuja or Lagos to offer him the education he so desperately needs and record a success story that debunks myths, stereotypes and taboos.

I thank you, Adel thanks you For taking the time to read our story and for your anticipated support

story:
Traditional Chinese Culture Center

(中文在下面）

Why a Traditional Chinese Culture Center?

After spending most of my adult life in China, in 2006 I moved back to North Carolina. I became a visiting scholar at Duke University where I'd studied in the 1980s. I was astonished to find that there's now as much Mandarin as English spoken on the campus. Chinese are by far the largest group of international students at Duke. When I attended there were only a couple of Chinese graduate students and no undergraduates. Now the number of both is in the thousands, well more than half of the international student body. With China's economy continuing to grow rapidly there is increasing international interest in China. The number of young Westerners studying Chinese language, history and culture is skyrocketing. We host a Chinese Roundtable once a week at Duke and dozens of Chinese and American students gather to speak Mandarin and share their mutual interest in Chinese culture. I host regular homemade Chinese dumpling parties at my house and the attendance always numbers in the dozens. My house is already an informal Chinese culture center. Now I'm formalizing it. It's clear that the time is ripe for a traditional Chinese culture center in Durham. 

 

What will we offer? 

The center will offer classes in:

  • Mandarin language 
  • Calligraphy and Painting
  • Martial Arts
  • Yoga
  • Meditation
  • Traditional Chinese Medicine, Acupressure Massage and Bodywork

Other activities include:

  • Vintage Chinese tea ceremonies
  • Traditional meals from our on-site organic garden
  • Chinese music performances
  • Chinese film screenings
  • Homemade Chinese dumpling parties

 

My History

Water & Tea 水/火

After two decades in China, I moved back to the Bay Area and met a teacher of traditional Chinese culture more knowledgeable than any I'd found in China. Wang Mingyi and I had known each other in Beijing prior to the events of 1989. I was a foreign correspondent for UPI and he was a translator for the Baltimore Sun. After the tragedy in Tiananmen Square in June 1989 people were scattered to the winds. Mingyi returned to his village in southwestern Yunnan Province—bordering the Golden Triangle of Burma, Vietnam and Thailand—and apprenticed with a doctor of traditional Chinese medicine. He began practicing the healing arts, met and married an American woman, had three children and moved to San Francisco. It was there that I met him again after more than a decade. He looked the picture of health—younger than when I had last seen him more than ten years before. I said to him: "Whatever you're doing to stay so healthy, I want to learn it." He smiled and said: "Drink hot water." 

This is based on the Zen-Taoist principle: 上善若水 (the highest virtue is to be like water). But Doctor Wang explained to me that the real meaning is to BE water. It's a traditional health practice dating back millennia, fusing the water and fire elements [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wu_Xing] to flush the body of toxins and cleanse it. To aid in the ingestion of hot water we drink vintage Pu'er old growth tea from Doctor Wang's home province of Yunnan. Our healing center will make this unique tea available to all interested in experiencing traditional Chinese tea culture.

 

Clean Food 木

Soon after meeting Doctor Wang I quit my magazine editing job at UC-Berkeley and began spending every day with him, helping with his clinic, patients, and learning as much as I could about his traditional healing practice. In addition to drinking hot water, the practice also includes a simple plant-based diet. The philosophy is that we are so full of toxins that to cleanse you have to first stop putting more poison into your body. I've seen people lose ten pounds in a week this way, not fasting but just drinking hot water and eating healthy food. I helped Doctor Wang open a healing center in the Mission District of San Francisco, and moved into the center as its first caretaker. After serving in the center for a year, I drove cross-country to Duke and found that traditional China had come to North Carolina.

 

Kung-fu 金 

Upon arriving, I sought out the Duke Tai-Chi Club. I found a martial arts community more vibrant than any I encountered in my daily pre-dawn forays to Chinese parks to learn tai-chi. The Duke Tai-Chi Club was led by Ben Fisher, a disciple of Master Sam Chin and his 意力拳/Iliqchuan (ILC) family martial art [http://www.mindfulkungfu.com]. I've been studying with them ever since. The group, no longer affiliated with Duke, meets three times a week for 2-3 hours and practices solo exercises and also spars. Sam Chin is the most knowledgeable martial artist I've ever studied with. He's a dedicated teacher with students all over the world. 

The North Carolina ILC community is a special piece of traditional Chinese culture in Durham, and our culture center will host regular martial art classes and events.

 

Organic Farming 土

During my time in China, what I missed more than anything was unspoiled nature. I've reconnected with that in North Carolina. My love for the outdoors and commitment to healthy eating has led me to organic gardening. For the past six years I've cultivated my own and the Duke Community organic garden. I grow most of the food I eat, supplemented by the fresh produce at the Durham Farmer's Market. Organic gardening is an integral part of my health and spiritual practice, as it was in traditional Chinese culture.

Our traditional culture center will teach people not only how to grow their own organic produce, but how to live off of it. We will offer organic meals and juice from our home-grown fruit.

 

中国传统文化中心

为何要开办中国传统文化中心？

我的大部分成年时光是在中国渡过的。2006年，我搬回北卡，在我曾于80年代就读过的杜克大学做访问学者。我非常吃惊地发现，在校园内，说中文像说英文一样普遍。迄今为止，中国留学生是杜克大学外国留学生中最大的群体。80年代我上学时，杜克只有为数不多的来自中国的研究生，且根本没有本科生。现在不同了，中国的研究生和本科生加起来有几千人，占外国留学生半数以上。随着中国经济的不断快速发展，人们对中国的兴趣愈加浓厚。学习中文、 中国历史和文化的年轻西方人与日俱增。我们在杜克举办的每周一次的中国圆桌会议，每次都有几十位中美学生出席，他们聚在一起说中文，分享对中国文化的感想。我也常在家开饺子派对，总有几十位客人光临。我的家一直是个非正式的中国文化中心。现在时机已经成熟，我要把它办成在Durham正式的中国传统文化中心。


提供的活动项目：

中心将提供以下课程：

 

普通话

书法、 绘画

武术

瑜伽

打坐

中医，指压按摩，及全身治疗 (bodywork)

 

其他活动包括：

 

传统中国茶道

用自家种植的有机植物烹调的传统美食

中国音乐表演

中国电影放映

自制饺子派对

 

我的经历

水与茶—水/火 

在中国工作和居住了20年后，我回到了旧金山湾区，再次遇见了这位比我在中国认识的任何人都精通中国文化的老师。 我和王明一（Wang Mingyi）早在1989年事件之前就在北京相识。 我当时是合众国际社的外国记者，他是巴尔迪摩太阳报的翻译。1989年6月天安门广场悲剧发生后，人们都随风散落各地。明一回到了他位于缅甸、越南和泰国金三角边界的云南省的村庄，给一位中医当学徒。他开始实践这一医术，邂逅了一位美国妇女，便与她结婚成家。他们育有三名子女，现住旧金山。在那里，十年之后，我再次跟他不期而遇。 他是健康的化身，他比我十几年初次见面时更年轻了。我跟他说：“你是怎么保持健康的，我也要跟你学。”他笑着对我说：“喝热水。”

这源于禅和道家的原理：上善若水。 但王大夫跟我解释说它的真正含义就是人要像水一样。这是有着几千年历史的医道，通过水与火融合将体内的毒素冲洗干净。为了有助于热水的吸收，我们每天喝王大夫云南老家种植的陈年普洱。我们的治疗中心备有这种独特的茶，随时欢迎对传统中国茶道感兴趣的人。

 

干净的食物—木

见到王大夫不久，我就辞去了在加州伯克利大学做杂志编辑的工作。我每天跟王大夫一道帮他料理诊所和患者，同时跟他学习他的传统治疗术。除了喝热水，该治疗术还包括主要由植物构成的食谱。该原理认为，我们全身充满毒素，要想清洗，必须首先停止把更多的毒素带入体内。我亲眼见到有人用此办法在一周内体重减轻了10磅。这并不是禁食，而是喝热水，吃健康食品。我帮助王大夫在旧金山的Mission 区开办了他的诊所，随即搬到那里成为诊所第一个管理人。在诊所服务了一年之后，我开车穿越美国返回杜克，我发现传统的中国已经来到了北卡。

 

功夫—金

一到此地，我便找到了杜克太极俱乐部。这里的武术社区充满活力，绝不亚于当年我每天凌晨在中国的公园学太极拳所见的景象。杜克太极俱乐部由Ben Fisher 带领。Ben Fisher是Sam Chin 师傅的弟子，跟随他学习意力拳。我从那时开始就一直跟他们学。如今，这个俱乐部已经不属于杜克了。它的成员每周三次、 每次2 到3 小时练习单手拳和对手拳。Sam Chin 是我所从师的武术教练中对武术最精通的师傅。他具有奉献精神，他的学生来自世界各地。 

北卡意力拳社团是Durham 中国传统文化的一只独秀。我们的文化中心将举办定期的武术课和活动。

 

有机栽培—土

在中国居住期间，我最怀念的是未受破坏的自然。回到北卡，我又回归到大自然之中。我对户外运动的热爱和对健康饮食的承诺使我开始栽培有机植物。六年来，我耕种自家和杜克社区的菜园。我吃的大部分食品是我自己种的，其它的是Durham 农贸市场的新鲜农产品。就像中国传统文化，有机栽培是我身体和精神实践的一个组成部分。

我们的传统文化中心不仅会教大家怎样种植有机农产品，还教人们怎样靠它生活。我们还会提供自家种植的有机美食和水果的果汁。

我的经历
水与茶—水/火 
在中国工作和居住了20年后，我回到了旧金山湾区，再次遇见了这位比我在中国认识的任何人都精通中国文化的老师。 我和王明一（Wang Mingyi）早在1989年事件之前就在北京相识。 我当时是合众国际社的外国记者，他是巴尔迪摩太阳报的翻译。1989年6月天安门广场悲剧发生后，人们都随风散落各地。明一回到了他位于缅甸、越南和泰国金三角边界的云南省的村庄，给一位中医当学徒。他开始实践这一医术，邂逅了一位美国妇女，便与她结婚成家。他们育有三名子女，现住旧金山。在那里，十年之后，我再次跟他不期而遇。 他是健康的化身，他比我十几年初次见面时更年轻了。我跟他说：“你是怎么保持健康的，我也要跟你学。”他笑着对我说：“喝热水。”
这源于禅和道家的原理：上善若水。 但王大夫跟我解释说它的真正含义就是人要像水一样。这是有着几千年历史的医道，通过水与火融合将体内的毒素冲洗干净。为了有助于热水的吸收，我们每天喝王大夫云南老家种植的陈年普洱。我们的治疗中心备有这种独特的茶，随时欢迎对传统中国茶道感兴趣的人。
 
干净的食物—木
见到王大夫不久，我就辞去了在加州伯克利大学做杂志编辑的工作。我每天跟王大夫一道帮他料理诊所和患者，同时跟他学习他的传统治疗术。除了喝热水，该治疗术还包括主要由植物构成的食谱。该原理认为，我们全身充满毒素，要想清洗，必须首先停止把更多的毒素带入体内。我亲眼见到有人用此办法在一周内体重减轻了10磅。这并不是禁食，而是喝热水，吃健康食品。我帮助王大夫在旧金山的Mission 区开办了他的诊所，随即搬到那里成为诊所第一个管理人。在诊所服务了一年之后，我开车穿越美国返回杜克，我发现传统的中国已经来到了北卡。
 
功夫—金
一到此地，我便找到了杜克太极俱乐部。这里的武术社区充满活力，绝不亚于当年我每天凌晨在中国的公园学太极拳所见的景象。杜克太极俱乐部由Ben Fisher 带领。Ben Fisher是Sam Chin 师傅的弟子，跟随他学习意力拳。我从那时开始就一直跟他们学。如今，这个俱乐部已经不属于杜克了。它的成员每周三次、 每次2 到3 小时练习单手拳和对手拳。Sam Chin 是我所从师的武术教练中对武术最精通的师傅。他具有奉献精神，他的学生来自世界各地。 
北卡意力拳社团是Durham 中国传统文化的一只独秀。我们的文化中心将举办定期的武术课和活动。
 
有机栽培—土
在中国居住期间，我最怀念的是未受破坏的自然。回到北卡，我又回归到大自然之中。我对户外运动的热爱和对健康饮食的承诺使我开始栽培有机植物。六年来，我耕种自家和杜克社区的菜园。我吃的大部分食品是我自己种的，其它的是Durham 农贸市场的新鲜农产品。就像中国传统文化，有机栽培是我身体和精神实践的一个组成部分。
我们的传统文化中心不仅会教大家怎样种植有机农产品，还教人们怎样靠它生活。我们还会提供自家种植的有机美食和水果的果汁。

story:
The Discovery Annex

“A place for all our kids”

A little about the program:

The Discovery Annex will be special place for children and families, offering children ages 2-12 the opportunity to develop and learn at their own pace. The integrated curriculum will cover not only academics but social, emotional, and physical development as well as a strong arts/ language and technological component. A qualified, dedicated staff combined with a low teacher: child ratio means that each child gets the most from their earliest journeys of discovery.

Our goal is to develop lifelong learners who are ready to meet their future academic and social challenges with success and confidence. As part of that goal, we know that our focus cannot only be on the child but must include the family and the community at large. We will partner with families to form a circle of learning for their child, and a circle of support for the family. We will also partner with local agencies to serve our community as a whole.

A little about me.

My name is Kelly Sedlak.(That’s me with the chick,in the pic).

I have been a Teacher of young children and Director of childcare / preschool programs for over 20 years. I hold a Master’s Degree in Special Education and Early Childhood from St. Joseph College in CT, as well as an undergrad degree from Sarah Lawrence College. I have directed some of the largest programs in the State of CT. I have guided programs through national accreditation as well as being well versed in all administrative aspects of a Childcare program.

I am an active member of my community, and the ECE community. I have 10+ of experience on various community boards such as School Readiness, Head Start, and the United Way, and have coordinated over 50 community events (some city wide).I also teach and direct a local Baton Twirling group.

The time is now to open a program in CT where the best practices I have seen, taught, developed and implemented over the years, can be incorporated into one special place. The Discovery Annex will be that place. The only thing needed is your support!

A little about what The Discovery Annex needs:

The Discovery Annex will be located in a currently operational Childcare program that is for sale. As this is a “turnkey” business, with transition assistance provided by the current owner, the state and local licensing will be streamlined.

Your support of The Discovery Annex will allow us to transition the program to one that will be a model for the area. Each contribution will help to:

  • partially fund the deposit / down payment for the existing program
  • Fund the initial startup / change over costs
  • Purchase new equipment as needed to facilitate the tech component of the program.
  • Offset the costs of startup fees for the State and Local agencies.

A little about the Perks!

If you support The Discovery Annex you will be laying the groundwork for hundreds of children to have the opportunity for a special experience. Check out the Perk section of the campaign! You can receive an original work of art, a plaque on the wall of the Center showing your support, or even get to NAME one of our classrooms!

Every dollar will get The Discovery Annex closer to opening!

BUT if you can’t donate there is still something you can do!!

TELL EVERYONE YOU KNOW ABOUT THIS!!!!

Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, etc…email them, shout it from the rooftops!!

story:
Hi, I’m Jasmine Mattson a 12 year old student from North Carolina. This year I have been offered the chance of a lifetime… to be a delegate on a global service-learning experience to Ghana, West Africa, to learn, share, and work with African villages!  When I was about 5 I got a book about Africa and ever since then I was obsessed with it. It became a dream of mine to visit Africa and I have been offered the chance … to actually GO THERE, and to help!   I was ecstatic, but I don’t have the money ($2,200) to go so I am on a fundraising effort and my first deadline is on Friday.
 
In March 2013, our group of 7th and 8th grade delegates from Evergreen Community Charter School (ECCS; evergreenccs.org) will embark on a 12-day global service-learning experience to Ghana, in partnership with Motherland International Relations (motherlandinternational.org). I need my first taste of the developing world like nothing else, and want to share the wonders of lifetime with the other curious children at my school.
 
In Africa, we will connect with students at The Esiam Heritge Academy, a progressive school in the heart of Ghana, to help initiate a new farming program for the 1,000 day-students at Heritage Academy. The farming program is the result of a Heritage Academy student-lead project aimed at developing sustainable solutions to the challenges of contemporary village life (schoerkefoundation.org).
The ECCS delegation will also work with AproTech, an organization dedicated to fostering sustainable and equitable development in Ghana and across Africa (aprotechghana.wordpress.com). AproTech, created by Dr. Kofi Sam, a physics professor, government Secretary of Housing, and classmate of former UN Secretary Kofi Annan, is devoted to giving Africa's rural poor the right tools to make use of the resources around them so that they can work their own way out of poverty.
 
If I were you this would be great to donate to, because it’s not a simple trip somewhere it’s educating the young minds of the next generation. I know I have made a difference where I have gone before, but this is bigger than any goal I’ve pushed myself towards before. Just remember if you can’t donate that’s fine but it would be lovely if you spread the word to others that you think may be able to. If you have and account on Indigogo or Facebook, please share!!  I really appreciate it!  
Thanks – Jasmine Mattson

story:
Support Girls Leadership

Help us send three of our 6th grade girls from the South Bronx to the Girls Leadership Institute in South Hadley Massachusets for 3 weeks this summer.

The Girls Leadership Institute (GLI), founded by girl expert and best selling author Rachel Simmons, gives girls the skills and confidence to be leaders in their communities.

At Mott Hall Charter School our mission is to prepare our students for the best high schools in New York City and beyond. 

GLI is providing half scholarships to our students and now we have to come up with the rest. 

Please make your tax-deductible contribution today and share this project with others.

Thank you for your support!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Hola!

You've gotten this far, so thank you! A little about about why I created this page...

If you're not familiar with Google Glass, the video above is a great introduction. 

How I got here...

A while ago, the Project Glass team opened up a way for the eager Google Glass community to submit fun, and creative things they would do if they had a pair, so I submitted the following:

#ifihadglass I'd explore more than I'd ever imagine, differently, in order to experience things in a way I never thought possible.

— Cesar Razuri (@CeaseTheDay) February 20, 2013

About a month later I started seeing tweets indicating that they've been selected to be a lucky bunch of 8,000 #GlassExplorers, and then I got this reply on Twitter: 

@ceasetheday You’re invited to join our #glassexplorers program. Woohoo! Make sure to follow us - we’ll DM in the coming weeks.

— Project Glass (@projectglass) March 27, 2013

 My jaw dropped... If you know me, you know I love technology and all things Google. 

Be part of this journey with me!

The enrollment to this program comes at a cost. Being an early adopter isn't cheap, nor is this opportunity. $1,500 is the enrollment fee (I'm only asking for $1,000 + $100 to cover fees), and gets me a pair of Google Glasses, but it's more than that...

My tweet above is 100% true. An avid oversharer, my passion for technology is rooted in its impact to society and how it can help create a single, or multiple stories. I don't do it on purpose, it just happens organically. The way I see technology in the future is a simplification of our day-to-day activities, but more importantly, introduce a more efficient, and impactful way to communicate. I get giddy about the day these glasses get delivered to me, but I need your help! Be part of this journey with me!

I tried to offer a variety of different donation buckets. 

The bonus factor.

Should your gratious donations exceed my goal, I will take those additional funds and put them towards a charitable donation to the ASPCA, and yes, I will show proof to show that it will happen :)

Trust me, I hesitated setting this page up because there are several reasons to donate to a variety of different casuses. I get that, but if you decide to donate elsewhere that's totally fine by me. In fact, if this page inspires you to donate towards another cause, that's awesome!

Wait, one more thing!

Another way you can help me is by spreading the word. Let's turn this into a fun way we share this technological milestone with friends and family. Whether it's a picture, video, or being part of a hangout, there is a shareable opportunity to include those close to you as well.

Indiegogo has some share tools that makes it easier.

Thank You!

No, honestly. Thank you. Even if you don't donate and you've read this far I hope it'll at least give you a glimpse of me and my excitement towards being part of this journey.

story:
About Prince Otchere

UPDATE - PARTIAL SUCCESS!
By God’s grace, I have successfully registered for the first Semester of the academic year. Through the effort of this campaign, a generous man has co-signed an amount that made my registration possible. I appreciate your prayers, contribution and support through this difficult time. Your words of encouragement and your zeal to help another in need have been inspiring. I am still short $16,174 for the Second half of the year. Because of your generous donation of $5600, what I actually need to raise now is $10,569 to cover the rest of the school year. Again, I thank God and everyone who has given of themselves to make sure that my dream comes true.

-Prince

------------

A huge, sincere thank-you to everyone who has contributed, been involved with and shared this campaign so far. The response has been uplifting and heart-warming. Your help is truly appreciated.

(Please note that we cannot change the official "goal" of $30,000 as it is listed on this campaign. The true goal of this campaign now is $16,174 - $5,605 of which has been met at the time of this writing.) Thank you.

-Ryan

------------

My name is Ryan Knopper and I have created this campaign to help my friend Prince Otchere continue his education at Loma Linda University School of Medicine. Let me tell you more about him. 

Imagine one day you fall ill and are in desperate nend of medical attention. None of us ever expect to be in this predicament, but if we are, we want to know that we are being cared for by the most knowledgeable and capable physician possible.  Someone who is caring, smart, intelligent and able to work with you to get you better.

This is exactly the type of physician that Prince Otchere is becoming. Having already completed his first year of medical school and excelling in his classes, he is on track to fulfill his dream and calling to become a physician who will meet the needs of underserved communities both here and abroad. 

The only problem is that Prince’s path is threatened to be derailed due to financial need. As an intenational student from Ghana, Prince is not eligible for financial aid. As a first year student, he received a scholarship to cover part of tuition expenses and secured a private student loan to cover the rest. Thankfully, he has another scholarship and found a cosigner for much of the sophomore year.. However, he still needs to raise $10,569 to make up the remainder. At present, he has truly exhausted all available options up to this point, including scholarships, loans, and gifts from family and friends. He has been in contact with the administration of the school and has worked hard to actively seek out resources and networking opportunities to finance his education. His efforts have brought him this far, but even after working with several cosigners, the circumstances of our current economy have made it difficult to secure private loans for the full amount necessary for him to be able to continue on in medical school with his class this coming fall.

Once he is finished with his 2nd year, the school will give him full institutional aid for his 3rd and 4th years, so this is the time that we really need your assistance to help us collectively push Prince over this financial hump.

Why Contribute

Your donation will not only benefit a future physician, but all of the communities and families that Prince will come in contact with in the future around the world. This is an opportunity to give a gift that will have exponential dividends far beyond this moment. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not help financially, please help spread the word throughout your social networks, coworkers, church groups, friends and family. Indiegogo has some amazing tools that make sharing fast and easy. Prince can use any help you are willing to give.

Thank-you!

I would like to personally thank you for your time in reading about Prince's story. If anyone would like more information please feel free to contact me at rknopper@llu.edu or you can contact Prince directly at potchere@llu.edu. 

May God Bless you.

Ryan
