story:
About the TAASC Dyslexia Project

 It is believed that dyslexia can affect around 10 percent of a given population

Dyslexia is a learning disorder characterized by difficulty reading. The disorder is a specific information processing problem that does not interfere with one’s ability to think or understand complex ideas.

Dyslexic people are highly creative, intuitive, and excel at three-dimensional problem solving and hands-on learning. Unfortunately the core of our educational system and environment outside of school relies on reading, word recognition and decoding. These areas are of great struggle and difficulty for the dyslexic.

Because of this many students with dyslexia experience a loss of or low self-esteem. This can lead to behavior problems, anxiety, aggression and withdrawal from friends, parents and teachers. 

The TAASC impact 

We have found at TAASC that our students with dyslexia flourish. TAASC is a youth based non profit (501(c)(3) that combines wilderness leadership and service learning to create compassionate, capable leaders. For over 7 years we have been providing life changing experiences aimed at developing qualities essential to succeeding in life.

Parents of our dyslexic students comment on the changes they see in their kids. They grow in confidence and are able to transfer this confidence from their wilderness experiences to their school work. Their self-esteem develops as they master the skills required to travel, play, and learn in the wilderness. They are natural leaders and begin to see themselves for the strengths they possess rather than the disability they have.

The multi-sensory environment of the wilderness plays to their intellectual strengths  allowing them to believe in themselves as capable, bright leaders. The experiential nature of the wilderness allows them to have breakthrough successes they have not yet experienced at school or home.

We have been amazed at the impact of TAASC on students with dyslexia and would like to offer it to a larger number of students who struggle with the self doubt and sense of inadequacy that can be so paralyzing.

Freya’s story from the video above is a great testimonial to the success of students with dyslexia participating in this program.

 

Funding Received for this Project will go directly to the following:

  • specialized curriculum development for children with learning challenges
  • scholarship for students with dyslexia who would benefit from being in TAASC
  • an evaluation study, so we can track our results and keep improving what we do

 

Your investment in a student with dyslexia will provide them with the following activities over the course of a year.

  • 30 days of outdoor adventure trips/service projects during the school year
  • 36 weekly meetings, where students learn both technical and leadership skills, plan service projects and wilderness adventures
  • Longer 10-day summer adventure trips
  • Learning hard skills such as knot tying, map reading, wilderness first aid, cooking, and other technical outdoor skills
  • Developing organizational and planning skills
  • Practicing leadership skills, working in a group and increasing their ability to share ideas and help the group problem solve.

 

Whether we meet, exceed or fall short of our goal all of the funds raised will go toward developing the Dyslexia Project as outlined above.

 

Other Ways You Can Participate

If you can’t donate, please share this web page with your friends and family. Use the IndieGoGo tools at the top to recommend this page via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, or Google+.

 

You can learn more about us at www.ashevilletaasc.com

or via the facebook link below
story_txt:
About the TAASC Dyslexia Project
 It is believed that dyslexia can affect around 10 percent of a given population
Dyslexia is a learning disorder characterized by difficulty reading. The disorder is a specific information processing problem that does not interfere with one’s ability to think or understand complex ideas.
Dyslexic people are highly creative, intuitive, and excel at three-dimensional problem solving and hands-on learning. Unfortunately the core of our educational system and environment outside of school relies on reading, word recognition and decoding. These areas are of great struggle and difficulty for the dyslexic.
Because of this many students with dyslexia experience a loss of or low self-esteem. This can lead to behavior problems, anxiety, aggression and withdrawal from friends, parents and teachers. 
The TAASC impact 
We have found at TAASC that our students with dyslexia flourish. TAASC is a youth based non profit (501(c)(3) that combines wilderness leadership and service learning to create compassionate, capable leaders. For over 7 years we have been providing life changing experiences aimed at developing qualities essential to succeeding in life.
Parents of our dyslexic students comment on the changes they see in their kids. They grow in confidence and are able to transfer this confidence from their wilderness experiences to their school work. Their self-esteem develops as they master the skills required to travel, play, and learn in the wilderness. They are natural leaders and begin to see themselves for the strengths they possess rather than the disability they have.
The multi-sensory environment of the wilderness plays to their intellectual strengths  allowing them to believe in themselves as capable, bright leaders. The experiential nature of the wilderness allows them to have breakthrough successes they have not yet experienced at school or home.
We have been amazed at the impact of TAASC on students with dyslexia and would like to offer it to a larger number of students who struggle with the self doubt and sense of inadequacy that can be so paralyzing.
Freya’s story from the video above is a great testimonial to the success of students with dyslexia participating in this program.
 
Funding Received for this Project will go directly to the following:

specialized curriculum development for children with learning challenges
scholarship for students with dyslexia who would benefit from being in TAASC
an evaluation study, so we can track our results and keep improving what we do

 
Your investment in a student with dyslexia will provide them with the following activities over the course of a year.

30 days of outdoor adventure trips/service projects during the school year
36 weekly meetings, where students learn both technical and leadership skills, plan service projects and wilderness adventures
Longer 10-day summer adventure trips
Learning hard skills such as knot tying, map reading, wilderness first aid, cooking, and other technical outdoor skills
Developing organizational and planning skills
Practicing leadership skills, working in a group and increasing their ability to share ideas and help the group problem solve.

 
Whether we meet, exceed or fall short of our goal all of the funds raised will go toward developing the Dyslexia Project as outlined above.
 


Other Ways You Can Participate


If you can’t donate, please share this web page with your friends and family. Use the IndieGoGo tools at the top to recommend this page via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, or Google+.
 
You can learn more about us at www.ashevilletaasc.com

story:
Adolescents Breathe Peace in Prison

My name is Lisa V. Blake and I am the founder of the Maine Mindfulness Project, a program I began in 2009 to teach the practice of meditation in a number of venues in the state of Maine.  The initial focus was to deliver meditation sessions in schools and medical settings to help children and people of all ages learn to use a simple breathing technique to create peace and expand inner space awareness, while also enjoying the side perk of the practice: alleviating stress and negativity.

In 2010, I was asked to start a program as a volunteer at the state's largest adolescent prison.  Due to the success of the work with over a hundred adolescent inmates who have gone through the meditation and yoga classes, the inmates have requested that we expand this project.

I will love to do just that with your kind support and generous help.  

This project is especially important to me because these children are the self described "worst adolescent criminial offenderes in Maine," but under the veneer of the scared and hardened attitude are tender and confused hearts waiting for someone to teach them peace, love and happiness.  

This is what our meditation and yoga program does by helping them to learn how to feel safe and breathe peace.

The magnitude of what contributors will help us achieve is to create a more peaceful society by helping these young people understand themselves on a more profound level and that they do have other choices in life beyond violence and crime. Therefore, the whole community in the state benefits from truly rehabilitating and re-forming these young people.  

What We Need & What You Get

I have kept this volunteer project going on my own expense for over 2 years.  Recently i asked a yoga teacher to come on board and she is great!

We need to raise $12,000 to continue to add another teacher and expand the number of classes we offer in order to meet the demand from the adolescent inmates.

 Currently, we have volunteered 5 hours each per week and have covered our own travel expenses for the past 2 years (over 100 miles per week).  In order to keep the program growing and successful, we are trying to offer 5 hours of instruction each week covering all the units and inmates.  

If we do not reach our entire goal, we will use whatever funds are raised to expand the program as feasibly as possible.  I am also the Buddhist Chaplain at the prison.

The Impact

Our unique program is building a more peaceful society here in Maine and is a model that can be expanded and duplicated in other states and countries. By sharing love and happiness with youth who have not truly experienced much of either of these feelings we are truly able to help young people learn to love themselves and make better choices in the future.

Maine has the nation's lowest adolescent recidivism rate and it is due to engaged interaction with deeply troubled youth who are eager to learn better.  This program teaches them how to learn and feel better, pointing them inward in order to guide them outwardly in new directions. 

I have taught meditation to thousands of people, many of them youth and teenagers.  No one has yet reported that they felt zero benefit or did not enjoy the experience. If we want world peace, we have to teach our children well how to live in peace.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for reading about our project.  If you are unable to help financially, please help us spread the word about our project to media or other folks who might be able to contribute.  Or just get excited that we are truly helping to make the lives of some imprisoned young people better for them, which ultimately will be better for us all.

story:
Short Summary

In 2008 Camp Thunderbird South Dakota was founded by a few caring teachers at He Dog School on the Rosebud Indian Reservation in South Dakota.

Their intention was not to solve all of the problems faced by students growing up on the reservation, but to offer a tool to address them.

With support from He Dog School and the Boys and Girls Club of Rosebud, the camp was able to hold summer camp on the reservation and become a source of learning, leadership, and success for kids.

Now, the camp aims to grow and impact an increasing number of students.

What We Need & Why

In order for us to reach this goal, we need:

  • $1,500 to fund a stipend for a part-time, volunteer Camp Director.
  • Communicating with families, soliciting and vetting camper applications, scheduling activities, arranging for food and lodging, and recruiting and training staff -- that's hard work. Even harder when the same person is responsible soliciting donor and community support. We need a dedicated position to improve our effectiveness.
  • To make this position feasible for qualified candidates, we hope to cover living expenses for the weeks leading up to and following each camp, and provide a stipend for some of their service. This will allow us to begin this summer prepared to give campers the best experience possible.
  • Any money we raise through our IndieGoGo campaign will help to fund this position and improve the effectiveness of our organization.

The Impact

Native American youth in South Dakota face poverty, substance abuse, gangs and parental neglect. The suicide rate for Native youth in the Great Plains is ten times the national average [1]. Not surprisingly, education is undermined. Native students trail their white peers by two to three grade levels in reading and math [2]. As one community member and aide at He Dog School on the Rosebud Reservation described, “There are so few opportunities here that can give our kids hope from a young age.”

Excitingly, small, targeted interventions focused on self-affirmation can feedback to have lasting impacts on academic achievement for those most at risk [3]. Camp Thunderbird works to provide educational, confidence-boosting, summer activities, that are otherwise not available in these remote rural areas. Because cultural pride is crucial, we work along side other community organizations and with community members to help foster cultural competency and pride. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The Camp Director position is just one way we're looking to expand. Here are additional ways of getting involved:

  • Spread the word!
    • Visit our website at www.campthunderbirdsd.org/info
    • "like" Camp Thunderbird South Dakota on facebook!
    • Follow us on Twitter. @CampTbirdSD
  • Join our Advisory Board!
    • Advisory Board members help raise funds for Camp Thunderbird, and we utilize their skills in other ways. If you are interested in volunteering, contact us through our website for more information. www.campthunderbirdsd.org/info
  • Contact us!
    • We would love your questions and feedback!
  • Donate!
    • If you're unable to donate before the project deadline, you can donate on our website any time.

 

[1] Woodard S. Oct. 10, 2012. "Suicide is epidemic for American Indian youth: What more can be done?" (Open Channel on NBCNEWS.com). 

 Nieves E. June 9, 2007. New York Times. "Indian Reservation Reeling in Wave of Youth Suicides and Attempts."

[2]National Conference of State Legislatures, 2008

[3]Cohen et al. 2009. Science. "Recursive Processes in Self-Affirmation: Intervening to Close the Minority Achievement Gap."2

story:
The Jeff and King Foundation

 

We want to commemorate the history of Black America by celebrating the excellence of future â€œhistory makersâ€ in Black America.  Throughout February, we urge Durham to show its gratitude for the youth that are working hard to achieve, despite adverse conditions.

 

Durham has long been commended for the educated mass of urban transplants that take residence here, finding employment at the Research Triangle Park or furthering their education at one of the many institutions of higher learning.  Conversely, the city is mired by a persistent failure to improve the test-scores and graduation rates of its own high school students.  Most notably is the considerable disparity between Black and white test takers. (For statistical evidence view 2011â€™s Preliminary ABC Data Presentation available here: http://www.dpsnc.net/news/frontpage-news/dps-releases-preliminary-abcs-test-results)

 

It is not our aim to highlight the negatives; rather, as college educated Black males, who excelled within Durhamâ€™s dysfunctional system, we want to celebrate the success of one rising senior who has worked diligently to counter the odds.

 

While many have narrowed our contributions by labeling us as â€œparty promotersâ€ we counter that limiting perception with the following assertion: our primary undertaking is to offset local, national, and international inequality with philanthropy and conscientious, grassroots fundraising.  The formation of The Jeff and King Foundation endeavors to demonstrate our commitment to peer leadership and civic duty.

 

The Jeff and King Foundation aims to offer a $15,000 scholarship to a rising senior who meets the following criteria:

 

  • Black Male
  • Resident of Durham County
  • Graduating Senior within the Durham Public School system
  • Minimum 3.3 GPA

 

All applicants will need to submit the following for consideration:

 

  • High School transcript
  • Resume (extracurricular activities, honor society memberships, work experience, volunteerism, and accolades)
  • Three Reference Letters (professors, employers, coaches, volunteer supervisors, pastor/church leaders, or guidance counselors)
  • 900-word essay answering the query: What Black Man has served as the greatest inspiration in your Life? Why? 

 

Funds will be raised throughout the month of February here and at sponsored locations/events.

 

*Applications will be accepted March 1st â€“ April 30th.  The award will be rewarded during the recipientâ€™s graduation ceremony.

 

A panel of esteemed, Black men will review the applications (TBA).

 

No contribution is too small. 

 

Thank you in advance for your continued support,

Jeff and King

story:
Well, hello! Allow me to start by saying thank you for visiting this page and considering supporting this project. My name is Amanda- I am a Returned Peace Corps Volunteer who served in the country of Kyrgyzstan (in Central Asia) from 2012-2013. During my service, I had the distinct pleasure of working with my good friend Kushtar. This friend of mine has had a significant impact on me. Kushtar is the definition of a kindred spirit: humble, kind, compassionate, hard-working, enthusiastic, intelligent, and dedicated to her community, family, friends, fellow teachers, and especially to her students. Her dedication to students is illustrated by her taking a personal interest in them, desiring each of them to achieve their full potential. As an example of her dedication to her community- Last year, Kushtar went door-to-door in her village raising money for her disabled neighbor who could not afford a medically necessary surgery. 

Kushtar has taught English to students full-time at E. Kenderbiev Secondary School in Barskoon Village for nearly a decade and has never had her own classroom. She must temporarily use the classrooms of other teachers and lug her books and teaching materials from room to room to teach her lessons. Along with the funding of this project, Kushtar will be awarded with her own classroom- allowing a refuge for her students and Kushtar with the ability to reach her teaching and creative potential. Great teachers should be rewarded and encouraged- Kushtar is an incredible English teacher. 

Students at E. Kenderbiev are eager to learn and improve their English. Many of the students I worked with chose to stay after their lessons at school to take advantage of extra time with the English textbooks and with Kushtar. The classroom will serve as a refuge for these students for decades to come. 

Specifically, this project will allow Kushtar to purchase white boards for the classroom (a rare luxury in a Kyrgyz Village), Kyrgyz-English dictionaries, educational posters and banners, a bookshelf, a CD player for English listening activities, and some classroom decorations. Upon project funding, expect to see happy pictures from Kushtar and her students using these classroom materials! 

For Kyrgyz youth raised in a village, the best chance most have of leaving their village for a better job and the opportunity of improving their life circumstance is to learn English. This project directly funds the improvement of educational opportunities for these youngsters. Kushtar understands the need for her students to learn English if they hope for a brighter future and better jobs. 

While working together during my service in Barskoon, Kushtar and I successfully raised funds for a weekly Girl's Club- designed to give high school girls a safe place to talk about controversial issues pertaining to young females, and a Healthy Women's Club- teaching women about the value of good nutrition and exercise. 

I understand some of you may be reading this while unable to contribute financially to the campaign- that's okay! You can still help by sharing this page with your family and friends. Thank you again for visiting and considering giving your support to "A Classroom for Kushtar!" 

Check out the links below to a few of my blog posts for more stories about Kushtar and the people of Barskoon!

story:
What is TADW

Teenage Drama Workshop (TADW) is a six-week intensive workshop for young people (grades 7-12) interested in theatre. It is the longest running workshop of its kind in the nation.The faculty and staff are members of the CSUN Theatre department, experienced drama teachers and theatre professionals.

The full-time program begins at 8:15am and ends at 4:15pm, every weekday. Classes are from 8:15am to 12:30pm every morning (except when we have 11am performances). 

  • Students in the performance track begin the day with intensive classes in voice, dance and acting, along with an elective (improvisation, musical theatre or playwriting).  After lunch, they break out by cast to rehearse for either the musical or the play. 
  • Students in the technical track will begin their morning with classes in costuming, lighting, sound and stagecraft.  After lunch, they will break out by crew to work behind the scenes on the musical or plays. 
  • As the six weeks come to an end and the productions go up, the performance students will also use their afternoon session to rehearse for dance class finals, to stage and rehearse their 10-minute plays, and to prepare for the musical theatre showcase called “Munch & Crunch.”  Needless to say, TADW is a busy place!


The Miracle Project

THE MIRACLE PROJECT founded in 2004 is a multiplatform socialization program that enables children and teens with autism and other special needs to express themselves through music, dance, acting, story, and writing. ALL children of ALL abilities grow in skill and in spirit while creating and performing in original musicals. This acclaimed arts program was documented in the HBO double EMMY Award-winning documentary, AUTISM: THE MUSICAL.

In the summer 0f 2013, TADW teamed with the founder of The Miracle Project to create a special performance (sensory performance) of Disney's Aladdin. This gave children with Autism and other special needs, and their parents the opportunity to attend a live theater event. Children were introduced to the characters and actors before the play started, loud and sudden noises were curbed, and volume was decreased. This allowed for significantly less stress for the audience. It was a HUGE success.

This summer (2014), TADW will be offering sensory performances for both main shows (Disney's Beauty and the Beast, Cirque Des Pirates). TADW will also be teaming with The Miracle Project to create and produce an original show titled Joining The Spectrum: A Collaborative Play about Inclusion, will be staged by artists from The Miracle Project, led by director Elaine Hall and her award winning staff. The play will be created by the students of The Miracle Project AND TADW using theatre games, exercises, and storytelling techniques to generate the script.  


TADW Alumni

There are many teen summer theater programs available. But none can boast 57 years of service to their community. How many other programs have had such a profound impact on the students that 20 years later they enroll their own children? 

This unique experience not only helps those that want to pursue careers in the entertainment field. The lessons learned in TADW have helped many to go on to successful careers as doctors, lawyers, researchers, college professors, teachers, authors, speakers, therapists, counselors, corporate executives, graphic artists, computer programmers, clergy, etc, etc. Our alumni touch just about every field imaginable. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

It has been the policy of TADW to never turn away a student for financial reasons. Recent increases in program costs, and the poor economy have conspired to create a situation where more students need assistance, and less money is available to assist those potential students. I recently received the following email from Doug Kaback, Executive Director of TADW:

"TADW needs help as we prepare for our 57th summer. We never want to turn an interested student away from TADW because of money and we seek to help every family that requires financial assistance. There are more than 10 prospective students at the moment that need scholarships, but TADW doesn’t have the resources. Some of these students are teens on the Autism spectrum who would like to be part of our collaboration with The Miracle Project. We’ve received an important grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, but it doesn’t go far enough to provide for all the kids we’d like to serve. Let’s get the word out to our community – all the alumni who still value the role TADW has played in transforming their lives; friends who appreciate the groundbreaking work we’re doing to bring ASD teens and their non-disabled peers together in an original musical about inclusion; and anyone else that’s willing to support us with a tax-deductible contribution in any amount. Thanks to everybody as we all create another memorable summer together!"

WE NEED YOUR HELP to raise funds for financial assistance. We're trying to raise  at least $10000.00 (more = better) to help make this wonderful experience available to those with a real financial need. ALL money collected will go directly to TADW. TADW is a non-profit institution registered 501(c)(3). Your donations may be tax deductable (consult your tax professional). As such, all those who donate will receive a letter from TADW to verify their donation, for tax purposes.

To make donating as simple as possible, we've created four levels for donations:

 Enthusiastic Audience Member: With a $20 donation, you and a guest will be invited to attend any one, special Pre-opening performance of this summers shows. This is a priveledge ordinarally reserved for current and past TADW students.

Chorus Member: A $50 donation gets you 2 tickets to any one performance of any of this summers shows (subject to availability at the time of donation).

Lead Actor: A $75 donation will not only get you 2 tickets to any one performance of any of this summers shows (subject to availability at the time of donation), and a DVD of Autism: The Musical, signed by Elaine Hall..

Director: A donation of $100 will get you 4 tickets to any one performance of any of this summers shows (subject to availability at the time of donation), a DVD of Autism: The Musical, signed by Elaine Hall, AND (drum roll, please) one much coveted 57th annual TADW t-shirt (you will be contacted for size)

Producer: What can we say? A donation of $250 will not only garner you our undying gratitude and affection. You will also get 4 tickets to any one performance of any of this summers shows (subject to availability at the time of donation), a DVD of Autism: The Musical, signed by Elaine Hall, one (drum roll, please) much coveted 57th annual TADW t-shirt (you will be contacted for size), AND a special invitation to the Dean's Reception, July 19, 2014, 6pm (more details will follow in invitation).

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • If you know someone who might be interested in the program, or might want to contribute, PLEASE send them the link to this site.
  • SHARE us on your Facebook, Twitter, and other social media pages!!
story_txt:
What is TADWTeenage Drama Workshop (TADW) is a six-week intensive workshop for young people (grades 7-12) interested in theatre. It is the longest running workshop of its kind in the nation.The faculty and staff are members of the CSUN Theatre department, experienced drama teachers and theatre professionals.The full-time program begins at 8:15am and ends at 4:15pm, every weekday. Classes are from 8:15am to 12:30pm every morning (except when we have 11am performances). 
Students in the performance track begin the day with intensive classes in voice, dance and acting, along with an elective (improvisation, musical theatre or playwriting).  After lunch, they break out by cast to rehearse for either the musical or the play. 
Students in the technical track will begin their morning with classes in costuming, lighting, sound and stagecraft.  After lunch, they will break out by crew to work behind the scenes on the musical or plays. 
As the six weeks come to an end and the productions go up, the performance students will also use their afternoon session to rehearse for dance class finals, to stage and rehearse their 10-minute plays, and to prepare for the musical theatre showcase called “Munch & Crunch.”  Needless to say, TADW is a busy place!
The Miracle ProjectTHE MIRACLE PROJECT founded in 2004 is a multiplatform socialization program that enables children and teens with autism and other special needs to express themselves through music, dance, acting, story, and writing. ALL children of ALL abilities grow in skill and in spirit while creating and performing in original musicals. This acclaimed arts program was documented in the HBO double EMMY Award-winning documentary, AUTISM: THE MUSICAL.In the summer 0f 2013, TADW teamed with the founder of The Miracle Project to create a special performance (sensory performance) of Disney's Aladdin. This gave children with Autism and other special needs, and their parents the opportunity to attend a live theater event. Children were introduced to the characters and actors before the play started, loud and sudden noises were curbed, and volume was decreased. This allowed for significantly less stress for the audience. It was a HUGE success.This summer (2014), TADW will be offering sensory performances for both main shows (Disney's Beauty and the Beast, Cirque Des Pirates). TADW will also be teaming with The Miracle Project to create and produce an original show titled Joining The Spectrum: A Collaborative Play about Inclusion, will be staged by artists from The Miracle Project, led by director Elaine Hall and her award winning staff. The play will be created by the students of The Miracle Project AND TADW using theatre games, exercises, and storytelling techniques to generate the script.  TADW AlumniThere are many teen summer theater programs available. But none can boast 57 years of service to their community. story:
Since 2009, the large room connected to the band room at OHS has been a safe haven for students to come during their study halls, lunches, and after school.  This room - loosely christened "the band office" - has been a home-away-from-home for countless teenagers who need a place to study, discuss, decompress, eat and recreate on their lunch hour, and be themselves without judgement.  It is a place where all students are welcome and all have a voice, a "third space:" not home, not traditional school, but a third type of place to work comfortably.

While the large table is the centerpiece of the room, the primary draw has always been the presence of two couches, furnished by the band teacher.  Recently, in response to heightened district awareness and compliance with fire code and the wishes of the Fire Chief, our beloved couches have been removed from the office, leaving it bare and uninviting.  But all is not lost!  We can replace them just so long as we do so with new furniture, purchased from school specialty vendors, which meet the stringent fire code requirements.  This is where YOU come in!

We want to bring back the comfortable and inviting atmosphere for which the band office is well-known by replacing the old, unsafe furniture with new, code-and-district-approved furniture.  The specific vendors from whom we must purchase the furniture have been identified by the district.  Within those parameters, we chose the lowest cost option that fulfills our needs.  The cost of each unit is about $700, plus shipping; we will purchase two of them once the project is complete and fully funded.  If by chance the goal is exceeded, we will use remaining funds to purchase new and more sturdy office chairs for students to use with the center and surrounding tables.  All funding beyond that will be used to benefit OHS music students through the purchase of reeds, valve oil, instruments, and other similar musical materials and equipment.

If we don't reach our full goal, the money will be used to buy one couch, or saved until we have enough to purchase what we need.  Your contribution will be used for this purpose regardless of whether we make our goal this time around.

Thank you for supporting this project and for helping to provide a unique and comfortable work space for students at OHS!

story:
What is the BLOC BUILDER Fund ?

The Dream Defenders are raising $35,000 with the #blocbuilder fund to get the extra push our Bloc is Ours Program needs throughout the summer to amplify our impact, get out the vote in Florida and change lives in our communities.

A year ago -- on July 16, 2013 -- we took over the Florida Capitol to let the elected leadership of the state know that we mean business. This year, we're going to VOTE and we're bringing the people of FL with us to the polls.

A breakdown of how we plan to use the funds is below:


You Donate - We Swag You Out. 
Check out our exclusive perks:



Who Are the Dream Defenders ?

The Dream Defenders develop the next generation of revolutionaries to realize and exercise their independent power;  organizing to disrupt the systems that oppress our communities. 

  • We're roses that have grown through the concrete committed to making sure that the next generation bears a field of wildflowers. 
  • We're a statewide organization in Florida a little over two years old, that is led by Black and Brown youth.
  • Our organization lives through the 9 chapters that we have in key counties all throughout Florida.  We are about building and growing on college campuses and in our communities.
  • A lot of people heard about us last year after George Zimmerman was found "not-guilty" and we occupied and took over the State Capitol in Florida for 31-days and 30-nights straight.

We're serious, and we're here to stay.  We have a plan to continue building power in Florida throughout the summer, make a strong showing at the polls with our communities during the election in November, and move boldy into the Fall.




What is The Bloc is Ours ?

The BLOC IS OURS is Dream Defenders’ current field program, based in on-the-ground organizing by young people of color across Florida.

  • Fourteen field fellows (above) around the state are collectively creating a new model for educating and activating youth of color in election years; creating a permanent infrastructure of trained leaders who can move not just to vote, but to vote around issues and towards community building.
  • BLOC leaders are leading local Freedom Schools across Florida in lead up to the 2014 election on voter awareness and various issues relevant to communities of color in the state.
  • The program is firmly rooted in leadership development and the training of youth - at their college campuses, and in their communities.
  • Dream Defenders believe that collectively we can build a statewide voting BLOC with the power to influence the trajectory of Florida’s politics, and work on issue-based campaigns that improve the lives of black and brown and low income Floridians in between election years. 

    Find out more about the Bloc is Ours Program 


    Share This Campaign w/ Your Network

      Not only do we stand on the shoulders of giants in the organizing work that we do, but we are lifted up daily by our supporters.  

      We thank you for the contribution that you have made and would love for you to share this campaign.

      Use the buttons below to share with the folks in your social networks or use the following link:  http://bit.ly/blocbuilder

      Contact Us

      We are happy to answer any questions that you have about Dream Defenders, The BlocBuilder Fund, the Bloc is Ours program, and anything else you can think of.

      Feel free to reach out to us at: peacemedia@dreamdefenders.org


      * Funds raised as a part of this campaign are considered unrestricted gifts and will be used where needed most to support the BLOC is OURS initiative and the mission of the Dream Defenders *

story:
To End The War On Drugs - A Guide for Politicians, the Press and Public

As the Government takes their summer hiatus, we want to hand deliver a copy of this book to President Obama, every US Senator and Representative, all 9 Justices of the Supreme Court and mail copies to all 50 US Governors. 

I wrote/compiled this book to feature the thoughts of 115 experts on drug prohibition who have been guests on the Pacifica radio shows Cultural Baggage and Century of
Lies

Guests range from Michelle Alexander to Kevin Zeese.  A full list of those in the book is available at www.endthedrugwar.us.  Along the way we hear from reform leaders like Rob Kampia, Ethan Nadelmann, Joy Stickland and Keith Stroup.  We get the thoughts of criminal justice officials including former prosecutor  James Gierach, LEAP Director Neill Franklin, Jack Cole, Judge Elanor Schockett and Judge James Gray.  We have a chapter featuring Dr. Donald Tashkin of NIDA as well as Dr. Donald Abrams, Dr.Mitch Earlywine and Dr. Robert Melamede. 

With chapters on the prison industrial complex, hypocrisy of drug prohibition, politicians against prohibition, parents against prohibition, authors and pundits against prohibition, asset forfeiture,  international violence of the drug war and religious leaders against the drug war, this book is a scathing indictment of the war on drugs.

This book is about you, us, our reach towards ending this horrendous drug war.  When Eric Holder read his copy, he then forwarded it to the DEA to educate them as well.  This book would not exist without ARO, DPA, LEAP, the Baker Institute, DPFT, MPP, NORML and scores of other organizations and individuals who stepped up to the plate and took mighty swings at the logic of drug war.

We can use your help.  We will go to Washington DC and hand deliver nearly 600 copies of To End The War on Drugs – A Guide for Politicians, the Press and Public as soon as possible, likely around June 1, 2014.  This will be our "summer reading assignment" for these officials.  Once back in session, we will pull no punches regarding those who still choose to dismiss public safety by  still believing in drug war

We would like to include a “sign on” letter from your organization with each copy of the book that can include contact names, address and email.

The cost to print, ship to our offices to attach individual letters for each elected official will be approximately $10 per book.  435 Representatives, 100 Senators, the President and 50 US Governors gives a total of 586 books.  585 X 10 = $5,860.00 needed to deliver these books.

We have in mind to contact all news teams in Houston area, capture scenes of three generations of our family printing, labeling, stuffing and prepping the books for shipment.  We will put these scenes on flash drives to give reporters when we hold our press conference in D.C.  Thus far we have the support of the James A. Baker III Institute for Public Policy and Law Enforcement Against Prohibition.

We have 3 levels of participation:

Level 1, $1,000 or more - you can send a full sheet of information about your efforts

Level 2,  $500 – 999 - you can send a half sheet of information

Level 3,  $100 – 499, Your organization and info will be included on a compilation sheet.

We welcome pledges of any amount.

story:
Hie, I’m Emmanuel,  I’m going to be the new principal of a school.. Imagine, how cool that is..

Now, let’s get right into my story. I’m a freelance web designer and technician.. In the beginning of this year, I took a trip to Sodwana Bay, in Kwazulu Natal and also went through a place called Mbazwana where the interesting part started..

Let me tell you about Sodwana Bay first, this place has got a beautiful beach with lots of scenery, but that’s not what captured my attention, you see, the literacy rate in this place is so low that I could not believe it , I’m from Johannesburg,  the city of gold where they is everything at your fingertips (and everyone can speak English , in this place, there is almost close to nothing , it’s a small rural town in the middle of nowhere (not exactly) .. Take a look at Sodwana bay itself here 

My mission here is to educate .. Now, I teamed up with several friends from Johannesburg and we all came down here.. we hunted for a place to start our little venture and after speaking to the wonderful Mayor of Mbazwana , Mr Ncube , he gave us a place behind the library, that was used as a school before but was abandoned (or so I think) ..


What exactly are we going to be teaching here ? 

We took a good look around the local town and surrounding areas and realized that most people around here were ranging from ages  20 - 40 on average had either not made it to Grade 12 or failed ... This is where we came to a conclusion where the school will be a Matric finishing school .. 

We will be giving those who either never made it to Grade 12 or those who wish to re-write their grade 12 and also we are going to include a computer school with subjects starting from Introduction to computers (for the beginners  going all the way to advanced computing .. 


How will it help the community ?

Take a look at it from this angle , in South Africa, without a Grade 12 or any computer knowledge chances are slim (very very small, think about ameoba proteus small) that you will either get a job or pretty much do anything after that, and we are not even talking about college or university here because there is a minimum pass rate for that .. 

So in short, our school will be a bridge to those that never made it .. Giving them the second chance to go try again and aim higher ..

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What we did here 

The place was in ruins, so we cleaned it up and turned it into what now looks like a school.. Now the problem is, we have exhausted all our savings that we put on this because we never imagined that starting a school can cost so much (so much for raising a building from the ruins)...

Why only $5000 ? Isn't that too little ?

Well, as a matter of fact, if this whole project was depending on $5000 it was not going to be accomplished ..

As for the "why" part , after doing all the math (thanks to our Mathematician , she is good in numbers) we realized that in order to jump the finish line ( we almost there, but stuck at the moment) , we are only short about $5000 that roughly translates to ZAR 53 000 in South African currency ..

You Sure ? : Yes we are sure .. 100% Sure

Now this is the part where we need your help ….

As you can see from the pictures the classes are basically empty, we have managed to purchase several computers, a number of plastic chairs & desks (basically what we all could afford) but that is not enough to get the school running.

We still have a long way to go as we still need to get more cement, windows, stationery, printing equipment and the list is endless..

The local community has welcomed us with open arms and has even thrown in a Rand or two into the project which was awesome …

Now here is the question…

Will you help us?

What exactly are we going to be teaching here ? We took a good look around the local town and surrounding areas and realized that most people around here were ranging from ages  20 - 40 on average had either not made it to Grade 12 or failed ... This is where we came to a conclusion where the school will be a Matric finishing school .. We will be giving those who either never made it to Grade 12 or those who wish to re-write their grade 12 and also we are going to include a computer school with subjects starting from Introduction to computers (for the beginners  going all the way to advanced computing ..  How will it help the community ? Take a look at it from this angle , in South Africa, without a Grade 12 or any computer knowledge chances are slim (very very small, think about ameoba proteus small) that you will either get a job or pretty much do anything after that, and we are not even talking about college or university here because there is a minimum pass rate for that .. So in short, our school will be a bridge to those that never made it .. Giving them the second chance to go try again and aim higher .. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------What we did here 
The
place was in ruins, so we cleaned it up and turned it into what now looks like
a school.. Now the problem is, we have exhausted all our savings that we put on
this because we never imagined that starting a school can cost so much (so much
for raising a building from the ruins)...Why only $5000 ? Isn't that too little ? Well, as a matter of fact, if this whole project was depending on $5000 it was not going to be accomplished ..As for the "why" part , after doing all the math (thanks to our Mathematician , she is good in numbers) we realized that in order to jump the finish line ( we almost there, but stuck at the moment) , we are only short about $5000 that roughly translates to ZAR 53 000 in South African currency .. You Sure ? : Yes we are sure .. 100% Sure 
Now this
is the part where we need your help …. 
As
you can see from the pictures the classes are basically empty, we have managed
to purchase several computers, a number of plastic chairs & desks
(basically what we all could afford) but that is not enough to get the school running.

We
still have a long way to go as we still need to get more cement, windows, stationery, printing equipment
and the list is endless.. 
The
local community has welcomed us with open arms and has even thrown in a Rand or
two into the project which was awesome … 
Now
here is the question… 
Will
you help us?

story:
My Road to Becoming an International Election Observer

Having volunteered at home and abroad for a variety of organizations, from soup kitchens to wildlife rescue stations, I am always looking for new ways to make a positive impact on the world around me. I was recently referred by a local human rights group to an organization focused on social and economic justice in El Salvador.  Centro de Intercambio y Solidaridad (Center for Exchange and Solidarity) has since accepted my application to join an international delegation that will monitor the 2nd round of presidential elections on March 9th, and will train me for this new and challenging role. The position calls for me to "observe and provide witness to the electoral process and to potential violations of the electoral code" and "to provide a presence in order to reduce political intimidation and violence."  In addition to my formal duties, I will learn about El Salvador's history, culture, and political system while also meeting with various civic groups and other organizations. Apart from my main objective of contributing to transparent, safe, and fair elections, I also view this experience as a chance to gain greater mutual understanding between the people of two nations with a complex political history and ongoing economic ties. 


Why I Need Your Help

I work in the non-profit sector for my day job, and will be using my vacation days to do this instead of sunning myself on a tropical beach as any reasonable person experiencing this historically harsh Cleveland winter might do. The costs associated with my air fare, observer training, basic lodging, etc. are not insignificant. I am draining my meager savings to do this, but a co-worker sparked the idea of running this campaign to defray some of the expense.

I know that many people have too many obligations in their life to just take off and fly to another country, especially with only a couple weeks notice.  However, my hope is that many of those people will nevertheless see value in what I am doing and share my concern for the rights of citizens in every country to determine their own course in fair elections. It is my further hope that perhaps some of these generous friends, co-workers, acquaintances, and bighearted strangers might happily help a schlub like me to try and make a difference, and by extension, be making a difference themselves.

story:
Short Summary

Hand in Hand started out as a project under the American University of Beirut, this project was initiated by two Syrian students who felt like the needs of the refugee population could no longer be ignored. As such and since November 2012, we have been assisting Syrian refugees in Lebanon through various ways. We started out by delivering food baskets, clothes and blankets, soon after we started distributing toys to children on Christmas, we also implemented several projects with other NGOs. However, today we realized that our ideals and dreams need us to be more formal and more keen on our work, therefore we decided to register hand in hand and implement projects on bigger scales. The project we want to get funded is about opening a children community center in one of Lebanon's poorest areas. This community center will give children a space to socialize, learn, and have fun during these challenging times. 

What makes us special?

We are students who want to change the treatment that Syrian refugees receive in Lebanon. We believe that although we are students and young professionals, we are not better than those refugees that fled their homes, they deserve all the attention they can ger. They deserve to be empowered, to be taught how to love one another so that one day in the near future they can go back home as one. We are not affiliated with any political or religious organization, we work on our own with students and other refugees to make their lives more bearable under such bad conditions. We are special because we don't depend on staff and workers to implement change, on the contrary we urge students and refugees to bring on change.

Details about the community center:

Refugee children are staying at home or playing on dangerous streets, this is an issue that many refugees are facing and as such must be handled by NGOs. By opening a community center in Shatila Hand in Hand will be giving these children a safe and monitored place for them to play, socialize and learn.

•  HiH will open a center in Shatilla for the children. This center will have 2-3 rooms.

•  One TV and social room, in which children can watch cartoons and play video games as well as socialize with their friends

•  One activity room, in which children will play with puzzles, Legos, draw, paint on ceramic, etc…

•  One room to serve as a library, in which children can find countless children stories as well as educational books.

•  Moreover, several English workshops will take place to improve the children’s English communication skills.

•  Additionally a computer will be installed in the library with internet access, to allow kids to explore the internet as well as build some computer skills.

•  Furthermore, kids aged 14 and above will be provided with personality and skill test to guide them on possible educational and vocational paths. This can be done in assistance with the UNRWA’s Career Guidance Unit.

•  Children registered at the center will go on a bi-monthly field trip to museums, parks, swimming pools and maybe AUB for a fun day.

•  Approximate budget for the center is:

•  $500-800 rent for the center per month

•  $500 salary for a full time Syrian refugee staff woman who will handle cleaning and some children activities, moreover, she will have a place to sleep in at the center.

•  $1000-3000 rehabilitation and supplies: books, toys, TV, Computer, tables, chairs, light, and everything else required for rehabilitating the center.

•  Total: $1800- 4500

story:
If you’ve gotten to this page, you likely received a letter, email or Facebook link directing you here.  Thanks for getting this far! 

I’ve set up this crowd-funding campaign to ask for your support in helping me attend a six-month leadership program through the Institute for Compassionate Leadership (ICL), a non-profit organization whose mission is to train compassionate leaders who want to have an impact in the world.  I was recently accepted to this program and look forward to participating in it.

If that’s enough information – feel free to click the “Contribute Now” button.  Want to know more?  Some background and more information on this training is below…..

Some Background, Or How I Found Myself Here

As many of you know, I am currently taking a sabbatical and living in Montréal.  I am so fortunate to have so many people be supportive of this endeavor.

Just before leaving Philadelphia, I came across information about the Institute for Compassionate Leadership.  I felt completely in-sync with its mission and wanted to participate in its leadership development program.  But, with my train departing in less than a week, the timing was not ideal; perhaps it was something to consider upon my return home.  Last month some auspicious timing changed those plans.... 

I spent two weeks in June at a meditation retreat in rural Nova Scotia.  I camped in a tent, woke up every day at 5:30a.m. (OK, maybe that didn’t happen every day!) and met about 50 wonderful people from all over the world.  In separate conversations, a few people mentioned ICL and thought it would be a great match for me.  I made a mental note to pull out the information I had collected a bit sooner than originally planned. 

Before I got a chance to do this, however, someone I met at the meditation retreat told me that ICL was looking to fill an open spot in its upcoming class.  I could not ignore this synchronicity – within a week, I spoke with Lodro Rinzler (ICL’s Executive Director), wrote several essays and submitted my application.  Soon after, I was accepted into the program.  I can’t wait to get started!


“The bad news is you’re falling through the air, nothing to hang on to, no parachute.  The good news is there’s no ground.”  -- Chögyam Trungpa Rinpoche


But Wait, You Don’t Know What You Want To Do Next, Do You?

Well, the short answer is:  No, I don’t. 

At the same time, my experience at the meditation retreat helped a great deal.  One of the (many) things I got out of the retreat was insight into my natural ability and talent for mentoring others.

While it’s true that I’m still not sure what the next chapter of my life and career holds, I do want to further develop and utilize my mentoring, presentation and interpersonal skills to benefit others.  A return to my prior job is not off the table; I can return with a new perspective and approach that can be of benefit to my colleagues and our clients.  What I want to focus on now is not what work I may next do, but rather, what kind of person I want to be. 


This All Sounds Good, But Tell Me More About ICL

The Institute for Compassionate Leadership is a non-profit organization dedicated to developing authentic and compassionate leaders who want to figure out how to help others and have an impact in the world.  The six-month leadership program is taught by a first-rate faculty, who are accomplished leaders and entrepreneurs in political, business and social justice issues.  In addition, I will receive executive-level coaching, mentoring and networking opportunities.  For more information, check out its website here:  http://instituteforcompassionateleadership.org/

Awesome!  How Can I Support You?

I’m glad you asked!

The tuition for the ICL program is $7,500 and I’m estimating costs of $1,500 for travel between Montréal and New York City for several weekend retreats that are part of the course.  I am able to contribute $2,000 towards this amount and am, therefore, looking to raise the remaining $7,000 through this crowd-funding campaign. 

All contributions made through this campaign page are will be directed through the Interdependence Project, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, and are tax-deductible.  If I don’t reach the campaign goal, I’ll apply whatever amounts I receive towards the program tuition. 

Whether you’re family, a friend, a fraternity Brother, a work colleague, a fellow Shambhala practitioner or a Facebook acquaintance, you are all important to me and part of my life.  I hope you’ll consider making a donation to this campaign.  And if you cannot make a financial contribution, encouraging emails are also very welcome.  (Email me at: mjs223@cornell.edu.)

Thank you for reading this far.  And thank you for your support for me in this effort.

-- Marc

story:
Hope is the belief that something good may happen.

Hope is fundamentally what drives us all. Our mission is to build a center of hope...hope for inclusion, hope for acceptance, hope for resources, hope for friends, hope for better futures for our children and families with Autism and special needs.

Each supporter and each donation is one step closer to a safe, accepting, and encouraging place for our loved ones with Autism and special needs to shine and be supported. Join us in our mission to open our "center of hope" for thousands of children and young adults in the Lehigh Valley! Help us spread the word and make some noise for this desperately needed center.

Check out our website: www.livelearnandplay.org

**OUR CHALLENGE** 

To raise $50,000 by April 15th in order to secure a location for our center!

We have raised a total of $46,295.96 in the last 6 months, we need to reach our goal of $96,000 by April 15th in order to secure the space. $50,000 more to go...We're almost halfway there!! Help us boost some donations by sharing and helping us spread the word!

Our Story

The Live Learn & Play concept was formed in December 2009 after Jill VanKuren, a professional in the field, grew frustrated with the lack of (and non-existence of) resources, activities, and just fun places in general to recommend to families with Autism and special needs. There was a huge need for a place of acceptance for kids of all ability levels, a place for resources for families and professionals, and a place for parents to come and just be able to relax. She created the concept that became Live Learn & Play. Investors took on the concept and opened a center which closed due to unrelated financial problems of the investors. Because of the overwhelming community support and love for Live Learn & Play, it was established as a 501c3 non-profit organization officially in September 2012. We are raising funds to continue our mission and re-open this amazing center for our families. We are VERY close to reaching our goal! :)

Sections of the Center & Key Features:

  • Multisensory Play Center- bounce house, obstacle course, swings, ball pit, multisensory playhouse, quiet area, interactive spaces

  • Classes for kids and adults- music, art, dance, yoga, healthy cooking, drum circles, Zumba, support groups, social groups

  • Resource Center- for families and professionals to network, find information on services/programs in the community, featuring guest speakers and educational programs/seminars/conferences

  • Product Section- for sensory integration and therapeutic supplies that are currently only found in catalogs (very hard to get an accurate feel for the product before purchasing)

  • Toy Exchange program- will allow parents to exchange gently used sensory or therapeutic toys ("give a penny, take a penny" concept)

  • Mild Hyperbaric Therapy Center- opportunity to take advantage of this therapy that has been showing amazing results with various conditions (Autism, Traumatic Brain Injury, Cerebral Palsy, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, injuries, inflammation, etc).

What We Need & What You Get

The breakdown...

  • We need: $50,000 to secure a 7,000+ square foot space to develop our center

  • We have developed a great list of perks for our supporters! If you have any great, creative ideas, please share with us on our facebook page!

  • In the chance we don't reach our goal, here's where the money will go:
  • up to $5,000- development of Live Learn & Play weekends (small equipment purchases)
  • $5,000-$10,000- Bounce House purchase
  • $10,000-$20,000- Inflatable obstacle course purchase
  • $20,000-$30,000- Mild hyperbaric chamber purchase
  • $30,000-$49,999- Small office for family services and resources

  • $50,000+ - Full 7,000sq foot space for the center

The Impact

Your contribution and the impact of this center will be life-changing for thousands of kids and individuals in our community. Here are a few of our parent testimonials to better explain:

  • “I just had my son's 4th birthday at Live Learn & Play. I usually try and avoid taking him out in public due to his Autism and ADHD. But his 4th birthday was awesome!! He was able to play, have fun and just be himself! I didn't have to worry about explaining to typical children's parents why my son acts the way he does or apologize to them for my son doing something to their child. I got to meet other parents that are going through the same struggle my family is. It is a wonderful place and there is no place around here that even closely compares to Live Learn and Play. This is the perfect, safe environment for children like my son and we are so thankful we finally have a place to go and play.”- Nicole F. (June 2012)

  • “Unless you are a parent of a child with special needs, it is nearly impossible to describe the feeling when one finds a warm and accepting haven like Live, Learn & Play. The freedom to let our kids be who they are without worry or judgment is a precious gift, and their (and our) smiles speak more than words ever could. Live, Learn & Play is an invaluable addition to the Allentown community.”- Deb H. (July 2012)

  • “Live Learn & Play is a great resource for both my son with autism & my daughter who is neurotypical. They both enjoy attending open play times! It is wonderful to have a place that is welcoming, accepting, and understanding of my son's needs and behaviors. And my daughter enjoys playing there so much that she requested to have her upcoming birthday at LL&P. I love having an inclusive community resource that works so well for both of them!”- Tracy B. (July 2012)

  • “Bottom Line--there are places to play in the valley; there are places for therapy in the valley. But there is NO PLACE where my kids can engage in therapeutic play in a safe, encouraging environment. There is NO PLACE where I know my kids can be kids and I can turn my head and not wonder what might happen. There is NO PLACE where I can feel safe letting my daughter be herself without the stares and awkward moments from other parents. Thank you LLP for taking the risk and opening! Thank you for being here.”- Christa H. (June 2012)

  • “My daughter is 3 and is in the autism spectrum. She has a speech delay and sensory issues. After only a few weeks of attending the summer program at Live Learn & Play, we notice she is saying a lot more words and is more social. There's no other place in the area where she can interact with other kids while being exposed to sensory play.  And she loves it - when I drop her off she runs into the building and the other kids hug her when they see her!”- Nicole B. (June 2012)

  • “I can not live without Live Learn & Play! Though my constant request to just move in with my children is denied, we return on a regular basis for open play. I am the mother of 2 sons on the Autism spectrum ages 6 and 5. My 6 year old is high functioning and has ADHD as well. LLP provides a safe and understanding environment where he can run to his heart's content. I don't need to worry about him hurting himself when he falls (and he ALWAYS falls) because they were mindful enough to provide a play area with a padded floor. The staff is knowledgeable on the condition of Autism and other special needs. They go the extra mile for our special children. My younger son is non verbal and prone to aggressive meltdowns, and sometimes bangs his head. I am extra grateful for the padded floors when it comes to him! Because there are other families present living with special needs, we don't become a spectacle when negative behaviors happen. For example, if I was at a McDonald's play place, my son could bust his head wide open on the floor.....while the parents stand around judging how my bad child is a product of my bad parenting. The average typical family is clueless of our challenges. I am comforted by how supportive and helpful the staff and parents are and how quickly they come to help. It is an unspoken "rule" amongst us to help each other. Everything about LLP is wonderful. I finally have a place to take my kids to play! A place like this is long overdue.”- Charissa T. (July 2012)


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't Contribute? Not to worry...here are some great ways to show your support and help us spread the word:

  • Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, other social media, and email
  • Save the image below and use it as your profile pic until 4/15 to help spread awareness for our cause. When your friends/family ask about it, share the link to our campaign.
  • Volunteer- we have a few awesome events coming up and could always use some extra help!

The Live Learn & Play concept was formed in December 2009 after Jill VanKuren, a professional in the field, grew frustrated with the lack of (and non-existence of) resources, activities, and just fun places in general to recommend to families with Autism and special needs. There was a huge need for a place of acceptance for kids of all ability levels, a place for resources for families and professionals, and a place for parents to come and just be able to relax. She created the concept that became Live Learn & Play. Investors took on the concept and opened a center which closed due to unrelated financial problems of the investors. Because of the overwhelming community support and love for Live Learn & Play, it was established as a 501c3 non-profit organization officially in September 2012. We are raising funds to continue our mission and re-open this amazing center for our families. We are VERY close to reaching our goal! :)Sections of the Center & Key Features:
Multisensory Play Center- bounce house, obstacle course, swings, ball pit, multisensory playhouse, quiet area, interactive spaces

Classes for kids and adults- music, art, dance, yoga, healthy cooking, drum circles, Zumba, support groups, social groups

Resource Center- for families and professionals to network, find information on services/programs in the community, featuring guest speakers and educational programs/seminars/conferences

Product Section- for sensory integration and therapeutic supplies that are currently only found in catalogs (very hard to get an accurate feel for the product before purchasing)

Toy Exchange program- will allow parents to exchange gently used sensory or therapeutic toys ("give a penny, take a penny" concept)

Mild Hyperbaric Therapy Center- opportunity to take advantage of this therapy that has been showing amazing results with various conditions (Autism, Traumatic Brain Injury, Cerebral Palsy, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, injuries, inflammation, etc).

What We Need & What You GetThe breakdown...
We need: $50,000 to secure a 7,000+ square foot space to develop our center

We have developed a great list of perks for our supporters! If you have any great, creative ideas, please share with us on our facebook page!

In the chance we don't reach our goal, here's where the money will go:
up to $5,000- development of Live Learn & Play weekends (small equipment purchases)

$5,000-$10,000- Bounce House purchase

$10,000-$20,000- Inflatable obstacle course purchase

$20,000-$30,000- Mild hyperbaric chamber purchase

$30,000-$49,999- Small office for family services and resources

$50,000+ - Full 7,000sq foot space for the center

The ImpactYour contribution and the impact of this center will be life-changing for thousands of kids and individuals in our community. Here are a few of our parent testimonials to better explain:
“I just had my son's 4th birthday at Live Learn 
& Play. I usually try and avoid taking him out in public due to his 
Autism and ADHD. But his 4th birthday was awesome!! He was able to play,
 have fun and just be himself! I didn't have to worry about explaining 
to typical children's parents why my son acts the way he does or 
apologize to them for my son doing something to their child. I got to 
meet other parents that are going through the same struggle my family 
is. It is a wonderful place and there is no place around here that even 
closely compares to Live Learn and Play. This is the perfect, safe 
environment for children like my son and we are so thankful we finally 
have a place to go and play.”- Nicole F. (June 2012)



“Unless
 you are a parent of a child with special needs, it is nearly impossible
 to describe the feeling when one finds a warm and accepting haven like 
Live, Learn & Play. The freedom to let our kids be who they are 
without worry or judgment is a precious gift, and their (and our) smiles
 speak more than words ever could. Live, Learn & Play is an 
invaluable addition to the Allentown community.”- Deb H. (July 2012)




“Live
 Learn & Play is a great resource for both my son with autism & 
my daughter who is neurotypical. They both enjoy attending open play 
times! It is wonderful to have a place that is welcoming, accepting, and
 understanding of my son's needs and behaviors. And my daughter enjoys 
playing there so much that she requested to have her upcoming birthday 
at LL&P. I love having an inclusive community resource that works so
 well for both of them!”- Tracy B. (July 2012)






“Bottom
 Line--there are places to play in the valley; there are places for 
therapy in the valley. But there is NO PLACE where my kids can engage in
 therapeutic play in a safe, encouraging environment. There is NO PLACE 
where I know my kids can be kids and I can turn my head and not wonder 
what might happen. There is NO PLACE where I can feel safe letting my 
daughter be herself without the stares and awkward moments from other 
parents. Thank you LLP for taking the risk and opening! Thank you for 
being here.”- Christa H. (June 2012)










“My
 daughter is 3 and is in the autism spectrum. She has a speech delay and
 sensory issues. After only a few weeks of attending the summer program 
at Live Learn & Play, we notice she is saying a lot more words and 
is more social. There's no other place in the area where she can 
interact with other kids while being exposed to sensory play.  And she 
loves it - when I drop her off she runs into the building and the other 
kids hug her when they see her!”- Nicole B. (June 2012)















“I
 can not live without Live Learn & Play! Though my constant request 
to just move in with my children is denied, we return on a regular basis
 for open play. I am the mother of 2 sons on the Autism spectrum ages 6 
and 5. My 6 year old is high functioning and has ADHD as well. LLP 
provides a safe and understanding environment where he can run to his 
heart's content. I don't need to worry about him hurting himself when he
 falls (and he ALWAYS falls) because they were mindful enough to provide
 a play area with a padded floor. The staff is knowledgeable on the 
condition of Autism and other special needs. They go the extra mile for 
our special children. My younger son is non verbal and prone to 
aggressive meltdowns, and sometimes bangs his head. I am extra grateful 
for the padded floors when it comes to him! Because there are other 
families present living with special needs, we don't become a spectacle 
when negative behaviors happen. For example, if I was at a McDonald's 
play place, my son could bust his head wide open on the floor.....while 
the parents stand around judging how my bad child is a product of my bad
 parenting. The average typical family is clueless of our challenges. I 
am comforted by how supportive and helpful the staff and parents are and
 how quickly they come to help. It is an unspoken "rule" amongst us to 
help each other. Everything about LLP is wonderful. I finally have a 
place to take my kids to play! A place like this is long overdue.”- Charissa T. (July 2012)









Other Ways You Can HelpCan't Contribute? Not to worry...here are some great ways to show your support and help us spread the word:
Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, other social media, and email

Save the image below and use it as your profile pic until 4/15 to help spread awareness for our cause. When your friends/family ask about it, share the link to our campaign.
Volunteer- we have a few awesome events coming up and could always use some extra help!

story:
Short Summary

What is Matthew House Ottawa: Refugee Services? We are part of a growing network founded to help refugee claimants by providing a place to live while they attempt to build a future in Canada. Matthew House Ottawa: Refugee Services is able to provide short-term accommodation for up to 10 refugee claimants along with assistance in settling into life in Ottawa. Our goal is to connect a large range of services to refugee claimants who seek our assistance. We are not just a transient place to live but a real home supported by caring individuals; a place where people can know they are among friends and feel at peace.

We want to take our residents the Carp Fair to give them a typical Canadian experience! There will be a lot of Canadian culture, food, agriculture as well as a bunch of rides and games that the residents can try and experience.  

Your contributions will be greatly appreciated by not only the refugees themselves but also Matthew House Ottawa: Refugee Services staff and volunteers; they will never forget this amazing, Canadian experience!

What We Need & What You Get

We need money to help cover the costs of admission, food, ride tickets and gas for our resident refugees at Matthew House Ottawa: Refugee Services but also for a couple volunteers to come along to drive and help co-ordinate the outing.

GOAL: $900  

What your contributions can do!:

  • $30 CAN      Food for the fair!- Provide 1 refugee with lunch & dinner                           at the fair.
  • $35 CAN       Volunteer love- Provide 1 volunteer with                                       admission, some snacks & a couple of rides at the fair.
  • $40 CAN      Rides for Refugees-  Give 3 refugees the opportunity to                             go on 10 rides each!
  • $55 CAN       Share a Canadian Experience- Provide 1 refugee with                                 admission, lunch, dinner & some rides at the fair. 
  • $175 CAN      We LOVE volunteers!-This will provide all of our volunteers with                              admission, some snacks & a few rides at the fair. Volunteers are                            VERY important & this trip cannot happen without them!
  • $605 CAN     A Canadian Experience for all of our MHO residents!-This will                              provide ALL of our residents  with admission, lunch & dinner as                                well as some ride tickets. 
Website & Credit Card Fees: The fees for using a credit card fluctuate depending on how much we raise. Credit card fees range from $27-$45 If we reach our goal (we will) our website fees will be $36 & if we don't reach our goal, they will be $81. 

PERKS!!!

  • $50 CAN       Blessings & appreciation!- We will create your own personal shout-out on our Matthew House Ottawa Facebook page to thank you personally for your kind support.  Send us your twitter handle and we'll make you a twitter celebrity!
If we do not reach our goal, the funds will still go towards the fair but we might not be able to take all of our residents or we might not be able to purchase any ride tickets. It will deeply affect this outing so we will would love it if you could help us make it possible to reach our goal!
The Impact

Our residents at Matthew House Ottawa: Refugee Services have many incredibly stressful and pressure-making things to do in the first few months of arriving in Canada. This would be none other than a great Canadian experience for them but also a day where they can let loose, have fun, smile & enjoy themselves!

    Risks & Challenges

    There are always risk & challenges in any fundraising opportunity. To overcome some of these risks and challenges we have picked the flexible funding model which guarantees we get money to go to the fair either way. This may mean the residents may not get to go on any rides, it also may mean some residents may not even get to come. Therefore we really would love your support in helping us take all of our residents to the fair!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you cannot contribute monetarily, the second best way to contribute is to get the word out there and make some noise about our campaign. Tell everyone, even if they are out of province, state, country, etc, every little bit will help!
