This may mean the residents may not get to go on any rides, it also may mean some residents may not even get to come. Therefore we really would love your support in helping us take all of our residents to the fair!

  Other Ways You Can Help If you cannot contribute monetarily, the second best way to contribute is to get the word out there and make some noise about our campaign. Tell everyone, even if they are out of province, state, country, etc, every little bit will help!

story:
The legal action to stop the destruction of Peter Cooper's free college is being waged by a coalition of faculty, alumni, and students—joined by a broad community that is angered at the injustice of 155 years of free tuition ending in order to fund wasteful administrative bloat, misguided empire building, and questionable fiscal practices.

Life or Death for Cooper Union

Cooper Union receives income of over $20 million a year because of a tax exemption on commercial property owned by the school that was granted because the NY State Legislature believed that Cooper Union's free school, although private, was operating for the public's good. This tax exemption is essential to the Cooper Union’s survival.   The imposition of tuition by the Board of Trustees jeopardizes this tax exemption, which is worth far more than what their tuition scheme brings in. 

“The tax benefits that have accrued to Cooper Union are based on maintaining the mandate for free tuition. It is critical to the future access to higher education for deserving students that that commitment be maintained."

-- State Assemblywoman Deborah Glick 

"What's at stake here is if the free tuition is scrapped, then we in the legislature have to reconsider, I think, our position in affording a property tax break to Cooper Union. Let's be clear, no other private institution in New York currently receives such a tax break…"

-- State Senator Brad Hoylman

Just as the State legislature had the power to provide Peter Cooper with a massive tax subsidy to promote his vision of free education, it has the power to take it away.

The Cooper Union Board of Trustees has pursued the reckless course of charging tuition, thus endangering the very existence of the school. They should have worked with the dedicated community of faculty, alumni, and students to scale back runaway administrative spending and get Cooper Union back to a prudent course of living within its means as outlined in the Working Group plan. 

We have no choice but to continue legal action as they have rejected all alternative paths (including Trustee Jeffrey Gural’s offer to donate up to $2,000,000 to buy time to refine an alternative approach.) Please help!

Powerful Allies

We have gained powerful allies as the facts have come out, including State Senator Brad Hoylman and State Assembly member Deborah Glick (Chair of the Higher Education Committee). The Daily News, NY Post, NY Times, and PIX Ch. 11 News have taken notice and amplified our voice. Andrew Rossi's documentary, Ivory Tower, featured our struggle and explained how it is part of a larger national crisis in higher education where tuition costs and student debt are spiraling out of control. We need your help to sustain our efforts and preserve free education at Cooper Union for future generations.
(Video below includes footage of Senator Hoylman speaking at our press event.)


Round 1 (completed)

We spent $230,000 for legal fees, much of it raised here, that took us through the critical hearing last month with Justice Bannon of the NY State Supreme Court. We hope, based on the strength of our petition and oral arguments, that she will: reverse the imposition of tuition; remove errant Board members; order formation of The Associates of Cooper Union (as called for in the Trust); and begin an audit of the school's finances. But even then, we must continue to fund the legal effort.

Round 2: Our goal is to raise at least $100,000 for the second round of legal action.

If Justice Bannon rules for The Committee to Save Cooper Union we must be prepared to defend that decision against appeal (and if she rules against, we will mount an appeal). We don't know when her ruling will come down, so therefore time is of the essence. Whatever the outcome, it is almost certain that a final, binding decision will require additional steps. Thanks to a generous $25,000 donation from Cooper alum Adam Forbes, we are off to an excellent start - the remaining goal is $75,000. We need your continued support and faith in the true Cooper Union for what might be a protracted legal battle. We should take heed from Lincoln’s own words in Cooper Union's Great Hall on February 27, 1860 - "Let us have faith that right makes might, and in that faith, let us, to the end, dare to do our duty as we understand it."



    Fundraising Information

    • This "Appeal" Indiegogo campaign is part of the Phase 2 of our fundraising as discussed in our first Indiegogo campaign.
    • So far our legal fee expenditures have been: $50,000 for the initial petition and $180,000 for subsequent petitions and representation through the hearing, for a total of $230,000 in legal fees. The fixed fee arrangements we negotiated with our attorneys have resulted in a substantial discount to their normal hourly rates. We have other costs as well, including expenses such as our public relations firm, which has helped us generate support for our cause.
    • All members and officers of Committee to Save Cooper Union have put in their time and efforts on an unpaid volunteer basis.
    • We will still need to raise additional funds to complete our action and are working on other fundraising initiatives.
    • Regarding tax deductibility of donations: Committee to Save Cooper Union is a non-profit corporation, but we don't yet have 501c3 status for tax deductibility. We are working on a fiscal sponsorship arrangement which would enable tax deductibility for certain donations. Please contact us for issues related to this.
    • If our goal of preserving a free tuition Cooper Union is achieved, any remaining funds will be donated back to Cooper Union. If the goal is not achieved, any remaining funds will be donated to a worthy educational cause.

    New Perks

    We have some original new perks to show our appreciation for your donations:

    $50 - Save Cooper Union Embroidered Iron-On Patch (approx. 3" diameter)
    The hour is fast approaching! Peter Cooper's Foundation Building clock.

    $75 - Peter Cooper's Gelatine Totebag (15"w x 16"h with 22" long handles)
    A 19th century design replicated from the box top of an original package of Peter Cooper's Gelatine, screen printed in brown on a 100% cotton canvas tote.

    $100- Save Cooper Union Poster (18"w x 24"h)

    Designed by Cooper alum, Hope Gangloff

    $100 - Keep Cooper Free Poster (18"w x 24"h)
    Designed by Cooper alum, Hope Gangloff

    $250 - An original woodcut print, "Air & Water," designed and executed especially for the Committee by Cooper alum Bill Wolf. In it, you will observe a scene in which the Union of Science and Art is represented by two beasts, a Fish and a Bird, who have come together atop Peter Cooper's Foundation Building to form a machine, in which a wheel, representative of the active process of education, turns like a mill, the four spokes of the wheel indicating the four disciplines of the college: Art, Architecture, Engineering, and Humanities. Together, the Bird, representing "Air," and the Fish, representing "Water," reference Peter Cooper's popular belief that "Education should be Free as Air and Water." (Approx. 9"w x 12" h)

    $500 - "Air & Water" woodcut print along with both Save Cooper Union and Free Cooper Union posters, the Gelatine totebag, and the patch as well.

    $1000 - A special deluxe edition of the "Air & Water" woodcut print, signed by the artist as well as original litigants of the Committee to Save Cooper Union legal action. Own a piece of Cooper Union history!

    Special Featured Perks:

    $1200
    SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #17
    Sharon Horvath Mixed Media "Elemental Drift (#12)" 2006-2014, Pigment, Ink, paper on canvas, 10 x 10 inches. Unframed.
    An original mixed media work on canvas, donated courtesy of Sharon Horvath and Lori Bookstein Gallery.
    Sharon Horvath  received her BFA in from Cooper Union 1980 and her MFA from Tyler School of Art, Philadelphia. She is  Associate Professor of Art at Purchase College, SUNY. Horvath has been the subject of numerous exhibitions in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, and abroad. Her numerous awards and grants include the Fulbright-Nehru U.S. Scholar Grant, the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation Grant for Painting, the Rome Prize from the American Academy in Rome, the Anonymous was a Woman Award, the American Academy of Arts and Letters Richard and Hilda Rosenthal Award for Painting, the Edwin Palmer Prize in Painting from the National Academy Museum, two Pollock-Krasner Foundation Grants . The artist is represented by Lori Bookstein Fine Art in NYC, The Drawing Room in East Hampton, NY and the Schoolhouse Gallery in Provincetown, MA. She  lives and works in Queens and Brooklyn, NY.
    For more info: www.sharonhorvath.com
    Recent exhibition: www.loribooksteinfineart.com
    NYT Review: http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/24/arts/design/s...

    $375
    SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #14
    Ellen Hsiao Digital Art Print "Art & Industry" 2001, 18 x 24 inches. Unframed.
    An original digital drawing, printed on heavy matte paper.
    Ellen Chao Hsiao holds a BFA degree from Cooper Union. She also studied fine arts at NYU, and print making at Pratt, SVA and the Lower Eastside Printshop. Her work has been exhibited in numerous museum and gallery shows, including The Cooper-Hewitt Museum, The Lower East Side Print Shop, The Art Students League Gallery, Georgetown University, and a solo show at Gallery 456, NY. She has also designed art books for various publishers, including "Calder Circus" for The Whitney Museum, and was a co-founder of the Asian American Women Artists Alliance (AAWAA, 1997-2008), a non-profit organization with the mission of showcasing the works of Asian women artists. She currently lives and works in Manhattan.
    For more info, email: ehsiao707@aol.com
    $375
    SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #18
    Ellen Hsiao Digital Art Print "Flying Emissaries" 2003, 18 x 24 inches. Unframed.
    An original digital drawing, printed on heavy matte paper.

    $550
    SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #11
    Gerald Korman Watercolor "Whitestone bridge from College Pt." 12x16" unframed, (mounted in mat 16x20")
    An original watercolor on paper.
    Gerald Korman, Art'66, lived and worked in New York City until 2010. His work has been shown in several group shows in N.Y., as well as galleries at the University of Kentucky, Purdue University, and Wheaton College. Residency at the MacDowell Colony, 1972. He now lives and works in Pittsburgh.
    For more info: www.pittsburghartistregistry.org

    $800
    SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #5
    Julia Weist Painting   "Color Derived From Genre 1 (Romance)" 2014, 20 x 24 inches. Unframed
    Handmade paint from books applied to linen. This series uses the physical materiality of genre (ink and paper quality, size and proportion of text and imagery on the printed page) as pigment.  Book sections are pulverized to a ground, mixed with clear gesso and applied to stretched linen.
    Julia Weist (A '07) is an artist working in Brooklyn, NY and Durham, NY.  Recent exhibitions include a two-person installation with Haim Steinbach and group shows at The Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts and Meulensteen Gallery.  Her work has recently been featured in BOMB, The Paris Review, The New Yorker and Artforum.
    For more info:  www.deaccession.org



    $1500
    SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #15
    Noir LeBlanc 2 drawing pair  “La Petite Couquette I & II” 2010.  Each is 15 x 22 inches, ink on arches cotton rag paper. Unframed.
    A pair of original, live, blind contour drawings.
    Noir LeBlanc (Zeborah Houides) Art'92, is a dedicated artist working in Portland, Oregon. She is best known for her unique Skeletal and live figural blind drawing technique.
    For more info, email: noirleblanc@icloud.com
    $1500
    SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #12
    Brian Rose Photographic Print "Orchard Street 1980" 20x25 inches, mounted and floated in a white maple frame.
    A framed photographic print of an image made by Brian Rose and Edward Fausty in 1980, shortly after they graduated from Cooper Union. The image, "Orchard Street 1980," appears in the book "Time and Space on the Lower East Side."
    Born in Virgina, Brian Rose moved to New York City in 1977 to attend Cooper Union. In 1980 he and fellow Cooper graduate Edward
    Fausty photographed the Lower East Side of Manhattan. In 1985 Rose began photographing the Iron Curtain and Berlin Wall. That work was published in 2004 as The Lost Border, the Landscape of the Iron Curtain. After living in the Netherlands for 14 years, Rose returned to New York and began re-photographing the Lower East Side. That work, which encapsulates 30 years of history, was published as Time and Space on the Lower East Side. A companion project about the Meatpacking District of New York was published in June of 2014. Rose’s photographs have been collected by the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He is represented by Dillon Gallery in New York.
    For more info, email: brose@brianrose.com
    For more info: http://www.brianrose.com

We should take heed from Lincoln’s own words in Cooper Union's Great Hall on February 27, 1860 - "Let us have faith that right makes might, and in that faith, let us, to the end, dare to do our duty as we understand it."
 
  



Fundraising Information

This "Appeal" Indiegogo campaign is part of the Phase 2 of our fundraising as discussed in our first Indiegogo campaign.

So far our legal fee expenditures have been: $50,000 for the initial petition and $180,000 for subsequent petitions and representation through the hearing, for a total of $230,000 in legal fees. The fixed fee arrangements we negotiated with our attorneys have resulted in a substantial discount to their normal hourly rates. We have other costs as well, including expenses such as our public relations firm, which has helped us generate support for our cause.
All members and officers of Committee to Save Cooper Union have put in their time and efforts on an unpaid volunteer basis.
We will still need to raise additional funds to complete our action and are working on other fundraising initiatives.
Regarding tax deductibility of donations: Committee to Save Cooper Union is a non-profit corporation, but we don't yet have 501c3 status for tax deductibility. We are working on a fiscal sponsorship arrangement which would enable tax deductibility for certain donations. Please contact us for issues related to this.

If our goal of preserving a free tuition Cooper Union is achieved, 
any remaining funds will be donated back to Cooper Union. If the goal is
 not achieved, any remaining funds will be donated to a worthy 
educational cause.


New PerksWe have some original new perks to show our appreciation for your donations:
$50 - Save Cooper Union Embroidered Iron-On Patch (approx. 3" diameter)The hour is fast approaching! Peter Cooper's Foundation Building clock.

$75 - Peter Cooper's Gelatine Totebag (15"w x 16"h with 22" long handles)A 19th century design replicated from the box top of an original package of Peter Cooper's Gelatine, screen printed in brown on a 100% cotton canvas tote.

$100- Save Cooper Union Poster (18"w x 24"h)Designed by Cooper alum, Hope Gangloff
$100 - Keep Cooper Free Poster (18"w x 24"h)Designed by Cooper alum, Hope Gangloff


$250 - An original woodcut print, "Air & Water," designed and executed especially for the Committee by Cooper alum Bill Wolf. In it, you will observe a scene in which the Union of Science and Art is represented by two beasts, a Fish and a Bird, who have come together atop Peter Cooper's Foundation Building to form a machine, in which a wheel, representative of the active process of education, turns like a mill, the four spokes of the wheel indicating the four disciplines of the college: Art, Architecture, Engineering, and Humanities. Together, the Bird, representing "Air," and the Fish, representing "Water," reference Peter Cooper's popular belief that "Education should be Free as Air and Water." (Approx. 9"w x 12" h)

$500 - "Air & Water" woodcut print along with both Save Cooper Union and Free Cooper Union posters, the Gelatine totebag, and the patch as well.
$1000 - A special deluxe edition of the "Air & Water" woodcut print, signed by the artist as well as original litigants of the Committee to Save Cooper Union legal action. Own a piece of Cooper Union history!Special Featured Perks:


$1200SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #17
Sharon Horvath Mixed Media "Elemental Drift (#12)" 2006-2014, Pigment, Ink, paper on canvas, 10 x 10 inches. Unframed.
An original mixed media work on canvas, donated courtesy of Sharon Horvath and Lori Bookstein Gallery.
Sharon Horvath  received her BFA in from Cooper Union 1980 and her MFA from Tyler School of Art, Philadelphia. She is  Associate Professor of Art at Purchase College, SUNY. Horvath has been the subject of numerous exhibitions in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, and abroad. Her numerous awards and grants include the Fulbright-Nehru U.S. Scholar Grant, the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation Grant for Painting, the Rome Prize from the American Academy in Rome, the Anonymous was a Woman Award, the American Academy of Arts and Letters Richard and Hilda Rosenthal Award for Painting, the Edwin Palmer Prize in Painting from the National Academy Museum, two Pollock-Krasner Foundation Grants . The artist is represented by Lori Bookstein Fine Art in NYC, The Drawing Room in East Hampton, NY and the Schoolhouse Gallery in Provincetown, MA. She  lives and works in Queens and Brooklyn, NY.

For more info: www.sharonhorvath.com

Recent exhibition: www.loribooksteinfineart.com

NYT Review: http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/24/arts/design/s...




$375SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #14

Ellen Hsiao Digital Art Print "Art & Industry" 2001, 18 x 24 inches. Unframed.
An original digital drawing, printed on heavy matte paper.
Ellen Chao Hsiao holds a BFA degree from Cooper Union. She also studied fine arts at NYU, and print making at Pratt, SVA and the Lower Eastside Printshop. Her work has been exhibited in numerous museum and gallery shows, including The Cooper-Hewitt Museum, The Lower East Side Print Shop, The Art Students League Gallery, Georgetown University, and a solo show at Gallery 456, NY. She has also designed art books for various publishers, including "Calder Circus" for The Whitney Museum, and was a co-founder of the Asian American Women Artists Alliance (AAWAA, 1997-2008), a non-profit organization with the mission of showcasing the works of Asian women artists. She currently lives and works in Manhattan.
For more info, email: ehsiao707@aol.com





$375SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #18
Ellen Hsiao Digital Art Print "Flying Emissaries" 2003, 18 x 24 inches. Unframed.
An original digital drawing, printed on heavy matte paper.



$550SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #11Gerald Korman Watercolor "Whitestone bridge from College Pt." 12x16" unframed, (mounted in mat 16x20")An original watercolor on paper.


Gerald Korman, Art'66, lived and worked in New York City until 2010. His work has been shown in several group shows in N.Y., as well as galleries at the University of Kentucky, Purdue University, and Wheaton College. Residency at the MacDowell Colony, 1972. He now lives and works in Pittsburgh.
For more info: www.pittsburghartistregistry.org

$800SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #5Julia Weist Painting   "Color Derived From Genre 1 (Romance)" 2014, 20 x 24 inches. Unframed
Handmade paint from books applied to linen. This series uses the physical materiality of genre (ink and paper quality, size and proportion of text and imagery on the printed page) as pigment.  Book sections are pulverized to a ground, mixed with clear gesso and applied to stretched linen.
Julia Weist (A '07) is an artist working in Brooklyn, NY and Durham, NY.  Recent exhibitions include a two-person installation with Haim Steinbach and group shows at The Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts and Meulensteen Gallery.  Her work has recently been featured in BOMB, The Paris Review, The New Yorker and Artforum.
For more info:  www.deaccession.org



$1500SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #15
Noir LeBlanc 2 drawing pair  “La Petite Couquette I & II” 2010.  Each is 15 x 22 inches, ink on arches cotton rag paper. Unframed.
A pair of original, live, blind contour drawings.Noir LeBlanc (Zeborah Houides) Art'92, is a dedicated artist working in Portland, Oregon. She is best known for her unique Skeletal and live figural blind drawing technique.For more info, email: noirleblanc@icloud.com


$1500SPECIAL FEATURED ARTIST PERK #12
Brian Rose Photographic Print "Orchard Street 1980" 20x25 inches, mounted and floated in a white maple frame.
A framed photographic print of an image made by Brian Rose and Edward Fausty in 1980, shortly after they graduated from Cooper Union. The image, "Orchard Street 1980," appears in the book "Time and Space on the Lower East Side."Born in Virgina, Brian Rose moved to New York City in 1977 to attend Cooper Union. In 1980 he and fellow Cooper graduate Edward Fausty photographed the Lower East Side of Manhattan. In 1985 Rose began photographing the Iron Curtain and Berlin Wall. That work was published in 2004 as The Lost Border, the Landscape of the Iron Curtain. After living in the Netherlands for 14 years, Rose returned to New York and began re-photographing the Lower East Side. That work, which encapsulates 30 years of history, was published as Time and Space on the Lower East Side. A companion project about the Meatpacking District of New York was published in June of 2014. Rose’s photographs have been collected by the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He is represented by Dillon Gallery in New York.For more info, email: brose@brianrose.comFor more info: http://www.brianrose.com

story:
Update: We have received a pledge from a generous anonymous supporter to match all donations going forward, up to the goal of $5500. 

YOUR DONATIONS WILL BE DOUBLED! PLEASE GIVE ANY AMOUNT AND SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN ON YOUR NETWORKS.

Photo: Kathy Gilberd conducting a workshop on Military Sexual Assault and Harrassment in 2012. 

Overview

This campaign is to fund the salary of Kathy Gilberd, the Executive Director of the Military Law Task Force of the National Lawyers Guild, for at least six months. 

MLTF, like many progressive groups, is dealing with an ever-decreasing level of incoming funds from grants and general donations. The steering committee has been taking action to find new funding while reducing costs, but at this time without the results necessary to keep Kathy's part-time position funded.  

The Heart and Soul of MLTF's Work for Servicemembers and Vets

Kathy has worked with MLTF for many years, as a volunteer, as chair and now as Executive Director. A legal worker in San Diego, she has dedicated her life, really, to ensuring the rights of servicemembers and vets are protected and enhanced. Her experience, knowledge and skills are unequaled in the field of GI Rights. Her achievements and specialties for MLTF include: 
  • Author of many articles, legal memos, counseling and self-help guides provided freely to the GI Rights counseling network and to servicemembers and vets on the MLTF website. 
  • Trainer of counselors for the GI Rights Hotline and at GI Coffeehouses
  • Sought after trainer and panelist on GI Rights topics, particularly Military Sexual Violence (sexual assault and harassment). 
  • Received the Service Provider of the Year award from Service Women's Action Network in 2013. 
She also provides direct support to those contacting MLTF for assistance, including attorneys, law students, lay counselors, as well as servicemembers and vets and/or their families. 
As ED, she coordinates the military law library maintained on the MLTF website, organizes the quarterly military law journal On Watch and generally serves as the public face of the organization. Anyone who has had the need to seek her help and advice on a case or call knows that she is a library of information on the latest regs, trends and military policy news, and she keeps other MLTF members well informed on all matters in the field. 
Under the  MLTLF umbrellas, she also contributes valuable services to many other related organizations, including:
  • GI Rights Hotline - longtime board member and volunteer with the San Diego counseling group, helps plan the annual conference where she conducts workshops and participates in panels. 
  • Chelsea Manning Support Network - has served on the advisory board since its inception
  • Fort Hood Support Network - Serves on advisory board that operates Under the Hood Cafe and Resource Center (a GI coffeehouse) in Killeen, Texas, just outside Ft. Hood (the largest military base in the US)

In short, Kathy Gilberd is a resource that can't be replaced or eliminated from our budget or program work without dire consequences to the work of many other organizations and volunteers, not to mention the clients and hotline callers themselves. We must find a way to keep her working for the servicemembers and vets who have so few avenues to seek justice from the military.

That's where YOU come in. 

$5500 for six months

For this campaign, we want to raise enough to continue paying Kathy her part time salary for the next six months while we locate other funding sources.

All donations will be earmarked for that purpose. If we raise more than $5500, the additional funds will continue to fund Kathy's salary beyond the six month period. 

About MLTF and the organizer of this campaign

The Military Law Task Force is a standing committee of the National Lawyers Guild with the mission of ensuring the rights of servicemembers and veterans, challenging oppressive military policies, and opposing interventionist military action. For more information about its work, visit nlgmltf.org. 
This campaign is organized by Rena Guay, a member of the MLTF steeriing committee. However,  all funds raised here go directly to MLTF. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't make a financial donation, you can do a lot just by sharing and promoting this campaign, through social media, email, blogs or even word of mouth or distributing our flyer. If you have other ideas, please let us know. 

    Thank you!

story:
This is my brother, Ryan Howland. He’s a 15 year old violinist from Victoria B.C Canada. Since the age of 5, he has had a great passion for music and playing the violin. He’s very hard working with his studies and wishes to pursue a professional career as a violin concert soloist. He has accomplished amazing things so far, such as

  1. won three awards and prizes at the Victoria Performing Arts Festival.
  2. won first place in the provincial BC festival place.
  3.  has performed in places such as retirement homes, art galleries, garden tours, and in Taiwan.
  4. received a loan for a french violin made in 1848





 

That’s me! - Ian Howland. I am 18 years old, also from Victoria BC. Since a young age, I have had a passion in art and animation. Although I have also played violin for many years alongside my brother, my focus rests in the art field.




Recently, I got accepted into a prestigious summer school program in Paris, France, at Gobelins. I was one of few international students to be accepted. Taking this step would be a great leap towards my dream career- to be a film animator.However, we are in a dilemma! With me and my brother’s busking money, our mother is only able to pay for half of the fees. That’s why we are hoping that you could support us, and to help us reach our goals.




What We Need & What You Get


We are hoping to raise the amount needed for

  • Ryan to study violin in Switzerland  

  • Ian to be able to partake in the Gobelins Summer School program of 2014.


All the money raised will be going directly to these things, regardless of how much is fund-raised in the end! A few general things that the money will be put towards includes money for the train ride into Switzerland, money for food, metro tickets for two weeks, the violin and animation programs themselves, and student living costs. (Please scroll to the bottom for specific details)



 Perk Previews





-------------------------->> Deviantart Portfolio<<--------------------------------


-------------------------->>Violin performances<<--------------------------------


The Impact:

  • We both have big goals. Ryan has dreams to become a violinist, and to be at the top of the musical world. I have dreams to become an animator and to work in a good field.
  • If we are able to get some help from others with peoples' donations, it will help us to start accomplishing our goals. Even though we have been held back financially until now, it has never stopped us from working towards our future careers.
  • As shown in the video above, we were interviewed recently (June 18) about our cause.


Mothers' Words



I have been an instructor of piano at the Victoria conservatory of music, BC Canada since 1994. My goal is not only passing on the passion of music to my students but also supporting and giving good care to my 2 sons- by being a single parent since my second son was 2 years old. Both of my sons have followed their passions of art and music in good directions. Ian and Ryan have their own goals and dreams and they have been doing exceptionally well with what they like to do as a violin player and an artist. I tell myself everyday that if I follow my heart towards what I believe and what I do for my children, it will make them successful.

  • However, my piano teaching income can only afford minimum costs to support my sons. So, I have made a decision ... That is to sell my house to 
  • pay for both Ian's art school in Paris for 3 years and 
  • Ryan's violin study in Switzerland and Italy.  

Nevertheless, the seller's market has been very low that I am not yet able to sell my house to support my sons in time. I have been taking a chance-I keep my hope of selling my house before July 1st, so I can pay for my son’s tuition fees; Until my house is sold, I am not able to provide the money for my sons.

Up until now, I feel proud for what I have done for my sons. I have never stopped supporting them with their art and music since they were 4. I have continued to support them as a single mom and made my own beliefs, disregarding other peoples' negative feedback on how I do too much for my sons. I deeply know that if I do everything for them, they will be in a good field in the terms of what they can do. I will never stop supporting them and I know that I can see their success in no time, with the amount of effort I have put on them.


Costs

For Ian---

Gobelins Animation Summer School 2014 - deadline July 1st- needing 2600$ Canadian

LISAA (L'institut Supérieur des Arts Appliqués) program, registration confirmation- 420.77$ Canadian

Room and board for the summer program-365.06$ Canadian

Transportation for the Summer Program-64.59$ Canadian

For Ryan---

Room and board  during violin studies course in Switzerland-502.58$ Canadian

Train for Ryan from Zurich to Interlaken-170.34$ Canadian

lessons for Ryan-438.1$ Canadian

Flight for Ian- 1200$

Flight for Ryan- 1200$

total=6460$

+9 percent bring reduced from 6460- 7041.4$


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you aren't able to contribute, getting the word out and letting people see our cause would help immensely! Tell your friends, family, to share this with them. We thank you for your time, in reading our campaign and giving us a hand in the process.


Resumes of Ian and Ryan

Ian William Howland 

Accomplishments

Verbier Festival: Giving assistance to professional musicians, working backstage, and supervising classes

Illustrator for “Newsflash,” (Newsletter of Volunteer Victoria) and designing program covers for piano studio concerts.

Assisted tennis classes at the Oak Bay Tennis Club

Performing music in venues, such as retirement houses (ongoing)

Victoria Symphony: Instrument petting zoo, showing children the basics of an instrument.

Helped set up holiday events at Victor Brodeur; Halloween/Christmas decorations and observing that children are playing safely.

Winter market take down/Volunteer table: assisting in putting away stands after the market, and selling coffee/putting up balloons for the children.

French Festival: Helping at the crafts stand, taking care of paint and brushes used by others and painting on the canvas occasionally to invite people to join in.

---

2012 Fundraising for family member’s French exchange program by performing at coffee house

2010 After the Japan Earthquake, busked on the street with brother, raising over 500$ to donate to various relief efforts

2010 Auditioned for the Greater Victoria Youth Orchestra and was accepted on violin for their 2010-2011 concert season

2008 Winner of the École Victor-Brodeur Talent Show

Making programs, setting up and assisting in concerts for Victoria Conservatory of Music


Ryan Howland

Accomplishments

-Plays in the Greater Victoria Youth Orchestra 2011- present

-Participates in chamber ensembles

-is an active member of the Collegium program at the Victoria Conservatory of Music

-Performed as a soloist with the Sydney Classical Orchestra (Victoria) 2012

-Won the Greater Victoria Performing Arts Festival in 2012

-Finalist of the auditions for the Symphony Splash Annual Concert

-Studied in Dijon, France for three months, February to May 2013

-Studied with Igor Volochine, a teacher at the Paris Conservatory, in a spring music academy in Bordeaux, France, 2013

-Studied with Professor Zakhar Bron in Zürich, Switzerland in July 2013 (Zakhar Bron is one of the most well known teachers in the world and is in the jury of several international competitions)

-Currently studies with Michael van der Sloot, who studied in Austria

-received a loan from Chi Mei, Taiwan, in November, 2013 for french violin valued at 60,000 Euros

-Studied briefly with (Lon-Sin-Wen), a pupil of David Oistrakh, in Taiwan, in November, 2013

-Played for the conductor of the Taipei Philharmonic in Taiwan, November, 2013

-Briefly studied with Jonathan Crow in Montreal, January 2014

-Participated in Zakhar Bron’s master classes again in January 2014

-Studied with Maurizio Sciarretta in Italy, March 2014

-was accepted into the Music Academy of Imola, Italy, for 2014-2015 (a 40 week program for gifted musicians)

-won the 2014 Greater Victoria Performing Arts Festival for best Sonata, best concert and Outstanding Musician. Ryan will be going to participate in the Provincial Festival in June 2014

-invited to play in the 2014 Garden Tour

-accepted to do a live audition for Symphony Splash in May 2014

  -Winner of BC provincial Festival

  -Accepted to Ottowa music camp with Pinchas Zukerman

-Finalist of the auditions for the Symphony Splash Annual Concert
-Studied in Dijon, France for three months, February
to May 2013
-Studied with Igor Volochine,
a teacher at the Paris Conservatory,
in a spring music academy in Bordeaux, France, 2013
-Studied with Professor Zakhar
Bron in Zürich, Switzerland in July 2013 (Zakhar Bron is one of the most
well known teachers in the world and is in the jury of several international
competitions)
-Currently studies with Michael van der Sloot, who studied in Austria
-received a loan from Chi Mei, Taiwan, in November, 2013 for french
violin valued at 60,000 Euros
-Studied briefly with (Lon-Sin-Wen),
a pupil of David Oistrakh, in
Taiwan, in November, 2013
-Played for the conductor of the Taipei Philharmonic
in Taiwan, November, 2013
-Briefly studied with Jonathan Crow in Montreal,
January 2014
-Participated in Zakhar
Bron’s master classes again in January 2014 
-Studied with Maurizio
Sciarretta in Italy, March 2014
-was accepted into the Music Academy of Imola, Italy, for 2014-2015 (a
40 week program for gifted musicians) 
-won the 2014 Greater Victoria Performing Arts Festival for best Sonata,
best concert and Outstanding Musician. Ryan will be going to participate in the
Provincial Festival in June 2014
-invited to play in the 2014 Garden Tour
-accepted to do a live audition for Symphony Splash in May 2014
  -Winner of BC provincial Festival
  -Accepted to Ottowa music camp with
Pinchas Zukerman

story:
Short Summary

In 1998 Dr. Lita Mathews began the Book Give Away, at the annual Gathering of Nations Pow Wow in Albuquerque, to young Native American boys and girls. It was her attempt to provide young kids with their own books and the start of their personal library. As a young native girl growing up in Northern New Mexico, Lita and her seven brothers and sisters had no books in there home. Dr. Lita Mathews believes in early childhood literacy as a key to academic and social success.
Since Dr. Lita began the book giveaway she has been able to reach over 500 young native kids each year. The total amount of books given has reached three thousand books. Thus providing each child with several brand new books.
For many years the books were donated by various groups such as Disney and others. However those donations have gone away. It is important for Dr. Lita to reach out at this time for help to continue this wonderful and fantastic educational effort.
note: The Gathering of Nations, a non profit organization, produces the annual Gathering of Nations Pow Wow in Albuquerque New Mexico each April.  


What We Need & What You Get

It is the goal of Dr. Lita Mathews and the Gathering of Nations to receive $5000.00 through this campagain. The five thousand dollars raised will provide each of 500 native kids with approximately 8 to 10 books each. The book giveaway takes place on saturday afternoon at the Pow Wow. After all of the young kids have completed their time to dance they then to receive their new books. This is witnessed by nearly 20,000 people attending and another 20,000 people on line watching the live web cast.

As a spcial thank you to all who contribute to Dr. Lita`s campaign, the Gathering of Nations will publicly give thanks to all who contribute, and place their names on the thank you page in the souveinier program book.

No matter what the total amount of money rased it will all go to the purchase of books for Native American children.

  • The Impact which your donation will have is long reaching, as it is well known that early childhood literacy is vital to the growth and success of every young boy and girl. With your help each of these Native American children will be given a special boost. In past years since the book giveaway began, the parents have been most grateful and have been inspired to provide other books to their children. The children have tightened their bond with their moms and dads as the books are read to them. There has even been reports of the children passing the books down to younger brothers and sisters.
  • For more information about the Gathering of Nations and The book giveaway, visit the official web site; www.gatheringofnations.com 

Dr. Lita Mathews and the Gathering of Nations wants to thank all who have taken the time to read this campaign. Dr. Lita mathews is aware that everyone may not be able to contribute money to assits, however everyone can help by spreading the word to others. This grass roots effort is important to this campaign.

story:
The PHASE I SMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE programs will include:

Our Adult Renewable Energy Training Courses are geared towards the local workforce to stimulate the local economy. The objective is focused on renewable technologies, education, and training. The goal is to introduce these life skills to those most in need and at risk so they can obtain better jobs in these fields. Please refer to the video above for more information.


                        

Be a part of the GAET community solutions with a focus on education and training in solar energy, wind energy, energy audits, geothermal energy, bio-energy, hydro-electric energy and much more. Additionally, we gear our efforts towards the environment, energy & economy through renewable sustainability.


Why Crowd Funding?

Creating curriculum of this magnitude is not cheap, raising funds with your help allow us to develop the appropriate curriculum which qualifies individuals to become part of the ready and able renewable energy skilled workforce. These programs will offer solutions to local communities and their unemployed or under employed by offering an opportunity to secure higher paying and sustainable skilled jobs.

With your efforts we hope to achieve our funding goals, which will make a huge difference in thousands of people's lives. Even the smallest of donations can go a very long way. 


Why the GAETSMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE

Establishing the GAET SMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE as the center of the community will create a measurable and profound direct impact on the lives of interested individuals, “the students” and their families. In addition to the impact created throughout the community with further job placement through indirect jobs generated as a result of the economic stimulus in the community.


                                                           

GAET is a renewable energy developer established in the State of Tennessee to integrate emerging sustainable technologies, processes, and techniques that will lead to a greater good with a economic stimulation and environmentally-friendly impact mission.

Management Team

The GAET management team has broad base of experience and expertise. This experience is derived from a multitude of arenas, ranging from education, business management, environmental, finance, research, research and development, energy and community outreach.


Our next video details how GAETSMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE has identified the local workforce problems and how we plan to put the unemployed and under employed back to work – Check out our video below



                                                      

Our phase 1 campaign goal is to raise $100,000, which will go towards the development of the initial training programs within the GAETSMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE.

Once created will allow GAET to offer opportunities to thousands of those in need, generating new life and excitement to communities everywhere.

Other Ways You Can Help

Become a Humanitarian Soldier of GAET. Although the purpose of this campaign is to raise money for GAET, the program is in need of those who can spread the word and allow others the opportunity to pay it forward too. We are searching for people who are willing to promote GAET however they can.

If you do want to volunteer, you can contact GAET by emailing us at 

                                              Learngaet@gmail.com

                Doing the right thing – for the future – for all of us!

                                                Below are our goals 





Future programs will include:

  

Youth STEM 3e is an educational vision which utilizes a project-based learning approach to creating elementary, middle, and high school level science-based curriculum that teaches environment, energy and technology, with a goal of introducing energy management to the youth.

V

College level development of comprehensive computer/cyber security training programs that provide students the skill sets essential to maintain/improve sustainable project operations, and to use real world applications for their future.

                                                 

Our partnerships will provide a renewable energy and community sustainability curriculum with the assistance of our established accredited university partnerships. Our local government and business community partnerships shall expand our opportunities for availability in job placement for those who have graduated. 

  



                              


                            GAET’s own Commitment and Contributions

GAET will target under-served communities for employment and education, resulting in social and economic stimulus. We provide the difference as a good citizen, demonstrating that companies of all sizes can make a difference using our scalable approach.

Our mission is to create a sustainable and humane achievement. GAET will donate a percentage of all net bio-diesel profits to the GAET SMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE.

However, we need your contributions to the campaign which will make that required difference which provides the opportunity to achieve our goals. We appreciate any sort of donation, large or small.


                              

               

                                          

                                         

           

                               


The Perks: To thank you for helping make our vision a reality, we're offering some perks we hope you will enjoy. Our perks range from the smallest of donations to those that can afford more. All are appreciated and each are the foundation that build on each other to make this dream come true. Some of the larger donors  will also have their name inscribed on the Builders wall. It’s our way of saying thanks in addition to the perks you received. So no matter the size of your donation of $5.00 or more, we would like to say thank you very much with these perks below!


We'll ship all items free of charge of course!

Also, if you would like to donate your gift to someone else you know, we will show you how to do that as well in our email once you select your perk.

Take a look at our perks further down the page, and if you’re wondering how we are able to do this, watch the perks video right below.


                                              


  • For your 25 dollar perk we will give you this key-chain with the Smarter SchoolHouse logo on that shows you were the key to our success. Thank you! 


                                    

  • For your 50 dollar  perk you would receive  a tote bag for your phone with the Smarter SchoolHouse logo on it. Thank you!

                          


  • For your 75 dollar perk you will receive our quality t-shirt with the Smarter SchoolHouse logo, so wear it with pride and show the world you helped. We will have sizes to choose from in your email. Thank you!


                          The $5.00 to $75.00 perks are given as shown.



With this level below we start where the donor themselves get to choose the gift they want. Choose from over 100 in each category of perk they are in. Our mad procurement Agent was able to secure these perks with a company that specializes in these types of event.

            

                       possible 100 dollar perk choose 1 from over 100 Gifts!



           

  


                possible  250 to 500 dollar perks choose 1 from over 100 Gifts!


                                       

possible 1.500 to 2,000 perks choose 1 from over 100 Gifts


 


                     possible 3,000 dollar perk choose 1 from over 100 Gifts!

                

                     

          A Sharp AQUOS LC-90LE745U 90" Class LED Smart 3D TV

               Our  10,000 dollar perk or Choose from over 100 gifts as well.             

                                

                                        

Prizes above are only a few of the literally 100's  of perks you can choose from for  the $100 to $10,000 perks.  As we said our procurement agent made this possible to give these away. These may not be actual representations of perks received, as the donor chooses their own perks from a category  for the  specific amount of donations they gave.

You Choose the gift you Want! 

IT's your reward!


    

In addition if you are wanting to give your upper level perk to a good quality organization and not take it,we will gladly give your gift to a military charity  called "Wounded Warriors" and we love this charity and involves the military and warriors coming home from war. We give as much as we can to them. Just let us know  in the email sent back to you what you want done and check off which box you want, Either given to you, or to the charity. Its that simple. 

Thank you so much for your time and hope to see us reach our goal through your help.

 All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts to further the GAETSMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE program development. 

                

We would like to say a big thank you to CrowdFunding USA who put this whole front page together! They actually were able to find the video talent, icons, wrote the script and found the terrific perks to give away through a company they use. They pretty much did everything for us. 

If you want a good shot at raising money through crowd 

funding then use them!

They are CrowdFunding USA

Just copy and paste or click on the links below.

crowdfundingusa1@gmail.com

IF you want the best use them!!

                                     https://twitter.com/CFUSA1

                 Copyright  GAETSMARTER™ SCHOOLHOUSE 01/01/2014

story:
Sean Hannity, a strong believer of reporting unbiased facts on all issues, took his efforts of journalistic integrity full on and decided to visit Israel currently to report on the horrors of war and the day to day life of the Israeli suffering. He has been tweeting and letting us now how dire the situation is in Israel like the real champ that he is.

However, Sean Hannity has so far, unfortunately, been unable to visit Gaza right across the border even though he must have tried sincerely because of his love for reporting unbiased facts so this is where we can all help him!

Let's raise the funds necessary to pay for an all inclusive trip to Gaza! It'll be the opportunity of a lifetime for a member of the mainstream US media to actually be able and see the Gazan side of suffering and report on it to Americans. He'll be extremely appreciative for this opportunity since he has always wanted to give the Gazan side of the conflict but something just always hindered him from doing so.

Once Sean Hannity accepts our generous offer, all of the extra funds raised will be donated to Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)-Doctors without Borders- International efforts in Gaza. If for some strange reason Sean Hannity choses to not accept the offer all funds will be donated to MSF. 

His itinerary will be up shortly. 

Please reach out to him on Twitter/Facebook. Remember to invite your friends and use this hashtag #sendhannitytogaza

story:
The above video is from another school (6th -8th), but is the exact program we are running here at Meeker.


WEB is great because it's sort of a two for one deal!

Meeker is a low income middle school in the Kent school district in Washington State.  We are raising money to help fund our WEB (Where Everybody Belongs) program, now going into it's 4th year.  WEB is designed to train 8th grade students in middle school to be strong, confident, caring leaders.  Their training helps them be able to connect with incoming 7th graders (ten 7th graders each) and guide them in the often overwhelming and confusing transition to middle school.  Along with the WEB program training these great students to be even better leaders, our incoming 7th graders are able to make the switch to middle school with less problems and worries and more confidence in their middle school careers. 

Why WEB needs funding:

The great thing about this program, besides the skills kids learn and the assistance our 7th graders receive, is that 1) for the impact it makes, it is very low cost and 2) besides the two items listed below, these 8th graders do most everything without funding.  They work hard all year to make connections with 7th graders they don't know, check in with their ten assigned 7th graders, and put on some of our fantastic activities for the 7th graders....and that is before the funding.

The funds from this campaign will cover two main costs for our program:

1 - Shirts for the 8th graders.  Each year we choose a new color and shirt design.  These shirts are worn during our opening day assembly, which is just WEB leaders and the 7th graders (no other 8th graders) as well as throughout the year.  They will wear them to after school functions the WEB leaders host, every Friday the first month of school, sporting events they attend, and throughout the year.  7th graders know that if they see someone in a WEB shirt, it is someone trained and prepared to help them with any problem they may have and if the WEB leader can't help them, to get them to someone who can.

2 - Activities.  Although our WEB leaders put on some after school (and even during school) activities for their 7th graders, with little to no money needed, often there is a need for funds for some activities. 
 - Movie night; hosted, decorated, and put on by the WEB leaders.  To do this we need to purchase a license to show the movie, snacks, and decorations.
- Treats for some activities and get togethers; ice cream social a couple weeks into the year, movie night, game night, etc as well as snacks for the two training days in August when the WEB leaders are being trained and prepared for this amazing opportunity to help their school and classmates. 

If we surpass our goal there is even the possibility to bring in trainers from the Boomerang Project (where WEB comes from) and provide the 8th graders with even more and better leadership training.

The Impact WEB Makes

As teachers, every year we see the struggles kids new to middle school have in making the transition from elementary to middle school.  It is priceless having these 80+ WEB leaders back us up in providing the guidance and help these 7th graders need.  It takes very little time before we see and hear the 7th graders talk about how much they like their WEB leaders and even mentioning how they want to be a WEB leader when they are in 8th grade.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If making a donation is not possible at this time there are other ways to help.  Food/treat donations for our after school activities and get togethers is always appreciated.  Also, if you happen to have a great connection for providing screen printed shirts that would be fabulous as well! 

Thank you,
Your Meeker WEB coordinators Brenda, Bob, Jenny, and Kathy
story_txt:
The above video is from another school (6th -8th), but is the exact program we are running here at Meeker. WEB is great because it's sort of a two for one deal! 
Meeker is a low income middle school in the Kent school district in Washington State.  We are raising money to help fund our WEB (Where Everybody Belongs) program, now going into it's 4th year.  WEB is designed to train 8th grade students in middle school to be strong, confident, caring leaders.  Their training helps them be able to connect with incoming 7th graders (ten 7th graders each) and guide them in the often overwhelming and confusing transition to middle school.  Along with the WEB program training these great students to be even better leaders, our incoming 7th graders are able to make the switch to middle school with less problems and worries and more confidence in their middle school careers.  Why WEB needs funding:The great thing about this program, besides the skills kids learn and the assistance our 7th graders receive, is that 1) for the impact it makes, it is very low cost and 2) besides the two items listed below, these 8th graders do most everything without funding.  They work hard all year to make connections with 7th graders they don't know, check in with their ten assigned 7th graders, and put on some of our fantastic activities for the 7th graders....and that is before the funding.The funds from this campaign will cover two main costs for our program:1 - Shirts for the 8th graders.  Each year we choose a new color and shirt design.  These shirts are worn during our opening day assembly, which is just WEB leaders and the 7th graders (no other 8th graders) as well as throughout the year.  They will wear them to after school functions the WEB leaders host, every Friday the first month of school, sporting events they attend, and throughout the year.  7th graders know that if they see someone in a WEB shirt, it is someone trained and prepared to help them with any problem they may have and if the WEB leader can't help them, to get them to someone who can.2 - Activities.  Although our WEB leaders put on some after school (and even during school) activities for their 7th graders, with little to no money needed, often there is a need for funds for some activities.   - Movie night; hosted, decorated, and put on by the WEB leaders.  To do this we need to purchase a license to show the movie, snacks, and decorations.- Treats for some activities and get togethers; ice cream social a couple weeks into the year, movie night, game night, etc as well as snacks for the two training days in August when the WEB leaders are being trained and prepared for this amazing opportunity to help their school and classmates.  If we surpass our goal there is even the possibility to bring in trainers from the Boomerang Project (where WEB comes from) and provide the 8th graders with even more and better leadership training.The Impact WEB MakesAs teachers, every year we see the struggles kids new to middle school have in making the transition from elementary to middle school.  It is priceless having these 80+ WEB leaders back us up in providing the guidance and help these 7th graders need.  It takes very little time before we see and hear the 7th graders talk about how much they like their WEB leaders and even mentioning how they want to be a WEB leader when they are in 8th grade.     Other Ways You Can Help If making a donation is not possible at this time there are other ways to help.  Food/treat donations for our after school activities and get togethers is always appreciated.  Also, if you happen to have a great connection for providing screen printed shirts that would be fabulous as well!  Thank you,Your Meeker WEB coordinators Brenda, Bob, Jenny, and Kathy

story:
Summary

Hello!! My name Camilo Labarces. I am a 25 year old citizen of Colombia. I am currently finishing a Master's Degree in International Business Development & Consulting at Novancia Business School in Paris. 

As part of my Master's Degree, I would like develop a research project to analyze how cluster organizations can develop an organizational culture that leads to creative thinking amongst its members (with a focus on the Colombian IT Cluster CaribeTic). 

At this stage financial support would be greatly appreciated in order to move forward with this endeavour.  My research will anticipate a flight tickets from Paris to Barranquilla in order to access primary data sources, which are otherwise inaccessible from outside the country.  Additional funds are also needed to obtain survey supplies and potentially expand the scope of the research beyond Barranquilla to neighbouring cities. 

The aim of my research is not only to contribute to the growth of the IT industry in this region, but also to provide standard framework that could be use by companies and their employees to establish creative thinking processes potentially leading to innovation.  

Rewards for your support

I have prepared some really special rewards for you:

For $10 donations: Personalize thanking email

You will received an email from me thanking you for your support in this research project.

For $25 donations: A Facebook post in your Honor!

I will acknowledge your donation on my personal facebook account by posting a note in your Honor.

For $50 donations: Thanking Letter of Caribetic

The Director of Caribetic will write a thanking letter to you, for your contribution to the development of the IT Sector in the Colombian Caribbean.

For $100 donations: Acknowledgement in research

I will include your name in the acknowledgement page on the final version of my Thesis. For this donation you will also receive a copy of the Photographic Journal.

For $500 donations: Copy of research results

You will receive a Digital copy of the final research result for own and private use. For this donation you will also get acknowledgement in the final print version of the Thesis. You will also receive the Photographic Album.


Your Impact

Caribetic was officially created in March of 2013 as “an Innovation hub of the IT industry, born from the desire of entrepreneurs with a strategy focused on profitable growth for its members, the sector and the region. It offers the opportunity to integrate into a network of competitive talent at the highest level, to universities, support entities, the State, the community and leading business in the market.” (Source: Caribetic Official Website http://www.caribetic.com/en/).

In spite of the fact that Caribetic is actually working along with governmental institutions to develop the human talent, there are no clear initiatives to develop a common organizational culture that leads to creative thinking processes amongst its members.

Your donation will contribute to the creation of consciousness of the importance of human resources for the IT industry. It is hoped that this research will be the first step to create mechanisms that harness the potential of Caribetic members (whether employees or business owners) by developing their abilities and talents and fostering innovation.


Other ways you can Help!

Every little help will contribute to the project, so no donation is too small or too large!!

You can also help spread the word about this fundraising campaign by:

-Facebook

-Twitter

-Sharing the campaign with your friend and relatives.


Contact Information

You can contact me at:

camilolabarces@gmail.com

You can also visit my FB page: https://www.facebook.com/camilo.labarces

Or my LinkedIn page: http://www.linkedin.com/pub/camilo-andres-labarces-amell/35/924/422

story:
Summary

    In the current project, we intend to create a student-run rapid prototyping hub in Northwest Philadelphia to enrich the growth and stability of the community and to foster a globally-competitive spirit using STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics) subject areas. This is the first step of our journey. We are grateful for any contributions that may advance our cause.

      What We Need & What You Get

      • 3D printers
      • Digitizers (Kinect paired with Skanect Software will do just fine!)
      • PLA printing filament
      • NinjaFlex printing filament (for Phone Cases)
      • Sugru
      • Breadboards
      • Wires/Cables
      • Arduino Ultimate Starter Kit
      • Bitalinos (Biometric Tools)
      • Lillypad/Flora/Gemma Arduino platforms
      • Conductive Thread
      • LEDs
      • Sensors of all types
      • Xively Subscriptions
      • Soldering guns
      • Hot glue guns
      • Fasteners
      • Microtools
      • Macrotools (hammers, drills, screwdrivers, pliers)
      • Bandsaw
      • Lathe
      • Field trip funding
      • Hard drives for project archival
      • Google/iTunes App Dev Subscriptions
      • A Super Flashy and Informative Web Presence :)

      • As a financial contributor of the project, you will receive custom products created by the students in the WARP Lab.
      • If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds would be primarily used to purchase a 3D printer. This would allow the students to design and sell consumables to support their continuing fundraising efforts.

      The Impact

      At its most basic level, the strength of a community is derived from cumulative impact of each member and, even more importantly, the skills they possess and share with others. Of paramount importance is the development of skills that provide today's students with a strategic advantage to compete and thrive in an increasingly global economy. The community-based learning center that will arise from the WARP Lab will be a crucial component of that skill-building process.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you would like to participate as a non-financially-vested member of the WARP Lab initiative, please share 'used but still valuable' raw materials such as metal, wood, paper, electronics, etc.  We value your contributions, in whatever form they may take.

story:
Short Summary

Mellow Pages Library & Reading Room was founded in early February of 2013. Our original space, which was 200 square feet, quickly became recognized as a center for small press, independent and underground literature as well as a vital source for readings and literary gatherings. Following a storm of positive media attention, including the L Magazine, The New York Times and TimeOut New York, we received an outpouring of support and books which caused us to quickly outgrow our space. In July, we made a gamble on our new home, a huge (to us) 400 square foot corner studio in the same building, 56 Bogart. This is an ideal space for both our collection and our event programming, and was a necessary investment for the continuation and expansion of the community we created.


What's most important about this project is the idea that powerful community spaces can be created and sustained by the same communities they support. Mellow Pages is a functional library with over 200 members, and has always been an entirely free resource to the people who wish to use it. We will be keeping it that way. During our experimental first months it was up to us to prove whether or not we could handle the job. We took on that challenge because we were passionate about our idea and felt that a space free of consumer pressures was amiss in the neighborhood. Nothing is for sale in Mellow Pages, everyone is welcome, and you are free to read and work as you wish.


Now that it’s clear Mellow Pages Library is a worthwhile project, we agree it’s time to share the responsibility with those also up for the challenge. Thus far, we have funded the space ourselves, which has been a task we’ve enjoyed struggling through. But after countless strangers asking for ways they can help, this seems like a sensible option. We would love to continue taking on a greater schedule of events, housing more dynamic workshops like Words After War, and supporting the readership of small presses throughout the country. To do this we will need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

We want to be as transparent as possible here. Our goal of 20,000 dollars nominally reflects our needs over the course of one year, 15,000 of which solely amounts to the rent. Don’t get discouraged by this number. Whether or not we reach this goal is not contingent on continuing the dream. We will persevere, as we already have. That said, every dollar helps.

This monetary request represents the latest facet of the experiment: we want to make as big an influence as we can, as positive, to create the best small press experience possible. We are exploring our options. We would like the ability to buy the books we house straight from the publishers (publishers who have thus far donated at their own expense). We want the freedom to begin writing workshops of our own and reading groups with extended hours, to make a more tangible impact. We want proper shelving and proper heating. We want you to be comfortable as well as taken care of. We want some good coffee, and we want to provide that coffee free of charge. The corners of our imagination are bulging here. If we get enough, who knows? A nice camera to record readings? An archive of those readings? (a true to gosh website?) A screen to project movies upon? A karaoke machine that only has poetry? Let us explore.

Our ability to accomplish these things will depend on what we can raise. Sure, we would love to secure a year of rent, and on top of that, extend the goodness. Like we said, everything helps. Our goal is to offer everyone the chance to transform the neighborhood and hopefully alter some of the stigmas surrounding community spaces much like ours (spaces we think will spread if we can set a good enough example).


Here is exactly what your money will help us accomplish:

1) $15,000 secures the future rent of Mellow Pages for exactly one year, allows us to focus on our event programming and frees up time to establish writing workshops and reading groups at extended hours. It also allows us to create a functional website.

2) $20,000 gives us the ability to go on a small press book buying spree (~$2,000) which will allow us to financially support the work we are passionate about and give back to the people who helped us along the way. It will also allow us to build the space to our desires, establish proper shelving and archive our readings for future consumption.

3) $20,000+ We begin to support the people who run and manage the space daily (7 days a week) whose time and energy help produce the programming of events and workshops, the upkeep of the space, the organization of the catalogue and the turnover of checkouts and memberships. If anyone is supportive of providing a small wage to the people who run and established Mellow Pages, these funds will extremely alter our lives. Your generosity will go further than you know, and we thank you for your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, please share this campaign and help us reach our goal! Anything within your power will give us a positive boost, so fear not!

If you have other services you'd like to provide or donate, please do! Everything is welcome and helpful. If you have the skills to help us build, please let us know. If you have heaters, refrigerators, shelves, wood, tools, etc. we would love to share. Know that aside from money there are many ways you can help, and of course we are always eager to receive books of all kinds. Thank You!

Email us with your ideas at mellowpageslibrary@gmail.com

Check out what we do here: http://instagram.com/mellowpageslibrary

story:
Please contribute to buying Sandy in a date auction (so she doesn't go home dateless and get boo'ed off the stage...) The money raised goes towards supporting high-impact projects with nonprofits in developing countries that focus on social development and sustainability. To find out more about this excellent organization and their projects, please visit http://wivp.org/home.

As an added bonus, I will bake you treats if you are in the Philly area. For those of you with big hearts that are remote, I will give you all the hugs you could want when we are reunited and wingwoman / shop for you / listen to rants about your boss / etc. THANK YOU so much for helping!!

PS If www.paypal.com is more your thing, my username is sandy.pillalamarri@gmail.com. <3

story:
I am fund raising to help cover some of the expenses of the trip. I am the only woman pilot crew member flying this airplane and may be one of the only women who is an active pilot flying in the D-Day festivities.

I have been flying for over 35 years and have flown many aircraft. It is an honor to fly this Veteran of the actual D-Day invasion June 6th 1944, back to Normandy for the 70th anniversary.

Please help me remember and honor all that women have contributed to the wartime efforts. The WASP's, WAVE's, WAC's, nurses and servicewomen as well Rosie the Riveter and all the other women who made sacrifices to help us win.  If you would like to find out more information on Return to Normandy go to rtn2014.org

We are often in the background.  We need to shine in the light!   Help me represent us!!  Lets see what we can do!!
